PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Miami, Oklahoma. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1964 Code, as supplemented through January 30, 1989, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the board of commissioners. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1964 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-2 and the first section of Chapter 4 is 4-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 3-1 and 3-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 3-1.5. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as Chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. 
Indices 
    The indices have been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within each index which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this republication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the republication. With this system, the republication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the appropriate page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the republication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this republication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the republication. As revised sheets are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This republication was under the direct supervision of Dennis Sinnett, Vice-President of Supplementation, Kelly Heaton-Moniz, Supervising Editor, and Janet Cramer, Editor/Proofreader, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to George G. Russell, Jr., City Attorney, and Krista Duhon, Paralegal, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this republication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida  
ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 1298 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the City of Miami, Oklahoma; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
Be it Ordained by the Mayor and Board of Commissioners of the City of Miami, Oklahoma as Follows: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances, City of Miami, Oklahoma" published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of Chapters 1 through 26, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before October 1, 1990, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding thirty (30) days or any combination thereof. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided, shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code, when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the city to make the same a part of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. Ordinances adopted after October 1, 1990, that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7. It being immediately necessary for the preservation of the peace, health, safety and public good of the City of Miami and inhabitants thereof that the provision of this ordinance be put into full force and effect, an emergency is hereby declared to exist by reason whereof this ordinance shall take effect and be in full force from and after the date of its passage, approval and publication. 
Passed and the Emergency Clause ruled upon separately this 18th day of March, 1991. 
/s/ Louis E. Mathia 
      Mayor   ATTEST:

PART I - CHARTER[1] 
PREAMBLE 
    We, the people of the City of Miami, Ottawa County, Oklahoma, under the authority of the Constitution of the State of Oklahoma, do ordain and establish this Charter for the City of Miami. 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Printed herein is the Charter of the City, Res No. CC2017-02, adopted Jan. 17, 2017, as approved and adopted by special election on April 4, 2017. Amendments to the Charter are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original ordinance. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. Formerly, the Charter was adopted at an election held January 6, 1910. See the Charter Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

ARTICLE I. -   

Sec. 1. - Powers in General. 
    That the inhabitants of the City of Miami, Ottawa County, Oklahoma, within the boundaries as the same now exist and are described by City Ordinances, and such additional territory as may be hereafter added thereto and their successors, be and the same are hereby created and organized as a municipal corporation, with perpetual succession, under the name and style of "City of Miami", and as such they and their successors are by these presents organized and created as a body politic and corporate, and shall succeed to own, possess and control all the books, records, documents and all the property, real, personal or mixed and all the rights, privileges, franchises, powers and immunities now belonging to and possessed or enjoyed by the municipal corporation known as the City of Miami; that it shall be subject to and liable for all legal debts which the present corporation is now or may hereafter become legally bound; that the corporation hereby created and its successors in said corporate name of "City of Miami" shall have the power to sue and be sued, plead and be inter-pleaded, complain, intervene, prosecute and defend in all courts; it shall have the power to make contracts, to take and to acquire property by purchase or otherwise, necessary for the public good and to own, hold, sell, lease, convey or otherwise dispose of any real or personal property within or outside of the city limits; that it shall have, exercise and enjoy other and additional powers, rights, privileges, franchises and immunities as are granted by existing laws or may be granted or conferred by any other provisions hereinafter adopted; that it shall use a corporate seal of such design as the City Council shall designate. This Charter continues the form of government similar to the statutory Council-Manager form with a mayor to be elected at large and one City Council member to be elected from each of the four wards by the citizens of Miami. 
Sec. 2. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries and limits of said city shall exist as at the time of the adoption of this Charter, until altered as provided in the Oklahoma laws as the same may be amended from time to time. 
Sec. 3. - Application of State Law. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided for herein, the Constitution and laws of the State of Oklahoma as the same may be amended from time to time, control the rights, powers, duties and procedures of the City of Miami, Oklahoma, and all of its officers and employees. 
ARTICLE II. -   

Sec. 1. - Exercise of powers. 
    All powers conferred upon the City of Miami shall, unless otherwise provided in this Charter, be exercised by a governing body consisting of one (1) City Council member from each of four wards and one (1) mayor to be elected at large. 
Sec. 2. - Duties of mayor-Succession of mayor. 
    The mayor shall preside at meetings of the City Council and shall be a voting member thereof. The Mayor may not, however, vote on any appointments that he/she may make under this Charter. The mayor shall be recognized as head of the city government for all ceremonial purposes and by the Governor for purposes of military law. The mayor shall have no regular administrative duties except that the mayor will sign all conveyances and other written obligations of the city as the City Council may require. At a regular meeting first after the election and installation into office of the mayor, or any other time there is a vacancy in the position of Mayor Pro Tempore, the mayor shall nominate, subject to confirmation by said City Council, one City Council member who shall hold the office of "Mayor Pro Tempore" who shall continue to hold such title and office until the earlier of the expiration of the term of office for which he/she was elected or the expiration of the term of office of the mayor, unless removed therefrom, but shall receive no extra compensation for such extra service. The mayor pro tempore shall act as mayor during the temporary absence, disability or suspension of the mayor. In the event of the death or other permanent absence of the Mayor for whatever reason, the mayor pro tempore shall assume the position as mayor until the expiration of the term of office for which the mayor had been elected and a vacancy shall be declared on the City Council for the ward from which the mayor pro tempore had been elected. 
Sec. 3. - Qualifications of City Council members. 
    The City Council members and mayor shall be residents and registered voters of the city. The City Council members shall have been residents and registered voters of the City of Miami for at least two years next preceding their election and of their respective ward for at least six (6) months prior to filing a declaration of candidacy and during his/her term of office. The mayor shall have been a resident and registered voter of the City of Miami for at least two years preceding his/her election and during his/her term of office. A City Council member whose residence changes from their ward or a mayor whose residence changes from the city during their term of office shall cause that office to become vacant. 
Sec. 4. - Salaries. 
    The compensation of all City Council members shall be fixed by ordinance. Provided, that if at any time, the Charter or ordinances of the city should be so amended as to increase or diminish the salary of such City Council members, said change shall not become effective during the existing term of any City Council member but shall become effective only at the beginning of the next term when the next or re-elected City Council member is sworn into office. All City Council members shall be reimbursed for actual expenses in the performance of their duties, including but not limited to travel expenses, appropriate meals and lodging. In lieu of reimbursement the city manager may arrange for direct payment of the actual expenses. 
Sec. 5. - Oath and bonds. 
    Each City Council member and such other employees as determined necessary by law or ordinance, before entering upon the duties of his/her office, shall take and subscribe to the oath or affirmation of office prescribed by the Oklahoma Constitution. The oath or affirmation shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. The City Council shall require the city treasurer, any officer or employee designated by law or ordinance to sign municipal warrants or municipal checks, and any other officers and employees as the City Council may designate by ordinance, to give bond for the faithful performance of his/her duties within ten (10) days after his/her election or appointment, in such amount and form as the City Council shall prescribe. The city shall pay the premiums on such bonds. 
Sec. 6. - Powers vested in City Council-Designated powers. 
    All powers of the city as set out herein, including the determination of policy, shall be vested in the City Council. Without limitation of the foregoing, the City Council may: 
1.  Appoint and remove the city manager, the city attorney, the city prosecutor, the municipal judge, and the city treasurer as provided by law and this Charter; 
2.  Enact municipal legislation subject to limitations as may now or hereafter be imposed by the Oklahoma Constitution and law; 
3.  Set, and, if necessary, amend the budget, raise revenue, make appropriations, regulate salaries and wages, and all other fiscal affairs of the city, subject to such limitations as may now or hereafter be imposed by the Oklahoma Constitution and law; 
4.  Inquire into the conduct of any office, department, agency, commission or board of the city, and investigate municipal affairs, or authorize and provide for such inquiries; 
5.  Appoint or elect and remove its own subordinates, members of commissions and boards and other quasi-legislative or quasi-judicial officers as provided by law or ordinance, or prescribe the method of appointing or electing and removing them; 
6.  Create, change and abolish any necessary or appropriate office, department, agency, commission or board other than those established by this Charter or by law, and assign additional functions and duties to such offices, departments, agencies, commissions or boards so established; and 
7.  Grant pardons for violations of municipal ordinances, including the remission of fines and costs, upon the recommendation of the municipal judge. 
Sec. 7. - Limitation of City Council authority to act through city manager. 
    Except for the purposes of inquiry, the City Council and its members shall deal with the administrative service of the city solely through the city manager. The City Council and its members may not: 
1.  Direct or request the city manager or other authority to appoint or remove officers or employees; 
2.  Participate in any manner in the appointment or removal of officers and employees of the city, except as provided by this Charter or by law; or 
3.  Give orders on ordinary administrative matters to any subordinate of the city manager either publicly or privately. 
Sec. 8. - City manager-Appointment by City Council. 
    The City Council shall appoint a city manager pursuant to this Charter, by a vote of a majority of all its members subject to the terms of employment established by the City Council. It shall choose the city manager solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications with special preference to the actual experience in, or the knowledge of, accepted practice in respect to the duties of the office. At the time of appointment, the city manager need not be a resident of the city or state; but within sixty (60) days and during the tenure of holding office thereafter, the city manager shall reside within the boundaries of the city, any school district or districts that overlap the city boundaries, or within an area which the City Council may approve under the terms of employment established by the City Council. City managers may appoint themselves, or the City Council or other authority may appoint or elect the city manager to other offices and positions in the city government, subject to regulations prescribed by ordinance; but the city manager may not receive compensation for service in such other offices or positions. Neither the mayor nor any members of the City Council may be appointed city manager during the term for which they shall have been elected nor within two (2) years after they cease to hold such office. 
Sec. 9. - City manager-Duties. 
    The city manager shall be the chief executive officer and head of the administrative branch of the city government. He/she shall execute the laws and administer the government of the city, and shall be responsible therefor to the City Council. He/she shall: 
1.  Appoint, and when necessary for the good of the service, remove, demote, lay off or suspend all heads of administrative departments and other administrative officers and employees of the city except the city attorney, the city prosecutor, the municipal judge, or the city treasurer as otherwise provided by law. The manager or the City Council by ordinance may authorize the head of a department, office, or agency to appoint and remove the subordinates in such department, office, or agency; 
2.  Supervise and control all administrative departments, officers, and agencies under his or her control; 
3.  Submit to the City Council a report after the end of the fiscal year on the finances and administrative activities of the city for the preceding year; 
4.  Prepare a budget annually and submit it to the City Council and be responsible for the administration of the budget after it goes into effect; and recommend to the City Council any changes in the budget which he/she deems desirable; 
5.  Keep the City Council advised of the financial condition and future needs of the city, and make recommendations as the city manager deems desirable; 
6.  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by law or by policy or ordinance; and 
7.  Except as may be specifically prohibited by law, this Charter, ordinance, or subject to regulations by the City Council, the city manager may delegate any duty to other employees as he/she deems appropriate. 
Sec. 10. - Designation of acting city manager. 
    The city manager, by letter filed with the city clerk, may appoint a qualified administrative officer of the city to be acting city manager during the temporary absence or disability of the city manager which prohibits him/her from performing his/her duties. The City Council may appoint an acting city manager whenever: 
1.  The city manager fails to make such designation; 
2.  The City Council suspends the city manager; or 
3.  There is a vacancy in the office of city manager. 
Sec. 11. - Suspension or removal of city manager. 
    The City Council may suspend or remove the city manager or acting city manager at any time by a vote of a majority of all its members. 
Sec. 12. - Purchases and sales by city manager-Competitive bidding. 
A.  The city manager may enter contracts, work orders and shall purchase, or issue purchase authorizations for all supplies, materials, and equipment for offices, departments, and agencies of the city government, subject to any regulations which the City Council may prescribe. Every contract or purchase exceeding an amount to be established by the City Council shall require the prior approval of the City Council except in the case of a declared emergency as otherwise provided by law. The city manager may also sell or transfer to or between offices, departments, and agencies surplus or obsolete supplies, materials, and equipment, subject to regulations the City Council may prescribe. 
B.  Within the requirements of law, the City Council may prescribe requirements and procedures for competitive bidding. When required by law, ordinance or in accordance with regulations the City Council may prescribe, notice and opportunity for competitive bidding shall be given before a purchase or contract for supplies, materials, or equipment is made, and before a sale of any surplus or obsolete supplies, materials, or equipment is made. The City Council shall not exempt a particular contract, purchase, or sale from the requirement of competitive bidding except in the case of a declared emergency or as otherwise provided by law. 
Sec. 13. - City clerk. 
    The city clerk shall be an officer of the city, appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term. The city clerk shall serve as clerk for the City Council. Subject to regulations the City Council may prescribe, the city clerk shall: 
1.  keep the journal of the proceedings of the City Council; 
2.  enroll all ordinances and resolutions passed by the City Council in a book or set of books kept for that purpose; 
3.  have custody of documents, records, and archives as may be provided for by law or by ordinance, and have custody of the seal of the city; 
4.  attest and affix the seal of the city to documents as required by law or by ordinance; and 
5.  have such other powers, duties, and functions related to his/her statutory duties as may be prescribed by law, policy or by ordinance. The person who serves as city clerk may be employed by the city to perform duties not related to his/her position as city clerk. The salary, if any, for said duties may be provided for separately by ordinance. 
Sec. 14. - City treasurer 
    The city treasurer shall be an officer of the city, appointed by the City Council for an indefinite term. The City Council may allow the same person to hold both the office of city clerk and the office of city treasurer. Subject to such regulations as the City Council may prescribe, the city treasurer shall deposit daily funds received for the city in depositories as the City Council may designate. The city treasurer shall have such other powers, duties, and functions related to his/her duties as may be prescribed by law, policy or by ordinance. The person who serves as city treasurer may be employed by the city to perform duties not related to his/her position as city treasurer. The salary, if any, for said duties may be provided for separately by ordinance. 
Sec. 15. - Departments included. 
    There shall be maintained a department of law headed by a city attorney selected and employed by the City Council and a police department and a fire department as set forth by law or ordinance, and such other administrative departments, offices and agencies as the City Council may establish. 
ARTICLE III. -   

Sec. 1. - City Council meetings. 
    The City Council shall meet at least monthly at such times as it may prescribe by ordinance or otherwise. The mayor, individually, or any two City Council members, collectively, may call special meetings. 
Sec. 2. - City Council-Quorum-Rules. 
    A majority of all the members of the City Council shall constitute a quorum, but a smaller number may adjourn the meeting. The City Council shall determine its own rules. 
Sec. 3. - Vacancy on the City Council. 
    Should a vacancy occur on the City Council, (excepting the mayor) the mayor shall appoint another person to fill such vacancy and shall submit his/her name to the Council; if a nomination shall have the approval of a majority of the remaining City Council, said appointment shall take effect from and after confirmation of such appointee. In the event said City Council shall fail or refuse to confirm such nomination, the mayor shall make another nomination for said office and shall continue to do so until a nomination shall be confirmed by said City Council; and such appointee shall serve as a member of said City Council during the remaining unexpired term of his/her predecessor or until his/her successor is elected and qualified, unless sooner removed, and shall be entitled to the salary and other benefits of said office for the time he/she shall perform the duties thereof. 
ARTICLE IV. -   

Sec. 1. - Notice of City Election. 
    The city adopts the provisions of law as shown at 11 Oklahoma Statutes § 16-101 (Notice of Municipal Elections) as the same may be amended from time to time for its notice requirements for all city elections. 
Sec. 2. - General city elections-When held. 
    General city elections shall be held on the first Tuesday in April or on such other date(s) authorized by law or as may be otherwise approved by resolution or ordinance of the City Council. 
Sec. 3. - Mayor and City Council-Election and terms of office. 
A.  The mayor and City Council members each are elected for three (3) year terms. The mayor is elected at large by the registered voters of the entire city who vote in an election for that purpose. Each City Council member (other than mayor) is elected solely by the registered voters of the respective ward in an election for that purpose. The candidate who receives the highest number of votes shall be declared elected. Each term commences at the first regular meeting in May following the respective election and shall continue until the term expires, the Council member resigns or is removed. The term of the City Council members currently serving will continue until the election as set out in the following subsections. 
B.  Mayor. The mayor's current term is scheduled to end after the 2017 election and at the first meeting of the City Council in May, 2017. 
C.  City Council members from Wards 1 (NE) and 2 (NW). City Council members from Wards 1 and 2 current terms each are scheduled to end after the 2019 election and at the first meeting of the City Council in May, 2019. 
D.  City Council members from Wards 3 (SW) and 4 (SE). City Council members from Wards 3 and 4 current terms each are scheduled to end after the 2018 election and at the first meeting of the City Council in May, 2018 
Sec. 4. - Manner of becoming a candidate-Declaration of candidacy. 
    To become a candidate, a declaration of candidacy must be filed with the county election board within the times provided by law, including Title 11, Oklahoma Statutes, Article XVI as the same may be amended from time to time, or otherwise provided by municipal ordinance. 
Sec. 5. - Nonpartisan elections. 
    Municipal elections shall be nonpartisan and all qualified candidates shall file as independent candidates. No primary elections shall be held in a nonpartisan election. Any election proclamation or notice of election providing for a primary election shall be deemed to be amended by operation of this Charter to delete the call for a primary election and each candidate shall appear on the ballot as an independent candidate without party or other designation. 
Sec. 6. - Filing as a candidate in nonpartisan municipal election. 
    Filing as a candidate in a nonpartisan municipal election or voting for such candidate shall not affect one's political party affiliation. A qualified candidate may have his or her name printed upon the nonpartisan general municipal election ballot as candidate for any office to be filled at the election. 
Sec. 7. - Unopposed candidates in general election. 
    Any candidate who is unopposed for an office in a general municipal election shall be deemed elected and certified; and his/her name shall not appear on the general election ballot. If there is only one candidate for each of the offices which are to be filled at the election, and no questions are to be voted upon at the election, the general municipal election shall not be held. 
Sec. 8. - Special elections-Questions which may be submitted. 
    When the City Council shall deem it advisable, it may, by resolution or proclamation, authorize the mayor to call a special election for the purpose of submitting to the registered voters of the city any appropriate question, including, but not limited to the issuing of municipal bonds, of granting any franchise, of calling for a removal election, as provided in Section 9 of this Article, or for any other purpose authorized by law or ordinance. 
Sec. 9. - City Council member may be removed. 
    Any City Council member (including the mayor) may be removed at any time by the electors of the city qualified to vote for a successor of such incumbent. The removal of an incumbent City Council member shall be as follows: A petition, signed by electors entitled to vote for a successor to the incumbent sought to be removed, equal in number to thirty per centum of the entire vote cast for that position at the last preceding general municipal election demanding an election of a successor of the person sought to be removed shall be filed with the city clerk, which petition shall contain a general statement of the grounds and charges for which the removal is sought. The signatures to the petition need not all be appended to one paper, but each signer shall add to his/her signature his/her place of residence, giving his/her street number; one of the signers of each paper shall make oath before an officer competent to administer the same, that the statements therein made are true as he/she believes and that such signatures to the paper appended is the genuine signature of the person whose name it purports to be. Within ten days from the date of filing such petition the city clerk shall examine and, from the voters' register, ascertain whether or not said petition is signed by the requisite number of qualified electors and he/she shall attach to said petition his/her certificate showing the result of said examination. If by the clerk's certificate the petition is shown to be insufficient it may be amended within ten days from date of said certificate. The clerk shall within ten days after such amendment, make a like examination of the amended petition and if his/her certificate shall show the same to be insufficient it shall be returned to the persons filing the same without prejudice to the filing of a new petition to the same or similar effect. If the petition shall be found sufficient, the clerk shall submit the same to the City Council without delay. If the petition shall be found sufficient the said City Council shall within thirty days from the date of the clerk's certificate to the said City Council declare by proclamation that a sufficient petition is filed. Such proclamation shall contain the following information: 
1.  The setting of a filing period of three (3) days, on a consecutive Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday not less than ten (10) days nor more than twenty (20) days from the date of such proclamation; 
2.  The setting of the date of the Special Election, not less than forty-five (45) days nor more than sixty (60) days after the close of the filing period. A copy of the proclamation shall be filed with the secretary of the county election board not less than sixty (60) days preceding the date of the special general election. 
Sec. 10. - Successor of any removed City Council member. 
    The City Council shall make or cause to be made a legal publication of notice and all arrangements for filing for office and holding the election as provided for in Section 9 of this Article and the same shall be conducted, returned and the results thereof declared in all respects as other city elections. Any person sought to be removed may be a candidate to succeed himself/herself and unless he/she requests otherwise in writing, the clerk shall place his/her name on the official ballot without filing. In any such removal election, the candidate receiving the highest number of votes shall be declared elected at such an election; if some person other than the incumbent receives the highest number of votes and shall be declared elected as such, the incumbent shall thereupon be deemed to be removed from the office held by him/her upon qualification of his/her successor. In case the party who received the highest number of votes fails to qualify within ten days thereafter, having received notice of such election, the office shall be declared vacant by said City Council. The successor of any City Council member so removed shall hold office during the unexpired term of his/her predecessor. If the incumbent receives the highest number of votes cast at such an election, he/she shall continue in office for the balance of that term. This method of removal shall be cumulative and in addition to the other methods provided by law. 
CERTIFICATE 
    I, the undersigned and duly elected Mayor of the City of Miami, Oklahoma, do hereby certify that at a duly and legally called election held in and for the City of Miami on the 4th day of April, 2017, said election being called for the purpose of submitting to the voters of the City of Miami, pursuant to 11 O.S. § 13-112, the question of whether the then existing Charter of the City of Miami, Oklahoma, should be revoked and adopt in its place the within and foregoing Charter. I further certify that the forgoing Charter is the original Charter, adopted by the City Council by Resolution CC2017-02 on the 17th day of January, 2017, and submitted to the voters of the City of Miami on the 4th day of April, 2017; and which was adopted and approved by them with 228 voting for the proposition and 71 voting against the proposition. 
    In witness whereof, I have hereunto executed the foregoing Charter in duplicate this 18th day of April, 2017. 
      Rudy Schultz, Mayor   [Seal]

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Miami, Oklahoma," and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Miami Municipal Code." 
(Code 1964, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Codification of ordinances, 11 O.S. § 14-108. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the mayor and board of commissioners, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the mayor and board of commissioners: 
    Board of commissioners. Whenever the words "board of commissioners," "board," "this board," or "the board" are used, they shall mean the board of commissioners of the City of Miami, Oklahoma. 
    City. The word "city" shall mean the City of Miami, in Ottawa County, Oklahoma. 
    Commissioner. The word "commissioner" shall mean a member of the board of commissioners of the City of Miami, Oklahoma. 
    Computation of time. In computing any period of time prescribed or allowed, the day of the act, event, or default from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so computed shall be included, unless it is a Saturday, a Sunday, or a legal holiday as defined by state law, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day which is not a Saturday, a Sunday, or a legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven (7) days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays as defined by state law, or any other day when the city offices shall be excluded in the computation. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 12 O.S. § 2006. 
    County. The word "county" shall mean Ottawa County, Oklahoma. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Highway. The term "highway" shall include any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three (3) or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared. 
    May. The word "may" is to be construed as being permissive. 
    May not. The words "may not" state a prohibition. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Must. The word "must" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
    Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officers, departments, etc. Whenever any officer, department, board, commission or other agency is referred to by title alone, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Miami, Oklahoma." 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the word "person," as applied to partnerships or associations, shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Roadway. The word "roadway" shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Shall. The word "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription. The word "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Oklahoma. 
    Street. The term "street" shall include any highway, alley, street, avenue or public place, square, bridge, viaduct, underpass, overpass, tunnel or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Written or in writing. The words "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1964, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections, references to sections, history notes, footnotes. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of such sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  All references in this Code to chapters or sections are to chapters or sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
(c)  All statements of legislative history (history notes) appearing after sections or subsections of this Code are provided for the convenience of the user and are not part of this Code. 
(d)  All editor's notes, Charter references, and state law references appearing in footnote form in this Code are provided for the convenience of the user of the Code and are not part of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 1-2) 
Sec. 1-4. - Amendments or additions to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the mayor and board of commissioners. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "Section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Miami, Oklahoma, is hereby amended to read as follows: ...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "The Code of Ordinances, City of Miami, Oklahoma, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _____, which said section reads as follows: ...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(Code 1964, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-5. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  In this section a violation of this Code means: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; or 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(4)  A violation of this Code shall not include the failure of a city officer or employee to perform an official duty unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. 
(5)  With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate violation punishable as a separate offense. 
(b)  The Municipal Court may not impose a penalty, including fine or deferral fee in lieu of a fine and costs, which is greater than that established by a state statute for the same offense. In the event that a state statute provides a specific penalty for the same offense which is less, in whole or in part, than the general penalty provided by this Section, then such lesser penalty provided by state statute shall apply to cap the penalty for a violation of the respective municipal ordinance. 
(c)  The Municipal Court may not impose a penalty, including fine or deferral fee in lieu of fine and costs, which exceeds the authority granted by 11 O.S. § 14-111. In the event that a state statute provides a specific penalty for the same offense which is greater, in whole or in part, than the authority granted by 11 O.S. § 14-111, then the applicable provision of 11 O.S. § 14-111 shall apply to cap the penalty for a violation of the respective municipal ordinance. 
(d)  Except as otherwise restricted by law, a person convicted of a violation of a section of this Code shall be punished as set forth in that section and in the absence of such provision, by the following maximum fine or deferral fee in lieu of a fine: 
(1)  The maximum fine or deferral fee in lieu of a fine for traffic-related offenses relating to speeding or parking shall not exceed $200.00. 
(2)  The maximum fine or deferral fee in lieu of a fine for all other offenses, the maximum fine or deferral fee in lieu of a fine shall not exceed $500.00. 
(3)  The City of Miami has determined as a matter of policy that no offence against its Code of Ordinances will be punishable by incarceration for such offense, and therefore there is no imprisonment set for any violation of the City's ordinances. Provided, however, if in the discretion of the municipal judge, incarceration is appropriate as a means to address willful violations of court orders, it is a possible remedy he or she may utilize for contempt of court, within the parameters otherwise set by law. 
(e)  A person convicted of a violation of municipal ordinances regulating the pretreatment of wastewater and regulating stormwater discharges shall be punished by a maximum fine or deferral fee in lieu of a fine which shall not exceed $500.00. 
(f)  The Clerk of the Court is authorized to charge and collect court costs and fees in the amount(s) and in the manner provided by State Statutes, including, but not limited to 11 O.S. § 27-126 (Court Costs and Fees) and section 14-34 (Costs taxed to defendant) of this Code of Ordinances. 
(g)  Persons convicted of a violation of this Code may be required to make restitution to their victim. Persons convicted of a violation of this Code may be required to undergo evaluations, counseling, community service and other such remedial programs as may be provided for by this Code or otherwise allowed by law. 
(h)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of any license, permit or franchise. 
(i)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent equitable relief. 
(Code 1964, § 1-5; Ord. No. 1478, § 1, 6-17-04; Ord. No. 1594, § 1, 11-5-12; Ord. No. 2017-10, § 1, 12-5-2017) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to enforce ordinances by fine, Art. III, § 32; collection of fines, Art. III, § 33. 
Cross reference- Municipal court, ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, 11 O.S. § 14-111. 
Sec. 1-6. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and board of commissioners that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable and, if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the mayor and board of commissioners without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1964, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-7. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any appropriation or budget ordinance; 
(2)  Any ordinance authorizing or relating to the issuance or redemption of bonds; 
(3)  Any ordinance approving or authorizing specific contracts; 
(4)  Any ordinance authorizing a specific sale, lease or purchase of property; 
(5)  Any ordinance levying or assessing taxes not inconsistent with this Code; 
(6)  Any ordinance granting rights-of-way, franchises or easements; 
(7)  Any ordinance annexing territory to, excluding territory from, the city or describing the city boundaries; 
(8)  Any ordinance calling specific elections or providing for special elections; 
(9)  Any ordinance making special assessments for local improvements; 
(10)  Any ordinance creating or relating to specific sewer and paving districts or other specific improvement districts; 
(11)  Any ordinance establishing the grades of specific streets and other public ways; 
(12)  Any ordinance naming or changing the names of specific streets and other public ways; 
(13)  Any ordinance creating, dedicating, vacating or closing specific streets, alleys or other public ways; 
(14)  Any ordinance amending the zoning map or approving or disapproving a subdivision plat; 
(15)  Any ordinance rezoning property; 
(16)  Any ordinance dealing with the compensation, retirement, pensions or other benefits of city officers and employees; 
(17)  Any ordinance which is temporary although general in effect; 
(18)  Any ordinance which is special although permanent in effect; 
(19)  Any ordinance the purpose of which has been accomplished. 
Sec. 1-8. - Provisions deemed continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same in substance as ordinances existing at the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-9. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the City in effect on the date of adoption of this Code, except as otherwise provided. 
Sec. 1-10. - State laws adopted. 
    Statutes duly adopted by the State of Oklahoma which are not otherwise in conflict with the Charter and ordinances of the City of Miami but which in fact add to the police power of the City of Miami are hereby adopted and may be prosecuted in Miami's municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 1359, § 1, 3-17-97) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Oklahoma Municipal Code, 11 O.S. § 1-101. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Regulation of cable television rates. 
(a)  The city will follow the FCC rate regulations (as such have been and may be amended from time to time by the FCC) in its regulation of the basic service rates and charges of the company and any other cable television system operating within the city's jurisdiction, notwithstanding any different or inconsistent provisions in the franchise. 
(b)  In connection with such regulation, the city will ensure a reasonable opportunity for consideration of the views of interested parties by: (1) making available for public inspection, at a time and location to be specified by public notice, a copy of any rate filing submitted by the company to the city (hereinafter "rate filing"); (2) after public notice, accepting written comments submitted by interested parties and convening a public hearing within twenty (20) days (or more, but less than thirty (30) days) of the submission of such rate filing by the company; and (3) accepting additional public comments and/or convening further public hearings as the city deems necessary or desirable in carrying out its rate regulatory function in a fair and efficient manner which assures adequate public participation (for example, if the city avails itself of the additional ninety- or one hundred fifty-day periods permitted by the FCC to complete its review of the company's rate filing). 
(c)  In connection with subsections (a) and (b) above, the city will comply with all state and local requirements that apply to public participation in the city's regulation of the basic service rates and charges of the company and any other cable television system operating within the city's jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1322, § 1, 2-7-94) 
Secs. 2-2-2-25. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 2-36. - Position created. 
    There is hereby created the position of superintendent of public administration of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-37. - Appointment. 
    The mayor shall appoint, by and with the majority consent of the board of commissioners, the superintendent of public administration. Such employee shall hold such position until his successor is chosen and qualified. 
(Code 1964, § 2-18) 
Sec. 2-38. - Responsibilities. 
    The superintendent of public administration shall have the following responsibilities: 
(1)  Attend staff meetings with all departmental heads to inform them of such needed information as to coordination of projects being conducted or planned in other departments within the city. 
(2)  Gather information to make monthly reports to be given to the board of commissioners on a monthly basis. 
(3)  Gather information and related facts so mayor and commissioners can make evaluations of departments to establish needs and priorities that will be placed in a format with other compiled data so that if outside funding, such as state or federal monies are available they may be applied for in the proper manner. 
(4)  Compile information so mayor and commissioners can create and maintain an affirmative action program for the city. 
(5)  Work with any group of citizens or committees designated by the mayor and commissioners to keep both parties informed and to compile such information as both would desire. 
(6)  Assist mayor and commissioners in filing applications for federal or state assistance; after funding is successful, work with those agencies until project is completed and finalized. 
(7)  Attend negotiations on behalf of the city administration with unions of city employees. 
(8)  Work with department heads, city clerk, mayor and commissioners in formulating, preparing and finalizing a budget for the city. 
(9)  Coordinate with each department head in the screening of employees to be hired and to make sure that federal regulations dealing with hiring practices are complied with. 
(10)  Work with departments of other governmental agencies and coordinate with department heads to keep them informed of new regulations, such as wage and hour laws and safety laws that must be adhered to by cities. 
(11)  Cooperate with outside engineering firms so that needed data may be compiled on any project being conducted for the city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-19) 
Secs. 2-39-2-55. - Reserved.

DIVISION 4. - CITY ENGINEER AND BUILDING INSPECTOR[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 

Sec. 2-76. - Position created, appointment. 
    The dual offices of city engineer and city building inspector is hereby created and established. The city engineer and city building inspector positions shall be appointed by the city manager, and can consist of either: 1) an individual employed by the city, or 2) a consultant firm hired on a contract basis. The city manager will further have the discretion to determine if the same individual or firm could fulfill both these positions. If the city manager determines that a consulting firm or firms are appropriate to fill these positions, the city council and public utility board must approve any contract between the city and the firm prior to said firm providing services to the city. 
(Code 1964, § 5-19; Ord. No. 1408, § 2, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 1432, § 1, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 2-77. - Qualifications. 
    The city engineer and city building inspector must be able to show proof of appropriate state licensure or certification in the field of civil engineering and building inspections or the equivalent thereof, and be able to demonstrate to the city manager sufficient relevant experience in municipal engineering duties. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 3, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 1432, § 1, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 2-78. - Duties and inspections. 
(a)  The city engineer and city building inspector is hereby placed under control and direct supervision of the city manager. 
(b)  The city engineer and city building inspector shall advise the city manager and appropriate boards on all engineering matters referred to their office, and shall perform such duties as are provided by law or ordinance, and in addition thereto, such other duties as from time to time may be imposed upon their office by the city manager. These positions shall, from time to time, as required by the city manager, make reports regarding public improvements, repairs of streets, bridges and sidewalks or such other work as the city manager may request, and shall make such suggestions to the utility board and city council of the City of Miami, regarding the same, as shall in their judgment seem best and proper. The city engineer and city building inspector shall perform additional duties as requested by the city manager, in addition to these enumerated responsibilities. 
(c)  The city engineer and city building inspector shall further examine all buildings or structures in the course of erection or alteration to see that they conform to the provisions of the general statutes of the state, ordinances of the city and plans and regulations approved by city authorities, relating to the construction, repair and alteration and demolition or removal of buildings or structures within the city. They shall also, on complaint or any other information, examine existing and completed buildings or structures when there is reason to believe that an unsafe condition or violation of a provision of this or any other chapter of the Code of Ordinances exists. 
(d)  Whenever either the city engineer or city building inspector find, upon examination, that a violation of the provision of this chapter or of the accepted plans, or an unsafe condition exists, they shall endeavor to compel an immediate correction of the condition. Failing in this, they shall make a full report to the city manager on the conditions deemed to be unsafe or in violation, delivering a copy of said report to the owner or person in control of the premises. In addition, they shall collect all pertinent evidence for the information and use of the utility board and city manager, which shall proceed as provided in the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 5-21; Ord. No. 1408, § 4, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 1432, § 1, 10-1-01) 
Charter reference- Authority to inspect construction of buildings, Art. III, § 31. 
Sec. 2-79. - Right of entry; identification; police powers. 
    The city engineer and city building inspector, in the discharge of his duties, shall have authority at any reasonable hour to enter any premises, building or structure. For the purpose of identification, they shall adopt a badge of authority, which shall be displayed on demand, provided that, in an emergency any other method of identification shall be sufficient, and they shall have the authority of a police officer in all matters and conditions connected with the performance of his duties as city engineer and building inspector. 
(Code 1964, § 5-22; Ord. No. 1408, § 5, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 1432, § 1, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 2-80. - Records to be kept. 
    The city engineer and city building inspector shall keep accurate maps, plats and records of all public works, lands or property owned by the city and shall further keep a record, which shall be filed in the office of the city clerk, and shall be subject to inspection by any person entitled as well as the city officers as all reasonable hours. The city engineer and city building inspector shall retain on file copies of all papers in connection with building work so long as any part of the building or structure to which they relate may be in existence, except that construction plans need not be retained after the work shown on such plans has been completed and approved and accepted. 
(Code 1964, § 5-23; Ord. No. 1408, § 6, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 1432, § 1, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 2-81. - Monthly reports. 
    The city engineer and city building inspector shall make an itemized monthly report to the city manager of all permits granted, fees collected, certificates issued and order promulgated. 
(Code 1964, § 5-24; Ord. No. 1408, § 7, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 1432, § 1, 10-1-01) 
Sec. 2-82. - Building inspector. 
    The city building inspector is hired by the city manager. If the city engineering services are provided on a contract basis as promulgated in section 2-76, the city manager shall have final approval of the building inspector to be provided by said contract, if one is deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1408, § 8, 6-5-00; Ord. No. 1432, § 1, 10-1-01) 
Secs. 2-83-2-89. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-90. - City clerk. 
(a)  The mayor and city council shall appoint a person to the position of city clerk. The person who serves as city clerk may be employed by the city to perform other duties. In the absence of the appointment of a specific named individual to the office of city clerk, the city manager shall hold and exercise the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Compensation, benefits and other details of the employment of an individual to serve as city clerk shall be determined by written contract with the city council. 
(c)  The city clerk may, with the authorization of the city council, appoint and employ deputies. The city clerk may, with the authorization of the city manager, appoint individuals employed by the city manager to serve as deputies. The city clerk shall file written instruments evidencing the appointment of deputies in the records of the city clerk, and said deputy or deputies shall have such authority as the city clerk may delegate. 
(d)  In addition to all other responsibilities, powers, duties and functions imposed by state statute, state laws, municipal charter, municipal ordinance, and by employment contract, the city clerk shall, either in person or by deputy: 
(1)  Prepare and post all notice(s) for meetings as follows: 
a.  All regular, special and emergency meetings of the city council. Only the mayor, or two (2) or more council members, or the city manager may issue a call for a special or emergency meeting. 
b.  All regular, special and emergency meetings of the public utility board and all other subsidiary boards and committees of the city. Only the chairperson of such board, or two (2) or more members thereof, or the city manager may issue a call for a special or emergency meeting. 
c.  All regular, special and emergency meetings of a public trust authority for which the City of Miami is the beneficiary. Only the chairperson of such board may issue a call for a special or emergency meeting unless the trust indenture provides otherwise. 
(2)  Prepare and post all agenda(s) for meetings as follows: 
a.  Only the mayor, or two (2) or more council members, or the city manager may place an item or items on the agenda for a city council meeting. 
b.  Only the chairperson, or two (2) or more board members, or the city manager may place an item or items on the agenda for a meeting of the public utility board and all other subsidiary boards and committees of the city. 
c.  Only the chairperson of a public trust authority for which the City of Miami is the beneficiary may place an item or items on the agenda for a trust board meeting. 
(3)  Attend all meetings of the city council, utility board and all subsidiary boards and committees of the city, and all board of trustee meetings for public trust authorities of which the City of Miami is a beneficiary; and 
(4)  Keep the journal and official minutes of the meetings of the city council, utility board and all subsidiary boards and committees of the city; and 
(5)  If requested by any board(s) of trustees for any public trust authorities of which the City of Miami is a beneficiary, to keep the journal and official minutes of such board meeting(s); and 
(6)  Enroll all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council in a book or set of books kept for that purpose in the manner and form required by law, and to ensure that the ordinances of the city council are posted, published, codified, filed and recorded in the manner required by law; and 
(7)  Maintain files of all resolutions passed by the utility board and all subsidiary boards and committees of the city in the manner and form required by law; and 
(8)  If requested by any board(s) of trustees for any public trust authorities of which the City of Miami is a beneficiary, to maintain files of all resolutions passed by such board(s); and 
(9)  Have custody of city council documents, records, and archives. Assist the city manager with general city record-keeping and archival functions; and 
(10)  Have primary responsibility for receipt of and response to Oklahoma Open Records Act requests, and coordinate responses thereto with the city council, city manager and city attorney; and 
(11)  Immediately notify the city manager, city council and city attorney in writing upon receipt of any demand, claim or legal process directed to the city, its officials, officers, employees, agents, boards, commissions or any public trust authority of which the city is a beneficiary; and 
(12)  Have custody of the seal(s) of the city, and attest and affix the seal of the city to documents as required by law or by ordinance; and 
(13)  Maintain current contact information for all city elected officials, appointed officers, board and committee members and trustees of public trusts of which the city is a beneficiary. Maintain a list of all board and committee appointments, the date of appointment(s), the expiration of the term(s) of appointment, and contact information for such board and committee members. Ensure that the oaths of office and loyalty oaths required by state law are on file. Facilitate communication between the city council, city manager and city attorney with each other and with other board and committee members. Notify the city council by written instrument when a pending term of appointment is within thirty (30) days of expiration. 
(Ord. No. 1586, § 1, 7-16-12; Ord. No. 1599, § 1, 2-4-13) 
Secs. 2-91, 2-92. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - EMPLOYEE COMPENSATION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1592, § 1, adopted Nov. 5, 2012, set out provisions intended for use as Division 5, § 2-88. At the editor's discretion, to prevent duplication of division numbers, these provisions have been included as Division 6, § 2-93. 

Sec. 2-93. - Pay plan. 
    The City of Miami desires to recognize the exceptional performance of its employees through a competitive compensation system. The system will consist of four (4) major components. 
Pay System Components 
1.  Market comparability. 
2.  Cost of living adjustments. 
3.  Merit pool. 
4.  Sensational saver stipend. 
(1)  Market comparability. Biennially, in conjunction with the preparation of the respective year's budget, the city manager shall survey or cause to be surveyed the market of salaries paid by comparative employers. The city manager shall be the sole determinant in the establishment of the methodology and process used in the survey. The city manager shall make recommendations to the city council at the submission of the budget as to changes in the salary structures of the City of Miami based on the results of the salary survey. 
Market Surveyed Salary Range

(2)  Cost of living adjustments. Annually, in conjunction with the preparation of the fiscal year budget, the city manager shall identify an "across the board" adjustment to the pay ranges of the pay plan schedule of the City of Miami an amount equal to the U.S. City Average Consumer Price Index for the preceding month of February. This adjustment to the range shall not directly increase the pay of any employee. 
Cost of Living Adjustment

(3)  Merit pool. Annually, in conjunction with the preparation of the fiscal year budget, the city manager shall budget and recommend the formation of a merit pool line item. The amount of the merit pool shall be determined on the basis of the City of Miami's financial capabilities and performance at that particular point in time. Additionally, the city manager shall submit to the city council a series of performance goals for the city and its trusts to accomplish in the respective fiscal year. Each goal, if successfully met or exceeded, shall represent a respective percentage of the merit pool established in the fiscal year budget. Upon acceptance of city manager's recommendation to award merit funds the city council shall authorize the dispersal "across the board" of the merit pool to all employees in the form of a proportionate annual increase in base salary or a one-time stipend depending on status. For those employees who are below the mid-point of their respective pay range they shall be awarded the increase in an adjustment to their base pay. For employees at or above the mid-point the pay increase shall come in the form of a stipend (one-time payment). 
Merit Pool Award

(4)  Sensational saver stipend (SSS). Annually, in conjunction with the preparation of the fiscal year budget, the city manager shall budget a line item for the recognition of exceptional performance in identifying ways for the city to save money. Each department head in the month of November shall nominate subordinates for the receipt of a special and substantial stipend (one-time payment) for extremely sensational performance in identifying ways for the city to save significant money. The city manager shall convene a group to review the nominations and select award winners. Recipients will be recognized in December at a city function. 
    *Disclaimer, nothing in this pay plan shall constitute a contractual obligation to provide additional compensation to any employee and/or group. Changes in compensation are subject to availability of financial resources and acceptance and approval by the governing body of the City of Miami, which reserves the sole right to approve or disapprove said compensation. 
(Ord. No. 1592, § 1(2-88), 11-5-12) 
Secs. 2-99, 2-95. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY[6] 

Footnotes:
