State Law reference- Social security for public officers and employees, 51 O.S. § 121 et seq.; plans for coverage of municipal employees, 51 O.S. § 125. 

Sec. 2-116. - Extension of benefits; exclusions. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, at the earliest date, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law or this section, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of federal old age and survivors insurance as authorized by the federal social security act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734, 81st Congress. In pursuance of such policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(b)  There is hereby excluded from this section and the benefits extended hereby any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official now covered or authorized to be covered by any other ordinance creating any retirement system for any employee or official of the city, and any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position, or any employee or official, compensation for which is on a fee basis, or any position, or any employee who is an elected official of the city, or any position, or any employee or official not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1964, § 2-1) 
Sec. 2-117. - Execution of agreements. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state department of public welfare, as agent or agency, to secure coverage of employees and officials as provided in this division. 
(Code 1964, § 2-2) 
Sec. 2-118. - Withholdings from salaries or wages. 
    Withholdings from salaries or wages of employees and officials for the purpose provided in this division are hereby authorized to be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by such laws or regulations. 
(Code 1964, § 2-3) 
Sec. 2-119. - Appropriations. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds such amounts at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations for employer's contributions to the federal old age and survivors insurance program, which shall be paid over to the state or federal agency designated by such laws or regulations. 
(Code 1964, § 2-4) 
Sec. 2-120. - Records and reports. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations relative to old age and survivors insurance. 
(Code 1964, § 2-5) 
DIVISION 3. - ADDITIONAL RETIREMENT 

Sec. 2-121. - 457 Employee deferred compensation plan. 
    Pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of the state, and for the purpose of enabling municipal employees to enhance their retirement security, there is hereby authorized, approved and adopted, effective as of December 1st, 1997, a deferred compensation plan ("plan") of the city, executed counterpart of which is marked Exhibit A and attached to Ordinance No. 1371, on file with the city. 
(Ord. No. 1371, § 1, 11-3-97) 
Sec. 2-122. - Employee retirement system, defined benefit plan. 
(a)  [Created.] That pursuant to the authority conferred by the laws of the State of Oklahoma, and for the purpose of encouraging continuity and meritorious service on the part of city employees and thereby promote public efficiency, there is hereby authorized created, established, and approved and adopted, effective as of April 1, 2013, the amended and restated Plan designated "Employee Retirement System of the City of Miami, Oklahoma, Defined Benefit Plan," (hereinafter called System), an executed counterpart of which is marked Exhibit "A" (Joinder Agreement) and Exhibit "B" (amended and restated plan) and attached hereto as part hereof. This plan formerly known as Employees Retirement System of Miami, Oklahoma is hereby renamed to the "Employee Retirement System of the City of Miami, Oklahoma, Defined Benefit Plan" and this amended and restated plan replaces and supersedes the former plan known as Employees Retirement System of Miami, Oklahoma. 
(b)  Fund. A fund is hereby provided for the exclusive use and benefit of the persons entitled to benefits under the System. All contributions to such fund shall be paid over to and received in trust for such purpose by the city. Such fund shall be pooled for purposes of management and investment with similar funds of other incorporated cities, towns, and municipal trusts in the State of Oklahoma as a part of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund in accordance with the trust agreement of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, a public trust. The city shall hold such contributions in the form received, and from time to time pay over and transfer the same to the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund, as duly authorized and directed by the Board of Trustees. The fund shall be nonfiscal and shall not be considered in computing any levy when the annual estimate is made to the County Excise Board. 
(c)  Appropriations. The City of Miami, Oklahoma, is hereby authorized to incur the necessary expenses for the establishment, operation, and administration of the System, and to appropriate and pay the same. In addition, the City of Miami, Oklahoma, is hereby authorized to appropriate annually such amounts as are required in addition to employee contributions to maintain the System and the fin accordance with the provisions of the Defined Benefit Plan. Any appropriation so made to maintain the System and fund shall be for deferred wages or salaries, and for the payment of necessary expenses of operation and administration to be transferred to the trustees of the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund for such purposes and shall be paid into the fund when available, to be duly transferred to the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund. 
(d)  Government pick-up. Whereas, the Plan contains provisions which are intended to constitute a pick-up program by the employer which satisfies the requirements of Section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (the "Code"); and the Plan, as amended and restated, be, and it is, approved and adopted as of the date therein stated; and Mandatory Contributions (as defined in the Plan) are designated "picked-up" by the employer so as to not be included in Plan Participants ' gross income for Federal income tax purposes as provided in Section 414(h)(2) of the Code. All Mandatory Contributions are to be paid by the employer in lieu of contributions by the Plan Participant. No Participant in the Plan shall have the option of choosing to receive the amounts of Mandatory Contributions directly in lieu of having such amounts paid by the employer to the Trustees of the Plan. 
(e)  Execution. The mayor and city clerk be and they are each hereby authorized and directed to execute (in counterparts, each of which shall constitute an original) the System instrument, and to do all other acts and things necessary, advisable, and proper to put said System and related trust into full force and effect, and to make such changes therein as may be necessary to qualify the same under Sections 401(a) and 501(a) of the Internal Revenue Code of the United States. The counterpart attached hereto as Exhibit "A" and Exhibit "B", which has been duly executed as aforesaid simultaneously with the passage of this section and made a part hereof, is hereby ratified and confirmed in all respects. 
    This committee is hereby authorized and directed to proceed immediately on behalf of the City of Miami, Oklahoma, to pool and combine the fund into the Oklahoma Municipal Retirement Fund as a part thereof, with similar funds of such other cities and towns, for purposes of pooled management and investment. 
(f)  Survival. The provisions of the Special Retirement Option adopted by the City of Miami on March 5, 2013, by Ordinance #1603 shall survive this subsequent amendment and restatement of the Plan. 
(g)  Severability. If, regardless of cause, any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence or clause of this section, including the System as set forth in Exhibit "A" and Exhibit "B", is held invalid or to be unconstitutional, the remaining sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, or clauses shall continue in full force and effect and shall be construed thereafter as being the entire provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1510, §§ 1-3, 2-5-07; Ord. No. 1604, §§ 1-7, 3-5-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1510, §§ 1-3, adopted February 5, 2007, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § 2-122 was at the discretion of the editor. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Note- Exhibits "A" and "B" are not set out herein, but are on file and available for inspection in the city offices. 
Sec. 2-123. - Early retirement program. 
    The city adopts a 2013 Early Retirement Program which is composed of two parts: (i) a Special Retirement Option under the Employees Retirement System of Miami, Oklahoma, as described in subsection (1), below, and (ii) a retiree medical supplement, as described in subsection (2), below. 
(1)  Special Retirement Option: A current employee of the employer who is a participant and meets the eligibility requirements of Alternative #1 or Alternative #2 set forth below on February 28, 2013, and who retires from employment with the employer on or before April 15, 2013, may elect to receive a distribution of his or her Early Pension retirement benefit hereunder, calculated in the manner described in Section 6.2 of the Employees Retirement System of Miami, Oklahoma (the "Plan"), as modified by Alternative #1 or Alternative #2 below, as applicable. Such election must be made by the participant on or before April 5, 2013. The early pension provided hereunder shall be in lieu of any other benefit under the Plan. 
Alternative #1: Plus 5 Alternative 
Participants Eligible: To be eligible for Alternative # 1, a participant must be (i) an active employee as of February 28, 2013, and (ii) either age fifty-five (55) or older and have ten (10) or more years of credited service as of February 28, 2013, or age sixty (60) or older. 
Early Pension Provided: An early pension will be provided to the participant in accordance with Section 6.2 of the Plan, modified as follows: 
1.  Early pension will commence on the first day of the month coinciding with or next following participant's retirement. 
2.  If the participant is under age sixty-five (65), up to five (5) years are added to the participant's age when determining the early retirement reduction under Section 6.2 of the Plan. 
3.  If fewer than five (5) years are used under the prior sentence (because the participant is over age sixty (60)), the remaining part of the five (5) years are added to years of service for purposes of the pension formula in Section 6.2. In no event would the additional service credit be allowed to increase the participant's years of service to more than twenty (20) years (e.g., a participant age sixty-five (65) with twenty (20) or more years would receive no enhancement). 
4.  In the event that the Plan is amended on or prior to May 1, 2013 to enhance the formula for calculating an early pension under the Plan, then the early pension provided pursuant to this Plus 5 Alternative shall be calculated using the enhanced formula for the participant, if such formula yields a greater early pension than the preceding City of Miami Ordinance Amendment for early retirement provisions of this Plus 5 Alternative. 
Alternative #2: Rule of 80 Alternative 
Employees Eligible: To be eligible for Alternative #2, a participant must: (i) be an active employee on February 28, 2013, and (ii) meet the following Rule of 80: Age (rounded to two decimals) + years of credited service (rounded to two decimals) total 80 or more as of the February 28, 2013, measurement date. 
Early Pension Provided: An early pension will be provided to the participant in accordance with Section 6.2 of the Plan, modified as follows: 
1.  Early pension will commence on the first day of the month coinciding with or next following participant's retirement. 
2.  The early retirement reduction under Section 6.2 of the Plan would be eliminated. 
3.  In the event that the Plan is amended on or prior to May 1, 2013, to enhance the formula for calculating an early pension under the Plan, then the early pension provided pursuant to this Rule of 80 Alternative shall be calculated using the enhanced formula for the participant, if such formula yields a greater early pension than the preceding provisions of this Rule of 80 Alternative. 
(2)  [Retiree medical coverage:] With respect to any employee of the City of Miami, Oklahoma who meets the eligibility requirements for the Special Retirement Option described in subsection (1) above and who elects to receive the Special Retirement Option, the city shall provide to such retired employee, at no cost to the retired employee, retiree medical coverage under the city's group medical plan until the earlier of the individual 's attainment of age sixty-five (65) or eligibility for Medicare or any other employer provided group medical plan. Provided, however, in the event that the city concludes that the provision of such no cost retiree medical coverage would be discriminatory under Section 105(h) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, the city may instead pay the employee a taxable cash amount that is intended for the individual to use to pay the premiums for retiree coverage under the city's group medical plan for the period of coverage described in the prior sentence. 
(Ord. No. 1539, § 1, 2-2-09; Ord. No. 1603, §§ 1-3, 3-5-13; Ord. No. 1605, §§ 2, 3, 3-19-13) 
Secs. 2-124-2-140. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-156. - Created; purposes. 
    There is hereby created the economic development commission of the city for the purposes of: 
(1)  Assembling and providing information, ideas, and research results and to conduct research and advance proposals to promote the orderly development and use of the natural and human resources located in and around the city. 
(2)  To develop, maintain and review long-range plans, to accomplish the purposes for which the commission is created. 
(Code 1964, § 2-34) 
Sec. 2-157. - Membership; term and compensation. 
(a)  The commission created by this division shall be composed as follows: 
(1)  The mayor. 
(2)  The president of: 
a.  The First National Bank and Trust Company of Miami; 
b.  Security Bank and Trust Company; 
c.  Bank of Miami; and 
d.  Green Country Federal Savings and Loan Association. 
(3)  Chairman of the industrial committee of the Miami Chamber of Commerce. 
(4)  City clerk. 
(5)  The superintendent of public administration of the city and the manager of the Miami Chamber of Commerce shall be ex officio members of this commission. 
(b)  Members of the commission shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. Members of the commission shall serve without compensation and no members thereof shall receive any compensation from the city or from any trust, donation, or legacy for any service in such connection. 
(Code 1964, § 2-35) 
Sec. 2-158. - Duties. 
    The duties of the economic development commission shall be as follows: 
(1)  To support and assist the efforts of the city, local development corporations, industrial authorities and committees, chambers of commerce and other similar public and private agencies, to obtain new and foster expansion of existing agricultural, commercial, industrial and recreational facilities or enterprises. 
(2)  To maintain a continuing evaluation of sources available for the financing of the development or expansion of industrial and commercial facilities in and around this city. 
(3)  To assist in obtaining financing for the development and expansion of industrial and commercial facilities in and around this city. 
(4)  To serve as the city's official liaison agency between persons interested in locating new economic enterprises in and around this city. 
(Code 1964, § 2-36) 
Sec. 2-159. - Officers; meetings. 
    The economic development commission shall create and fill such offices as it may determine are necessary for the performance of its functions. The commission shall hold at least one (1) regular meeting in each month. It shall adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions and determinations. 
(Code 1964, § 2-37) 
Secs. 2-160-2-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DOWNTOWN REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authority and trust authority shall mean the Miami Downtown Redevelopment Authority, a public trust organized under the laws of this state, for which trust the declaration of trust was originally filed with the secretary of state on the 31st day of March 1987 and the amended declaration of trust was filed with the secretary of state on the 14th day of February 1990. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 6-4-90) 
Sec. 2-172. - Acceptance of beneficial interest. 
    The city does hereby accept the beneficial interest of the trust authority as set out therein. Further, the board of commissioners declares it to be the policy of the city to otherwise comply with the terms and conditions of the agreement of conveyance dated the 29th day of December 1989 between Ann Coleman, Susan C. Bassett and Sara C. Cecconi, d/b/a Coleman Properties and the city, whereby the Coleman Theatre was donated to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 6-4-90) 
Sec. 2-173. - Composition. 
    The trust authority shall consist of seven (7) members. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 6-4-90) 
State Law reference- Public trusts, 60 O.S. § 176 et seq. 
Sec. 2-174. - Appointment of trustees. 
    The trustees of the trust authority shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 6-4-90) 
Sec. 2-175. - Terms of trustees. 
    The initial appointment and confirmation of the trustees of the trust authority shall be such that the first trustee appointed shall serve and hold office for a term of one (1) year, the second for two (2) years, the third for three (3) years, the fourth for four (4) years, the fifth for five (5) years, the sixth for six (6) years and the seventh for seven (7) years. As the term of office of each trustee expires, such office shall be filled with an appointee who shall hold office for seven (7) years. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 6-4-90) 
Sec. 2-176. - Powers and duties. 
    The authority shall have the care, custody and management of the Coleman Theatre and such other properties located within the corporate limits of the city as the board of commissioners may delegate to it. Specifically included in those duties, but not by way of limitation, are the following: 
(1)  Hiring or contracting with a theatre manager and such other employees as it may deem necessary for the efficient administration of the Coleman Theatre and other properties; 
(2)  Overseeing the daily operation of the Coleman Theatre, including but not limited to setting and collecting the fees charged for the use of the Coleman Theatre and rental of business space therein; 
(3)  Receiving gifts, grants and donations of every kind for the renovation, maintenance and operation of the Coleman Theatre and other properties; 
(4)  Investing all monies received for the Coleman Theatre and other properties and expending such monies for the renovation, maintenance and operation of the Coleman Theatre and other properties as the authority deems appropriate so long as such investing and expending is in compliance with all applicable law and subject to audit by the city; 
(5)  Overseeing the renovation of the Coleman Theatre and other properties. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 6-4-90) 
Sec. 2-177. - Establishment of policies. 
    The authority may establish all necessary policies for the proper renovation, maintenance and operation of such facilities owned by the city; provided, however, the board of commissioners may, in its discretion, review, amend, repeal or add to any such policies. 
(Ord. No. 1293, § 1, 6-4-90) 
Secs. 2-178-2-187. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SPECIAL UTILITY AUTHORITY[8] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 1315, § 1, adopted July 6, 1993, set forth provisions intended for use as §§ 2-178-2-182. In order to provide room for future growth in Div. 3 of this article, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been renumbered §§ 2-188-2-192. 

Sec. 2-188. - Definition. 
    As used in this division, the term "authority" or "trust authority" shall mean The Miami Special Utility Authority, a public trust organization under the laws of the State of Oklahoma for which trust the declaration of trust was originally filed with the state secretary of state on January 7, 1982. 
(Ord. No. 1315, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 2-189. - Acceptance of beneficial interest. 
    The city accepted the beneficial interest of the trust authority as set out therein on September 8, 1981. 
(Ord. No. 1315, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 2-190. - Composition. 
    The trustees of this trust authority shall, ex officio, be the same persons who currently shall be the acting members of the legally-constituted governing body of the beneficiary without distinction as to the office held, subject to the conditions contained in the declaration of trust. 
(Ord. No. 1315, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 2-191. - General powers and duties. 
    The authority shall furnish and supply to the inhabitants utility services and facilities for the purposes of collection and disposing of solid waste. Specifically included in these duties, but not by way of limitation, are the following: 
(1)  Fix, demand, and collect charges, rates and fees for such service and facilities; 
(2)  To employ such agents, servants, and employees as they deem necessary, proper or convenient for the execution of the purposes of this trust; 
(3)  To manage, control and administer the trust, its property, assets and business and shall be absolutely and unconditionally free from direction and control of the beneficiary; 
(4)  To employ personnel necessary to manage and operate the incinerator facility, located in the city, as an enterprise operation; 
(5)  To establish a propriety fund separate and apart from all governmental funds to receive revenues to retire any revenue bonds that are used to acquire, maintain and operate the solid waste operation; 
(6)  To accept the city sanitation department's solid waste collection operation and establish a solid waste disposal regulation enforceable under the provisions of section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1315, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 2-192. - Policies. 
    The authority may establish all necessary policies for the proper maintenance and operation of facilities owned by the city to be used in connection with the collection and disposal of solid waste in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1315, § 1, 7-6-93)

ARTICLE V. - DEPARTMENTS

DIVISION 2. - DEPARTMENT OF LAW 

Sec. 2-221. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a department of law for the city. 
(Ord. No. 1295, 10-1-90) 
Sec. 2-222. - City attorney; [and city prosecutor]-Appointment, removal, qualifications. 
    There shall be a city attorney and a city prosecutor, who shall both be officers of the city and subject to removal by the Mayor and city council. The city attorney shall be director or head of the department of law. The city prosecutor will work within the department of law, and will have as a primary responsibility the prosecution of all municipal violations. Both shall be attorneys duly licensed to practice law within the state. The mayor and city council shall authorize all personnel positions in the department unless it delegates the power to appoint designated personnel to the city attorney subject to the approval of the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 1295, 10-1-90; Ord. No. 1417, § 1, 4-2-01) 
Sec. 2-223. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The city attorney shall be director or head of the department of law. The city prosecutor will work within the department of law, and will have as a primary responsibility the prosecution of all municipal violations. The city attorney and city prosecutor shall perform such duties as required of them by the mayor and city council, and as required by this Code, any ordinance, or the City Charter. It shall be the city attorneys duty to advise the mayor and city council upon all law questions, and he shall give opinions in writing when requested and shall represent the city as attorney in all litigations for or against the city unless the mayor and city council secures special counsel for particular proceedings. The city attorney shall perform such other legal services on behalf of the city, its officers and employees as may be required by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 1295, 10-1-90; Ord. No. 1418, § 1, 4-16-01) 
Secs. 2-224-2-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Sec. 2-301. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known as the Identity Theft Prevention Program (ITPP). 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-302. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to comply with 16 CFR § 681.2 in order to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft by identifying and detecting identity theft red flags and by responding to such red flags in a manner that will prevent identity theft. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-303. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following definitions apply 1 []: 
    City means the City of Miami. 
    Covered account means (i) An account that a financial institution or creditor offers or maintains, primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, that involves or is designed to permit multiple payments or transactions, such as a credit card account, mortgage loan, automobile loan, margin account, cell phone account, utility account, checking account, or savings account; and (ii) Any other account that the financial institution or creditor offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the financial institution or creditor from identity theft, including financial, operational, compliance, reputation, or litigation risks. 
    Credit means the right granted by a creditor to a debtor to defer payment of debt or to incur debts and defer its payment or to purchase property or services and defer payment therefore. 
    Creditor means any person who regularly extends, renews, or continues credit; any person who regularly arranges for the extension, renewal, or continuation of credit; or any assignee of an original creditor who participates in the decision to extend, renew, or continue credit and includes utility companies and telecommunications companies. 
    Customer means a person that has a covered account with a creditor. 
    Identity theft means a fraud committed or attempted using identifying information of another person without authority. 
    Person means a natural person, a corporation, government or governmental subdivision or agency, trust, estate, partnership, cooperative, or association. 
    Personal identifying information means a person's credit card account information, debit card information bank account information and drivers' license information and for a natural person includes their social security number, mother's birth name, and date of birth. 
    Red flag means a pattern, practice, or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft. 
    Service provider means a person that provides a service directly to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
Other than "city" and "personal identifying information", definitions provided in this section are based on the definitions provided in 16 CFR § 681.2. 

Sec. 2-304. - Findings. 
(a)  The city is a creditor pursuant to 16 CFR § 681.2 due to its provision or maintenance of covered accounts for which payment is made in arrears. 
(b)  Covered accounts offered to customers for the provision of city services include electric, electrical, water, sewer, solid waste, municipal court, purchasing, parks, engineering, civic center building rental, library, fire and police. 
(c)  The city's previous experience with identity theft related to covered accounts is as follows: 
Use of personal identifying information of another. 
(d)  The processes of opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account, making payments on such accounts, and transfer of service by name or address have been identified as potential processes in which identity theft could occur. 
(e)  The city limits access to personal identifying information to those employees responsible for or otherwise involved in opening or restoring covered accounts or accepting payment for use of covered accounts. Information provided to such employees is entered directly into the city's computer system and is not otherwise recorded for public access. 
(f)  The city determines that there is a low risk of identity theft occurring in the following ways: 
(1)  Use by an applicant of another person's personal identifying information to establish a new covered account; or 
(2)  Use of a previous customer's personal identifying information by another person in an effort to have service restored in the previous customer's name; or 
(3)  Use of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment by a customer to pay such customer's covered account or accounts; or 
(4)  Use by a customer desiring to restore such customer's covered account of another person's credit card, bank account, or other method of payment. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-305. - Process of establishing a covered account. 
(a)  As a precondition to opening a covered account in the city, each applicant shall provide the city with two (2) forms of personal identifying information of the customer to include valid government issued identification card, drivers' license, or passport and must contain a photograph of the customer. For customers who are not natural persons, a photograph of the customer's agent opening the account. Such information shall be entered directly into the city's computer system and written application stored in locked file cabinets located in a secure area. 
(b)  Each account shall be assigned an account number and personal identification number (PIN) which shall be unique to that account. The city may utilize computer software to randomly generate assigned PINs and to encrypt account numbers and PINs. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-306. - Access to covered account information. 
(a)  Access to customer accounts shall be password protected and shall be limited to authorized city personnel. 
(b)  Such password(s) shall be changed by the director of information technology, on a regular basis, shall be at least eight (8) characters in length and shall contain letters, numbers and symbols. 
(c)  Any unauthorized access to or other breach of customer accounts is to be reported immediately to the city manager, and the password changed immediately. 
(d)  Personal identifying information included in customer accounts is considered confidential and any request or demand for such information shall be immediately forwarded to the city manager, and the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-307. - Credit card payments. 
(a)  In the event that credit card payments that are made over the Internet are processed through a third-party service provider, such third-party service provider shall certify that it has an adequate identity theft prevention program in place that is applicable to such payments. 
(b)  All credit card payments made over the telephone or the city's website shall be entered directly into the customer's account information in the computer data base. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-308. - Sources and types of red flags. 
    All employees responsible for or involved in the process of opening a covered account, restoring a covered account or accepting payment for a covered account shall check for red flags as indicators of possible identity theft and such red flags may include: 
(1)  Suspicious documents. Examples of suspicious documents include: 
a.  Documents provided for identification that appear to be altered or forged; 
b.  Identification on which the photograph or physical description is inconsistent with the appearance of the applicant or customer; 
c.  Identification on which the information is inconsistent with information provided by the applicant or customer; 
d.  Identification on which the information is inconsistent with readily accessible information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor, such as a signature card or a recent check; or 
e.  An application that appears to have been altered or forged, or appears to have been destroyed and reassembled. 
(2)  Suspicious personal identification, such as suspicious address change. Examples of suspicious identifying information include: 
a.  Personal identifying information that is inconsistent with external information sources used by the financial institution or creditor. For example: 
i.  The address does not match any address in the consumer report; or 
ii.  The social security number (SSN) has not been issued, or is listed on the Social Security Administration's Death Master File. 
b.  Personal identifying information provided by the customer is not consistent with other personal identifying information provided by the customer, such as a lack of correlation between the SSN range and date of birth. 
c.  Personal identifying information or a phone number or address, is associated with known fraudulent applications or activities as indicated by internal or third-party sources used by the financial institution or creditor. 
d.  Other information provided, such as fictitious mailing address, mail drop addresses, jail addresses, invalid phone numbers, pager numbers or answering services, is associated with fraudulent activity. 
e.  The SSN provided is the same as that submitted by other applicants or customers. 
f.  The address or telephone number provided is the same as or similar to the account number or telephone number submitted by an unusually large number of applicants or customers. 
g.  The applicant or customer fails to provide all required personal identifying information on an application or in response to notification that the application is incomplete. 
h.  Personal identifying information is not consistent with personal identifying information that is on file with the financial institution or creditor. 
i.  The applicant or customer cannot provide authenticating information beyond that which generally would be available from a wallet or consumer report. 
(3)  Unusual use of or suspicious activity relating to a covered account. Examples of suspicious activity include: 
a.  Shortly following the notice of a change of address for an account, city receives a request for the addition of authorized users on the account. 
b.  A new revolving credit account is used in a manner commonly associated with known patterns of fraud patterns. For example: 
i.  The customer fails to make the first payment or makes an initial payment but no subsequent payments. 
c.  An account is used in a manner that is not consistent with established patterns of activity on the account. There is, for example: 
i.  Nonpayment when there is no history of late or missed payments; 
ii.  A material change in purchasing or spending patterns; 
d.  Mail sent to the customer is returned repeatedly as undeliverable although transactions continue to be conducted in connection with the customer's account. 
e.  The city is notified that the customer is not receiving paper account statements. 
f.  The city is notified of unauthorized charges or transactions in connection with a customer's account. 
g.  The city is notified by a customer, law enforcement or another person that it has opened a fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft. 
(4)  Notice from customers, law enforcement, victims or other reliable sources regarding possible identity theft or phishing relating to covered accounts. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-309. - Prevention and mitigation of identity theft. 
(a)  In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect to existing covered accounts, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the assistant city manager. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the assistant city manager, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the assistant city manager, in his or her discretion, determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one (1) or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the assistant city manager 
(1)  Contact the customer; 
(2)  Make the following changes to the account if, after contacting the customer, it is apparent that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's covered account: 
a.  Change any account numbers, passwords, security codes, or other security devices that permit access to an account; or 
b.  Close the account; 
(3)  Cease attempts to collect additional charges from the customer and decline to sell the customer's account to a debt collector in the event that the customer's account has been accessed without authorization and such access has caused additional charges to accrue; 
(4)  Notify a debt collector within twenty-four (24) hours of the discovery of likely or probable identity theft relating to a customer account that has been sold to such debt collector in the event that a customer's account has been sold to a debt collector prior to the discovery of the likelihood or probability of identity theft relating to such account; 
(5)  Notify law enforcement, in the event that someone other than the customer has accessed the customer's account causing additional charges to accrue or accessing personal identifying information; or 
(6)  Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. 
(b)  In the event that any city employee responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account becomes aware of red flags indicating possible identity theft with respect an application for a new account, such employee shall use his or her discretion to determine whether such red flag or combination of red flags suggests a threat of identity theft. If, in his or her discretion, such employee determines that identity theft or attempted identity theft is likely or probable, such employee shall immediately report such red flags to the assistant city manager. If, in his or her discretion, such employee deems that identity theft is unlikely or that reliable information is available to reconcile red flags, the employee shall convey this information to the assistant city manager, who may in his or her discretion determine that no further action is necessary. If the assistant city manager in his or her discretion determines that further action is necessary, a city employee shall perform one (1) or more of the following responses, as determined to be appropriate by the assistant city manager: 
(1)  Request additional identifying information from the applicant; 
(2)  Deny the application for the new account; 
(3)  Notify law enforcement of possible identity theft; or 
(4)  Take other appropriate action to prevent or mitigate identity theft. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-310. - Updating the program. 
    The city council shall annually review and, as deemed necessary by the council, update the identity theft prevention program along with any relevant red flags in order to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the city and its covered accounts from identity theft. In so doing, the city council shall consider the following factors and exercise its discretion in amending the program: 
(1)  The city's experiences with identity theft; 
(2)  Updates in methods of identity theft; 
(3)  Updates in customary methods used to detect, prevent, and mitigate identity theft; 
(4)  Updates in the types of accounts that the city offers or maintains; and 
(5)  Updates in service provider arrangements. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-311. - Program administration. 
    The assistant city manager is responsible for oversight of the program and for program implementation. The city manager is responsible for reviewing reports prepared by staff regarding compliance with red flag requirements and with recommending material changes to the program, as necessary in the opinion of the city manager, to address changing identity theft risks and to identify new or discontinued types of covered accounts. Any recommended material changes to the program shall be submitted to the city council for consideration by the council. 
(1)  The assistant city manager will report to the city manager at least annually, on compliance with the red flag requirements. The report will address material matters related to the program and evaluate issues such as: 
a.  The effectiveness of the policies and procedures of city in addressing the risk of identity theft in connection with the opening of covered accounts and with respect to existing covered accounts; 
b.  Service provider arrangements; 
c.  Significant incidents involving identity theft and management's response; and 
d.  Recommendations for material changes to the program. 
(2)  The assistant city manager is responsible for providing training to all employees responsible for or involved in opening a new covered account, restoring an existing covered account or accepting payment for a covered account with respect to the implementation and requirements of the identity theft prevention program. The assistant city manager shall exercise his or her discretion in determining the amount and substance of training necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Sec. 2-312. - Outside service providers. 
    In the event that the city engages a service provider to perform an activity in connection with one (1) or more covered accounts the assistant city manager shall exercise his or her discretion in reviewing such arrangements in order to ensure, to the best of his or her ability, that the service provider's activities are conducted in accordance with policies and procedures, agreed upon by contract, that are designed to detect any red flags that may arise in the performance of the service provider's activities and take appropriate steps to prevent or mitigate identity theft. 
(Ord. No. 1543, § 1, 4-20-09) 
Secs. 2-313-2-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - COMPETITIVE BIDS AND PURCHASING CONTROLS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Charter reference- Competitive bids required, Art. IX, § 6. 

Sec. 2-331. - Competitive bidding. 
(a)  The city shall adhere to the requirements of the City Charter and to the requirements of the laws of the State of Oklahoma as made applicable to this municipality when determining when competitive bidding is required and the manner in which competitive bids will be obtained. 
(b)  In addition the city shall adhere to the requirements of the city purchasing manual. The city manager shall have the authority to create, amend and approve the city purchasing manual provided that the same shall bear the endorsement of the city attorney regarding conformity with state law and the provisions of the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1545, § 1(a), 8-3-09; Ord. No. 1617, § 1, 11-8-13) 
Sec. 2-332. - Purchases of goods, services and capital. 
(a)  The city purchasing of goods, services and capital will be outlined by the city purchasing manual. The city purchasing manual will be the local authority to set the parameters of all purchasing procedures. 
(b)  The city manager shall designate certain individuals as purchasing officers empowered to purchase or contract against budget appropriations. Only these designated individuals will be empowered to obligate the city. 
(c)  For all purchases of goods, services or capital (all purchases or disbursements other than payroll and debt service) for which the obligation and final invoice for the payment of the obligation does not occur within the same month, purchase orders or contracts shall be prepared and approved, in writing, by a designated purchasing officer prior to the time the purchase commitment is made. The approved purchase order or contract shall be forwarded to an officer or employee charged with keeping the appropriation and expenditure records (encumbering clerk) who shall determine that there exists, available unencumbered appropriation for that purpose. Upon such determination, the encumbering clerk shall attest to that fact in writing. If appropriation is not available for the proposed purchase or commitment, the purchase or commitment shall not proceed until budget amendments are authorized to provide sufficient appropriation. 
Upon approval of the purchasing officer and encumbering clerk, an encumbrance shall be recorded in the appropriation and expenditure records in the amount or estimated amount of the commitment. 
These encumbering requirements shall not apply to the following type of purchases or commitments: 
-  Payroll and payroll related expenses 
-  Utility and telephone services by entities governed by State Corporation Commission 
-  Insurance contracts 
-  Purchases where the obligation and final invoice are processed in the same month 
(d)  For all purchases or contracts for goods, services or capital over the amount set forth in the city purchasing manual, city council approval shall be obtained prior to the time the commitment is made, and such approval shall be recorded in the minutes of the council. 
(e)  After satisfactory delivery of the merchandise or completion of contract provisions, an invoice or claim form shall be obtained adequately documenting request for payment. The officer or employee receiving satisfactory delivery of merchandise or contract service shall acknowledge such fact by signing the invoice, claim form, delivery ticket or receiving advice. 
The invoice or claims form, along with the written acknowledgment of receipt, shall be forwarded to the officer or employee responsible for processing accounts payable who shall review the invoice for accuracy and propriety, including comparison to the authorized purchase order or contract, if applicable. 
Upon completion of the accounts payable officer review, the invoices or claim forms along with the related supporting documentation shall be submitted to the city council for payment authorization. 
(Ord. No. 1545, § 1(b), 8-3-09) 
Sec. 2-333. - Bids process. 
(a)  Purchase of supplies, materials and equipment. 
(1)  Materials or supplies: Every contract for purchase of materials or supplies exceeding the amount(s) set forth in the then current Oklahoma Central Purchasing Act shall be let and awarded to the lowest responsible bidder, by free and open competitive bidding after solicitation for sealed bids. The bidding process shall be controlled by the provisions of the Oklahoma Public Competitive Bidding Act of 1974 as it now exists or is hereinafter amended. Exception to this requirement shall be as set forth from time to time in the Oklahoma Central Purchasing Act. 
The responsible staff will contact State of Oklahoma Central Purchasing Office to determine the state purchase price, if any, of the bid items. If the state purchase price is the lowest, the city may avail itself of the provisions of the Oklahoma Central Purchasing Office as its agent for the purchase or procurement of any item provided under the Oklahoma Central Purchasing Act in lieu of local competitive bidding. 
(2)  Equipment: Every contract for the purchase of equipment exceeding the amount(s) set forth in the then current Oklahoma Central Purchasing Act shall be purchased according to any of the following options: 
a.  Directly from the awarded solicitation list(s) for statewide contracts provided by and through the Oklahoma Central Purchasing Office without local competitive bidding if so approved by the city council; 
Or 
b.  On the basis of any U.S. Government Services Administration (GSA) Schedule Contracts without local competitive bidding if so approved by the city council; 
Or 
c.  From the lowest and best bidder after due notice inviting proposals as described in this Section. The price provided by the awarded solicitation list(s) for statewide contracts provided by and through the Oklahoma Central Purchasing Office, and the price provided by any GSA Schedule Contract, each may be considered a qualified bid for purposes of this subparagraph. 
(b)  Bid opening procedure. All bids shall be sealed and submitted to the purchasing agent and shall be identified as bids on the particular contract on the envelope. Bids shall be opened only at the time and place mentioned in the bid section. All bids shall be read aloud in the presence of the purchasing agent and made a matter of record. Such bid opening shall be open to the public and to all bidders. 
(c)  Rejection of bids. The city council shall have the authority to reject all bids, or parts of all bids, when the public interest will be served thereby. 
(d)  Factors considered in letting bids. Contracts for which bids are required shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. In determining the lowest responsible bidder, in addition to price, the city council shall consider: 
(1)  The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service required; 
(2)  Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference; 
(3)  The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder; 
(4)  The quality of performance of previous contracts or services; 
(5)  The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or service; 
(6)  The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the service; 
(7)  The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or contractual services to the particular use required; 
(8)  The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the contract; 
(9)  The availability of the bidder to provide maintenance, performance of warranties, guaranties, the proximity to the city of the bidder with reference to providing maintenance, warranty or services; 
(10)  Whether the bidder can perform the maintenance, warranty or service to the equipment, locally or otherwise; and 
(11)  Whether the bidder owns or operates a business within the corporate city limits of the City of Miami, Oklahoma. 
(e)  Tie bids. If all bids are received for the same amount or unit price, quality and service being equal, contracts shall be awarded to the local bidder. In all other cases where tie bids are received and a local vendor is not involved, the city council shall award the contract to one of the tie bidders by drawing lots in public. 
(f)  Performance bonds authorized. The city council shall have the authority to require performance bonds before entering into any contract for such amount as they shall find necessary to protect the best interest of the city. 
(g)  Subdividing to avoid bids. No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of this article. 
(h)  When bidding not required. Competitive bidding shall not be required in the following cases: 
(1)  Supplies, materials or equipment limited amounts which are set in the city purchasing manual. 
(2)  Supplies, materials or equipment purchased from another unit of government at a price determined below that obtainable for private dealers, including war surplus. 
(3)  Contractual services purchased from a public utility at a price or rate determined by proper governmental authority. 
(4)  Contractual services of a professional nature, such as engineering, architectural, legal, accounting, medical, laboratory testing or other such professional or skilled services. 
(i)  Emergency purchases. 
(1)  Should the city council find that an immediate emergency exists, which findings shall be entered in the minutes of the city council, by reason of which an immediate outlay of city funds, in an amount in excess of the limit set in section 2-118 hereof, is necessary in order to avoid loss of life, substantial damage to property or damage to the public peace or safety, then such contracts may be made and entered into without public notice or competitive bids. 
(2)  Should the city suffer a shortage of petroleum products due to no availability under the regularly bid contract, and the ability of the city to maintain services is threatened, the city manager or his designee is authorized and directed to contact suppliers of petroleum products directly and negotiate for a supply of fuel sufficient to maintain municipal services until the provisions of subsection (1) can be complied with. 
(3)  Should, in the case of a natural disaster, acts of terrorism, civil disturbances, uprisings or other disruption of public services involving public safety or welfare, the city require the immediate purchase of supplies, materials, and services in order to properly care for, provide for and recover from said disaster, the city manager is empowered to direct that any supplies, materials, or contract services whose immediate procurement is essential to prevent delay in the recovery from said disruption be procured on the open market with or without negotiation. If said emergency purchase is necessary, the requirements of subsection (1) above are waived until there is called a meeting of the council. The city manager shall report the reason for, necessity of and the amount of the purchases at the next meeting of the council. The city council shall meet as soon as practicable. 
(Ord. No. 1545, § 1(c), 8-3-09; Ord. No. 1610, § 1, 6-18-13; Ord. No. 1616, § 1, 11-8-13) 
State Law reference- General purchasing authority, 11 O.S. § 22-101. The Oklahoma Central Purchasing Act, 74 O.S. § 85.1 et seq. 
Secs. 2-334-2-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - RECORDS 

Sec. 2-401. - Open records compliance. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to ensure and facilitate full and lawful compliance with the Charter and the Oklahoma Open Records Act, 51 O.S. § 24A.1 et seq., as it presently exists and as it may be amended in the future. 
(b)  51 O.S. § 24A.2 provides that public bodies do not need to follow any procedures for providing access to public records except those specifically required by the Oklahoma Open Records Act except as may be required by other statutes. However, as allowed by 51 O.S. § 24A.5(5), the mayor and city council hereby establish reasonable procedures which protect the integrity and organization of its records and to prevent excessive disruptions of its essential functions. 
(c)  As provided by 51 O.S. § 24A.5(6), the mayor and city council designate the city manager and city clerk as the person(s) responsible to compile public records for inspection, copying or mechanical reproduction. The city manager and city clerk shall make an initial determination as to whether the responsive materials are complete and whether they include records specifically required by law to be kept confidential. If the city manager and city clerk determine that responsive materials do not include content which may be specifically required by law to be kept confidential, then they shall promptly provide reasonable access to those public records. If the city manager or city clerk make a preliminary determination that the responsive materials include content which may be specifically required by law to be kept confidential, then and in such event the mayor and city council designate the city attorney as the person responsible to make a final determination as to whether the responsive materials include records specifically required by law to be kept confidential, and the city attorney shall then provide prompt legal advice to the city manager, city clerk and city council pertaining thereto. The city manager, city clerk and city attorney may delegate authority to subordinate employees or agents to assist in the performance of these duties. 
(d)  The fees provided by 51 O.S. § 24A.3, as presently enacted by Laws 2006, HB 3139, c. 16, § 34, emerg. eff. March 29, 2006, shall apply. In the event that the aforementioned statute is amended, then the city shall comply with the new statutory law. As required by law, the written schedule of the fees shall be posted conspicuously in the ground floor lobby of the Civic Center and with the Ottawa County Clerk. As of the effective date of this article, the city shall charge the fees as described below. 
(1)  $0.25 per page for records having the dimensions of eight and one-half (81/2) by fourteen (14) inches or smaller, or a maximum of $1.00 per copied page for a certified copy. 
(2)  The direct cost of copying items having the dimensions greater than eight and one-half (81/2) by fourteen (14) inches. 
(3)  The direct cost of copying copies of electronic data. 
(4)  If the request is solely for commercial purpose, then a reasonable fee shall be charged to recover the direct cost of record search and copying. 
The city manager and city clerk shall be responsible to determine fees based upon the concept of "direct cost" of copying records other than for pages having the dimensions proscribed in subparagraphs one, above. The city manager and city clerk shall be responsible to determine the reasonable fee(s) to recover the "direct cost" of record search if the request is solely for commercial purpose. A person who has made a written Oklahoma Open Records Act request may appeal the determination of "direct cost" of copying and/or record search directly to the city council by filing a written appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) calendar days of the date on the notification of such costs. 
(e)  Further, in the event that the city manager, city clerk or city attorney shall make a preliminary determination that compliance with an Oklahoma Open Records Act request would clearly cause excessive disruption of the essential functions of the public body, then they shall request that the city council convene a meeting to address the matter. In such case, the city council shall make all appropriate determinations, including the following matters: 
(1)  Will the Oklahoma Open Records Act request clearly cause excessive disruption of the essential functions of the public body? 
(2)  Is the release of the records in the public interest, including, but not limited to, release to the news media, scholars, authors and taxpayers seeking to determine whether those entrusted with the affairs of the government are honestly, faithfully, and competently performing their duties as public servants? 
(3)  What fees, if any, should apply to the Oklahoma Open Records Act request? 
(4)  Are the fees being used for the purpose of discouraging requests for information or as obstacles to disclosure of requested information? 
(4)  Should the city require an advance deposit against the anticipated fees, and, if so, in what amount and under what terms? 
(f)  The city manager and city clerk may promulgate reasonable policies, regulations and staff instructions to promote compliance with the Oklahoma Open Records Act and this article. 
(Ord. No. 1580, § 1, 5-7-12) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, taxation and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 12; transporting nonintoxicating beverages, § 13-119; transporting intoxicating beverages, § 13-120; public drunkenness, § 13-162; reckless driving, driving while intoxicated, etc., § 23-126 et seq. 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, 37 O.S. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Occupation tax. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and assessed a $50.00 annual occupational tax on every business or occupation relating to alcoholic beverages licensed by the A.B.L.E. Commission of the State of Oklahoma and whose principal place of business is in Miami, Oklahoma. This occupational tax is levied and assessed on a fiscal year basis starting on July 1st and ending on the following June 30th. This occupational tax shall not be subject to pro rata allocation or refund 
(b)  Any Oklahoma A.B.L.E. Commission state licensee originally entering upon any licensed occupation within the City of Miami, Oklahoma, shall pay the occupational tax therefor at the office of the city clerk on or before the date upon which he enters such occupation. Such licensee shall provide a copy of his current state license before payment of an occupational tax will be accepted. Thereafter, the licensee shall pay the tax annually on or before the first day of July. 
(c)  Upon payment of the occupation tax, the city clerk shall issue a receipt to the state licensee, which shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises wherein he carries on his occupation. 
(d)  Any person who engages in any of the occupations taxed by this section without paying the occupation tax imposed therefor in advance of such operation is guilty of an offense. 
(e)  The city clerk shall make an annual report to the A.B.L.E. Commission covering the fiscal year, showing the number and class of licensees subject to the occupation tax and the amount of money collected from such tax. 
(Code 1964, §§ 3-1-3-3; Ord. No. 1281, § 1, 6-19-89; Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 6-7-10; Ord. No. 1609, § 1, 6-18-13) 
State Law reference- Occupation tax authorized, 37 O.S. § 554.1. 
Sec. 3-2. - Consumption in public places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any individual to consume intoxicating beverages or low-point beer in public places in the city without a special event permit as set forth in this section. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
(1)  Intoxicating beverages and low-point beer are as defined in sections 3-4, 3-31, and 37 O.S. §§ 163.1 and 163.2. 
(2)  Public places shall mean any area in open view to the public which is in the city, excluding private residential property, and the premises of any individual, partnership, trust, association, or corporation, who is otherwise licensed as a private club, or licensed to sell low-point beer for consumption on premises in the city. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to the premises occupied by any person or group who has obtained authority from the city manager or his or her designee authorizing a special event at a specific location (such as Riverview Park) for a designated time. 
(1)  Any person or group may apply for permission for a special event prior to the event by obtaining approval from the city manager or his or her designee. The city manager shall follow the guidelines established by the city council in determining whether or not to allow intoxicating beverages and/or low-point beer at a special event. 
(2)  Permission for distribution and consumption of alcoholic beverages (including low point beer) may contain conditions or restrictions including but not limited to supervision, security or types of beverages to be consumed. 
(3)  A special event permit issued under this section does not authorize the sale of intoxicating beverages or low-point beer. Any special event conducted shall be subject to all laws of the State of Oklahoma, which generally prohibit and criminalize the sale of intoxicating beverages and low-point beer without full compliance with state law. 
(4)  There shall be an administrative fee of $25.00 for each application. A separate application must be submitted for each special event. 
(Ord. No. 1366, § 1, 8-18-97; Ord. No. 1376, § 1, 4-6-98; Ord. No. 1587, § 1, 8-6-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1366, § 1, Aug. 18, 1997, re-instated § 3-2. Prior to the adoption of Ord. No. 1366, Ord. No. 1364, § 1, adopted June 25, 1997, had repealed § 3-2, which had pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1964, §§ 3-39, 3-40. 
Sec. 3-3. - Possession of nonintoxicating beverages, beer by minors prohibited; penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) to be in possession of any nonintoxicating beverages, or beer, while such person is upon any public street, road or highway, or in any public building or place. 
(Code 1964, § 3-26) 
State Law reference- Public possession of nonintoxicating beverages by persons under twenty-one with intent to consume same, 37 O.S. § 246(A). 
Sec. 3-4. - Application for certificate; investigations. 
(a)  Every applicant for a certificate of compliance with the zoning, fire, health and safety codes of the city required by O.S. tit. 37 shall apply at the office of the city engineer by: 
(1)  Filing a written application on the forms prescribed by that office, and 
(2)  Paying a verification and certification fee in the amount of $50.00 at the time of filing. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application for a certificate of compliance the city engineer shall cause an investigation to be made to determine whether the premises proposed for licensed operations complies with provisions of the zoning ordinance and any health, fire, building and other safety codes applicable to it. 
(c)  The city engineer shall act on all such applications within twenty (20) days of receipt thereof. 
(d)  Upon finding that the premises of an applicant for a certificate is in compliance with all applicable zoning ordinances, a certificate of zoning shall be issued to the ABLE commission. 
(e)  Upon finding that the premises of an applicant for a certificate is in compliance with all applicable fire, safety and health codes, a certificate of compliance shall be issued to the ABLE commission. 
(f)  The above certificates of compliance shall be signed by the mayor or by the city engineer. 
(g)  The definitions in the Oklahoma Alcoholic Beverage Control Act [37 O.S. § 502 et seq.] apply to this section. 
(Code 1964, §§ 3-4-3-6) 
State Law reference- Required local certificates, 37 O.S. § 523. 
Sec. 3-5. - False identification. 
    Any person under twenty-one (21) years of age who shall misrepresent his age or present false documentation of age for the purpose of inducing any person to sell or serve him alcoholic beverages or nonintoxicating beverages, or issue him a bottle club membership card, or who enters or attempts to enter a package store or a separate or enclosed bar area as designated by the ABLE Commission, or its successor, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1279, § 1, 6-5-89) 
Secs. 3-6-3-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NONINTOXICATING BEVERAGES 

Sec. 3-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nonintoxicating beverages shall mean and include beverages containing more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) alcohol by volume and not more than three and two-tenths percent (3.2%) alcohol by weight. 
    Operator shall mean and include any individual, partnership, trust, association or corporation who sells or offers for sale nonintoxicating beverages within the city. 
(Code 1964, § 3-21) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Nonintoxicating beverages defined, 37 O.S. § 163.2. 
Sec. 3-32. - License to sell. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every operator of a tavern, beer parlor or any other place of business of any kind or character where nonintoxicating beverages are sold or offered for sale to procure and obtain an annual license from the city clerk acting by and under the direction of the mayor and board of commissioners. It shall be unlawful for any operator to offer for sale or sell any nonintoxicating beverage in the city, without having first obtained such license. 
(b)  Such license shall be issued over the signature of the city clerk on the form prescribed and the fee for such license for each year or part thereof shall be $20.00 for businesses selling nonintoxicating beverages for consumption on or off the premises and $10.00 for businesses selling such beverages in original packages and not for consumption on the premises. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the operator to exhibit such license in a conspicuous location in his tavern, beer parlor or other place of business. 
(d)  When, in the judgment of the mayor and board of commissioners, this article has been violated, the mayor and board of commissioners may direct the city clerk to revoke and cancel the license of the offending operator. After such revocation, the operator shall not be permitted to sell nonintoxicating beverages or offer the same for sale in the city unless and until another license is thereafter issued to him. 
(Code 1964, § 3-22) 
State Law reference- Municipal license fee on nonintoxicating beverage dealers authorized, 37 O.S. § 163.10. 
Sec. 3-33. - Duty of operators and prohibited conduct on sales premises. 
    It shall be the duty of every operator to refrain from and prohibit the following: 
(1)  The sale of nonintoxicating beverages to persons who are drunk, harboring any drunk person in his place of business or permitting any drunk person to remain on the premises. 
(2)  The use of profane, loud or disturbing language. 
(3)  Conduct of any person which in the natural course of events is disorderly, disturbs the public peace or health or which openly outrages public decency. 
(4)  The sale to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age of nonintoxicating beverages to be consumed in his place of business or upon his premises, or allowing any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years of age to be on the premises except as authorized in 37 O.S. § 246(B). 
(5)  Every operator and any and all of his employees shall refrain from being or becoming intoxicated in or around his place of business or upon his premises. 
(6)  To refrain from and prohibit the violation of the laws of the state or the ordinances of the city relating to alcoholic beverages or nonintoxicating beverages. 
(Code 1964, § 3-24) 
Sec. 3-34. - Hours of sale for on-premises consumption regulated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed to sell beverages containing more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) of alcohol by volume and not more than three and two-tenths percent (3.2%) of alcohol by weight to sell such beverages for consumption on the premises except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. until 2:00 a.m. the following day, daily. 
(Code 1964, § 3-25) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 37 O.S. § 213. 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 1527, § 1, adopted Dec. 3, 2007, repealed Ch. 4, Art. I, §§ 4-1-4-11, Art. II, Divs. 1-3, §§ 4-41-4-43, 4-61-4-65, 4-81-4-83, Art.
