ARTICLE II. - AIRPORT AUTHORITY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions, etc., § 2-141 et seq. 

Sec. 5-26. - Created; function. 
    There is created an airport authority board to regulate and operate the Miami Regional Airport. 
(Code 1964, § 2-31; Ord. No. 1638, § 2, 6-2-2015) 
Sec. 5-27. - Membership. 
    The airport authority board shall consist of seven (7) members, four (4) of whom shall be citizens of Miami and three (3) of whom shall reside in Ottawa County; and each of whom shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to the confirmation of the board of commissioners, and also, the commissioner of streets and property of the city, who shall be an ex officio member of the board. One (1) of the appointed members shall serve for a term of one (1) year; four members shall serve for a term of two (2) years each and two (2) of the members shall serve a term of three (3) years each. 
(Code 1964, § 2-32; Ord. No. 1314, § 1, 6-21-93; Ord. No. 1400, § 1, 7-19-99; Ord. No. 1412, § 1, 10-16-00) 
Sec. 5-28. - Authority. 
    The airport authority board shall have the care and management of the municipal airport and may make all necessary rules and regulations for the proper care and management of the airport. 
(Code 1964, § 2-33) 
Secs. 5-29-5-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AIRPORT ZONING ORDINANCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; flood damage prevention, ch. 10; planning and development, ch. 18; subdivisions, ch. 22; zoning, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Airport Zoning Act, 3 O.S. § 100 et seq.; authority to adopt airport zoning regulations, 3 O.S. § 103. 

Sec. 5-51. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Airport Zoning Ordinance of the Miami Municipal Airport." 
(Code 1964, § 2A-11) 
Sec. 5-52. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    Airport shall mean the Miami Regional Airport. 
    Airport hazard shall mean any structure or tree or use of land which obstructs the airspace required for the flight of aircraft in landing or taking off at the airport, or is otherwise hazardous to such landing or taking off of aircraft. 
    Landing strip shall mean the area of the airport used for the landing or taking off of aircraft. 
    Nonconforming use shall mean any structure, tree or use of land which does not conform to a regulation prescribed in this article or an amendment thereto, as of the effective date of such regulations. 
    Person shall mean any individual, firm, copartnership, corporation, company, association, joint stock association or body politic, and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee or other similar representative thereof. 
    Structure shall mean any object constructed or installed by man, including, without limitation, buildings, towers, smokestacks and overhead transmission lines. 
    Tree shall mean any object of natural growth. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-12; Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 4-7-97; Ord. No. 1638, § 1, 6-2-2015) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 3 O.S. § 101. 
Sec. 5-53. - Establishing airport hazard area. 
    For purposes of this article, rules and regulations, certain areas of land and water within a radius of three (3) miles of a certain point hereinafter described and established are hereby declared to be the Miami Municipal Airport hazard area, and the whole of such area is made subject hereto. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-13) 
Sec. 5-54. - Location and elevation of airport reference point. 
    A point on the runway centerline and three hundred twenty-five (325) feet west and seven hundred thirty-six (736) feet north of Section 13, Township 28 North, Range 23 East, Ottawa County, Oklahoma, is hereby established as the airport reference point of the airport hazard area. The latitude is 36 degrees 54 minutes 33.34 seconds north (36-54-33.34N) and the longitude is 094 degrees 53 minutes 15.01 seconds West (094-53-15.01W). For purposes hereof, the elevation of such radius point is declared to be 806.06 M.S.L. This is based on NAD 83. (This information is contained in the recently completed airport master plan dated December 1993.) 
(Code 1964, § 2A-14; Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 4-7-97) 
Sec. 5-55. - Division of airport hazard area into zones. 
    The airport hazard area is hereby divided into separate zones as follows: 
(1)  Airport property zone, 
(2)  Approach zone, 
(3)  Transitional zone. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-15) 
Sec. 5-56. - Airport property zone. 
    The airport property zone is hereby fixed and declared to be the Miami Municipal Airport real property situated in the county specifically described as follows: 
Beginning at a point, point being the southwest corner of the southeast quarter, Section 13, Township 28 North, Range 22 East, Ottawa County, Oklahoma, thence east 213.7 feet, thence north 7,357.19 feet, to the intersection of said line and the Indian Reservation line, thence in a northwesterly direction along said reservation line for a distance of 1,418 feet, thence south for a distance 1,380 feet thence west along the south PL of 32nd Avenue, northwest for a distance of 165.3 feet thence south along a line parallel to the north, south quarter section line for a distance of 5,933.15 feet to the intersection of the said line and the east-west section line, thence east for a distance of 540 feet thence south for a distance of 1,320 feet, thence east for a distance of 760 feet, thence north for a distance of 1,320 feet to east-west section line, thence 20+ feet east to point of beginning. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-16) 
Sec. 5-57. - Designation of landing areas. 
    For the purposes of fixing and determining the locations and restrictions on the several zones, certain landing areas are hereby designated and declared upon the airport property zone. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-17; Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 4-7-97) 
Sec. 5-58. - Location of primary surface. 
    The landing area is hereby fixed and declared to be one (1) in number, being a rectangular strip of land, more specifically described as follows: 
    The primary surface of the airport consists of a rectangular area five hundred (500) feet wide and five thousand four hundred twelve (5,412) feet long, the centerline of which is located two hundred fifty (250) feet from each side of the centerline of the runway, all specifically described as follows: 
    Beginning at the corner of the southeast-southeast Section 13, Township 28 North, Range 22 East, Ottawa County, Oklahoma; thence south 89 degrees 42 minutes west for a distance of 1,664.41 feet; thence south 00 degrees 16.80 minutes west for a distance of 823 feet to a point which is the south end of the primary surface centerline and the south end of an existing 100-foot wide paved runway; thence south 00 degrees 16.80 minutes west for a distance of 4,067.15 feet to a point which is the north end of the primary surface centerline, said point being more particularly described as a point south 8.25 degrees 24 minutes west a distance of 1,433.02 feet and south 00 degrees 08.52 minutes east a distance of 408 feet from the northeast corner of the northwest-northeast. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-18; Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 4-7-97) 
Sec. 5-59. - Height limitations. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein no structure shall be erected or altered and no tree shall be allowed to grow in a hazard area to a height in excess of the following: 
(1)  A maximum limitation of one hundred fifty (150) feet greater than the radius point. 
(2)  Further height limitations are imposed within areas designated: 
a.  Approach zones. An inclined plane, symmetrical with the runway centerline extended, beginning at each end of the primary surface at the centerline elevation of the runway end and extending for ten thousand (10,000) feet. The slope of the approach clearance surface is thirty-four (34) to one (1) along the runway centerline extended until it reaches an elevation of one hundred fifty (150) feet above the established airport elevation. It then continues horizontally at this elevation to a point ten thousand (10,000) feet from the point of beginning. The width of this surface at the runway end is the same as the primary surface, it flares uniformly, and the width at ten thousand (10,000) feet is three thousand five hundred (3,500) feet. 
b.  Transitional surface. These surfaces connect the primary surfaces, the first two hundred (200) feet of the clear zone surfaces to the inner horizontal surface, conical surface, outer horizontal or other transitional surfaces. The slope of the transitional surface is seven (7) to one (1) outward and upward at right angles to the runway centerline. 
c.  Conical surface. A surface extending from the periphery of the horizontal surface outward and upward at a slope of twenty (20) to one (1) for a horizontal distance of four thousand (4,000) feet to a height of four hundred (400) feet above the established airfield elevation. 
d.  Horizontal surface. A circular plane, one hundred fifty (150) feet above the established airport elevation, with a radius from the ends of the primary surface on the centerline extended ten thousand (10,000) feet. 
(3)  Such portions of transitional zones adjoining the primary surface and within the property zone are further restricted to prohibit any fixed structure above the ground surface within five hundred (500) feet of the landing strip centerline. 
(4)  In cases where there is overlapping of zones with any other zone, the lowest height limitation fixed for either of such zones shall be applied. 
(5)  Provided, however, that the height or other limitations and restrictions herein imposed shall not apply to such structures and uses as may be needful, appropriate or customarily employed for aeronautical purposes. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-19; Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 4-7-97) 
Sec. 5-60. - Drawing attached; purposes thereof. 
    Attached hereto and made a part hereof is the drawing, Airport Zoning Map, approved by the FAA. Its purpose and use is to provide aid in verifying the meaning and explaining the article, rules and regulations as to the general plan and principals involved in its administration. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-20; Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 4-7-97) 
Editor's note- The airport zoning map referred to in section 5-60 is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the city clerk's office. It is also located with the airport zoning board for its use in determining noncompliance with its provisions. 
Sec. 5-61. - Use restrictions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no use may be made of land within the hazard area in such manner as to create electrical interference with radio communication between the airport and aircraft, make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights and other lights, result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport, or otherwise endanger the landing, taking off or maneuvering of aircraft. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-21) 
Sec. 5-62. - Nonconforming uses. 
    The regulations prescribed in sections 5-59 to 5-61 shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering or other change or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to the regulations as of the effective date hereof, or otherwise interfere with the continuance of any nonconforming use. Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the construction, alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to the effective date of this article, and is diligently prosecuted and completed within two (2) years thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-22) 
State Law reference- Nonconforming uses, 3 O.S. § 106. 
Sec. 5-63. - Variances. 
    Any person desiring to erect any structure or increase the height of any structure, or permit the growth of any tree, or use his property, not in accordance with the regulations prescribed in this article, may apply for a variance therefrom. Such variance shall be allowed where a literal application or enforcement of the regulations would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest but do substantial justice and be in accordance with the spirit of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-23) 
State Law reference- Variances, 3 O.S. § 107(2). 
Sec. 5-64. - Permits. 
(a)  Future uses. No material change shall be made in the use of the land and no structure or tree shall be erected, altered, planted, established by natural growth or otherwise, which exceeds the height limitations within the hazard areas unless a permit therefor shall have been applied for and granted. Each such application for a permit shall include the exact location, height above the ground and any other pertinent data needed to determine whether or not a permit shall be granted. 
(b)  Existing uses. Before any existing use, structure or tree may be replaced, substantially altered or repaired, rebuilt, allowed to grow higher, or replanted, which exceeds the height limitations within the hazard area, a permit must be secured authorizing such replacement, change or repair. No such permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of an airport hazard or permit a nonconforming use, structure or tree to be made or become higher, or become a greater hazard to air navigation than it was on the effective date of this article unless a variance has been granted as provided in section 5-63. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-24) 
State Law reference- Permits, 3 O.S. § 107(1). 
Sec. 5-65. - Hazard marking and lighting. 
    Any permit or variance granted may, if such action is deemed advisable to effectuate the purposes of this article and reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree to permit the airport owner at its own expense to install, operate, and maintain thereon such markers and lights as may be necessary to indicate to flyers the presence of an airport hazard. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-25) 
State Law reference- Hazard marking and lighting, 3 O.S. § 107(3). 
Sec. 5-66. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved, or taxpayer affected, by any decision of the administrative officer made in the administration of this article, if of the opinion that a decision of such officer is an improper application of this article, may appeal to the board of adjustment for which provision is made in section 5-68. 
(b)  All appeals taken under this section must be taken within ten (10) days, by filing with the administrative officer and with the board of adjustment, a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The administrative officer shall forthwith transmit to the board of adjustment all the papers constituting the record upon which action appealed from was taken. 
(c)  An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the administrative officer certifies to the board of adjustment, after the notice of appeal has been filed with him, that by reason of the facts stated in the certificate a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings shall be stayed otherwise than by order of the board of adjustment on notice to the administrative officer and on due cause shown. 
(d)  The board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing any interested party may appear in person or by agent or attorney. 
(e)  The board of adjustment may, in conformity with the provisions of this article, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirement, decision or determination as ought to be made, and to that end shall have all the powers of the administrative officer. 
(f)  The board of adjustment shall make written findings of fact and conclusions of law giving the facts upon which it acted and its legal conclusions from such facts in reversing, or affirming, or modifying any order, requirement, decision or determination which comes before it under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-26) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 3 O.S. § 108. 
Sec. 5-67. - Administrative agency. 
    The joint airport zoning board is hereby designated the administrative agency charged with the duty of administrating and enforcing the regulations herein prescribed. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-27; Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 4-7-97) 
State Law reference- Administrative agency required, 3 O.S. § 109. 
Sec. 5-68. - Board of adjustment. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board of adjustment to have and exercise the following powers: 
(1)  To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the administrative officer in the enforcement of this article. 
(2)  To hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this article upon which such board may be required to pass by subsequent ordinances. 
(3)  To hear and decide specific variances under section 5-63. 
(b)  The board of adjustment shall consist of five (5) members, each to be appointed for a term of three (3) years and until their successors are appointed and qualified. Members shall be removable for cause by the joint airport zoning board upon written charges and after public hearing. In event of vacancy for any cause the joint airport zoning board shall fill such vacancy for the unexpired term. 
(c)  The board shall adopt rules for its governance and procedure in harmony with the provisions of this article. Meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the board may determine. The chairman, or in his absence the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. All hearings of the board shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act [25 O.S. § 301 et seq.]. The board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon question, or if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall immediately be filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-28) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions, etc., § 2-141 et seq. 
State Law reference- Board of adjustment, 3 O.S. § 110. 
Sec. 5-69. - Judicial review. 
    Any person aggrieved, or taxpayer affected, by any decision of the board of adjustment may appeal to the county court as provided in 11 O.S. § 111. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-29; Ord. No. 1360, § 1, 4-7-97) 
Sec. 5-70. - Enforcement and remedies. 
    Each violation of any of these regulations, orders or rulings promulgated or made pursuant thereto, shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment for not more than one (1) year in the county jail, or both such fine and imprisonment. In addition, the joint airport zoning board may institute in any court of competent jurisdiction an action to prevent, restrain, correct or abate any such violation, and the court shall adjudge to the plaintiff such relief by way of injunction or otherwise, as may be proper under all the facts and circumstances of the case, in order fully to effectuate the purposes of the regulations, orders and rulings made pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-30) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 3 O.S. § 111. 
Sec. 5-71. - Conflicting regulations. 
    Where this article imposes a greater or more stringent restriction upon the use of land than is imposed or required by any other ordinance or regulation, the provisions of this article shall govern. 
(Code 1964, § 2A-31) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 3 O.S. § 104(2). 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter and in the various Codes adopted by this Chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
1.  "Building official," "Code Official," "Department of Property Maintenance Inspection," or similar names or terminology shall mean the city's building inspector, or such other department, division, team or appointee(s) to whom the City Manager shall delegate such function. 
2.  "Municipality" or "City" shall mean the City of Miami, Oklahoma. The phrase "City of Miami, Oklahoma" shall be inserted whenever the prompt [Name of Jurisdiction], or similar language, may appear in any Code adopted by the City as set out in Section 6-2. 
3.  "State" shall mean the State of Oklahoma, including all of its duly authorized boards, trusts and commissions, as may be pertinent to the subject at hand. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-2. - Codes adopted. 
    Pursuant to 59 O.S. § 1000.23(C) and other applicable state law, the City the adopts the version of: 
1.  the International Residential Code, 
2.  the International Building Code, 
3.  the International Existing Building Code, 
4.  the International Fire Code, 
5.  the International Fuel Gas Code, 
6.  the International Mechanical Code, 
7.  the International Plumbing Code, and 
8.  the National Electric Code, 
all as then currently adopted by the Oklahoma Uniform Building Code Commission, together with all such modifications, amendments and other changes as the same shall be provided by current or future orders of said Commission. 
    Further, the most recent versions of: 
1.  the International Property Maintenance Code, 
as published by the International Code Council (ICC) which corresponds with the same year version of the International Residential Code adopted above is adopted by City of Miami, Oklahoma, and if subsequently adopted by the Oklahoma Uniform Building Code Commission, all such modifications, amendments and other changes which shall be provided by orders of said Commission shall similarly be adopted. 
    Provided, further, the City reserves unto itself the right to modify such Codes by ordinance additions, insertions, deletions and changes in this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, 11 O.S. § 14-107, 59 O.S. § 1000.23(C), 11 O.S. § 14-107(B). 
Sec. 6-3. - Application of Codes adopted. 
    Except as provided within the Codes adopted in this chapter and as hereinafter excepted, all work, including maintenance, on any structure, equipment and/or facilities within the city limits, including, but not limited to electrical, mechanical, plumbing or roofing shall require the application, permit, fees and inspection as set forth in this Chapter and by the Codes adopted herein and must be performed by a duly licensed individual where applicable. Except as provided within the Codes adopted in this chapter and as hereinafter excepted, all electrical or plumbing work, including maintenance, on any structure, equipment and/or facilities outside of the city limits, but which are connected to the City's electrical distribution, water distribution or sanitary sewer collection systems, shall require the application, permit, fees and inspection applicable to the connected system(s) as set forth in this Chapter and by the Codes adopted herein and must be performed by a duly licensed individual where applicable. The exception to the requirements of this section is that a person who is both the property owner and current resident of the property involved shall comply with the application, permit, fees and inspection requirements of this Chapter and the adopted Codes, but that owner may do the work for himself/herself whether or not licensed to do so. Provided, further, the finished work product must still meet all inspection and Code requirements. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-4. - Conflicts. 
    If any provision of the Codes adopted by reference in this article conflicts with this Code, this Code shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-5. - Building inspector. 
    The City Manager shall appoint a building inspector who shall also serve as the electrical inspector, the refrigeration-air conditioning-heating inspector, the plumbing inspector and the roofing inspector. The City Manager may also appoint deputies to the building inspector as he/she may from time to time deem necessary. The building inspector and his/her deputies shall have a thorough knowledge of the Codes herein adopted and the systems they monitor. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-6. - Same-Qualifications. 
    The building inspector shall have qualifications as required for each trade by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
State Law reference- Qualifications of electrical inspector, 59 O.S. §§ 1016, 1031 et seq., 1693. 
Sec. 6-7. - Same-Interference with. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with the building inspector in the lawful discharge of his/her duties. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-8. - Inspections generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the building inspector to make inspections of all work for which permits have been issued under this Chapter, and it shall be the duty of the person making the installation to promptly notify the inspector when the work is ready for inspection. Failure to promptly notify the inspector shall result in an additional administrative fee of $50.00. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-9. - Correction of or discontinuance of service to defective installations. 
(a)  If, upon any inspection, the building inspector finds any part of any work or apparatus or materials to be in a defective or dangerous condition, he/she shall notify, in writing, the contractor and the owner or occupant of the premises to have the defects corrected within such time as the inspector shall deem necessary. If the contractor, owner or occupant refuses or fails to comply with the requirements of the inspector or to correct all defects as directed within the specified time, it shall be the duty of the inspector to notify the utility furnishing the utility service of such dangerous defects. Upon receipt of such notice, the utility shall immediately disconnect the service as directed by the inspector, until notified in writing by the inspector that the defects have been corrected. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to make corrections of dangerous, defective or hazardous installations, after having been notified by the inspector, within a time designated by the inspector and shall be punished accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-10. - Approval of work to be concealed. 
    No work requiring inspection may be concealed or in any way covered until it has been inspected by the building inspector. Upon inspecting the roughing-in of any work governed by this Chapter that is to be concealed, the building inspector shall leave a notice, in a conspicuous place close to the work that is to be concealed, clearly stating whether the work is completed and approved or is to be kept open for correction or completion. In the event the notice indicates that the work is to be kept open for correction or completion, it shall be unlawful for any person to, in any manner whatsoever, cover or conceal such work until it has been approved. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person not connected with the installation of the same, to in any manner disturb or interfere with any work governed by this Chapter which has not been so approved. If the work is in such a condition as to interfere with the completion of the building or the installation of other apparatus, the contractor or owner must be notified and given time to make the necessary changes. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-11. - Variances. 
    If, in the installation of any electrical, plumbing, mechanical or roofing job, the licensed contractor or owner installing the same shall find that, on account of some mechanical construction of the building, location of fixtures, or for any other reason, it would be impossible to abide by the letter of this Chapter or any Code adopted herein, he/she may apply to the building inspector for a variance, stating his/her reasons for any changes and setting forth the conditions, with a statement of his/her desires to a variance from the provisions of this Chapter or the Code for the particular job. If the inspector finds that the conditions warrant the same and that it would be impractical and unreasonable to require a strict conformance to this Chapter or the Code, he/she shall have the authority to make special rulings, for the safeguarding of life and property and the improvement of the installations. In all such cases, the contractor or owner who applied for the variance shall be notified in writing of the decision. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-12. - Approval of completed work. 
(a)  After all work authorized by a permit under this Chapter has been completed, it shall be inspected as provided in section 6-8, and, if found to be in accord with this Chapter and all other applicable ordinances, statues and rules, the building inspector shall issue an approval certificate or tag. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to connect or use any equipment on the electrical or water to supply electric current over the same, until such approval certificate or tag is issued. It shall likewise be unlawful for any utility to connect, or cause to be connected, any service or building for the supply of electric current until it has been notified by the electrical inspector that the electric work has been inspected and approved and is ready for electric service. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-13. - Permits and fees. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit required by this Chapter shall make written application therefor to the building inspector, on blank forms furnished by him/her. Such application shall be in duplicate, indicating such facts as to the nature of the work to be performed and drawings setting out the plans as the inspector may require. 
(b)  The application and drawings shall be retained in the office of the inspector as per the City's document retention policy. 
(c)  If the proposed work specified in an application does not violate any provisions of this Chapter, any Code adopted herein, or any other ordinance of the City or applicable statute or rule of the state or federal government, the building inspector shall write the word "approved" on the face of the original application, together with his/her signature. 
(d)  No application for a permit required by this Chapter shall be accepted and no such permit shall be issued until the following fees and the reasonably anticipated inspection fees as determined necessary by the building inspector have been paid to the City in addition to any fee(s) which state law requires the City to collect: 
(1)  For a permit for a new residential building or structure the fee based on the estimated improvement is as follows: 
Up to first 1,000 square feet ..... $150.00 
Each additional 100 square feet ..... $5.00 
(2)  For a permit for additions/remodels or the alteration of an existing residential structure, the fee based on the estimated improvement is as follows: 
Up to first 500 square feet ..... $55.00 
Each additional 100 square feet ..... $5.00 
(3)  For a permit for a new commercial or industrial building or structure the fee based on the estimated improvement is as follows: 
Up to first 1,000 square feet ..... $200.00 
Each additional 100 square feet ..... $5.00 
(4)  For a permit for additions/remodels or the alteration of an existing commercial or industrial building or structure the fee based on the estimated improvement is as follows: 
Up to first 1,000 square feet ..... $150.00 
Each additional 100 square feet ..... $5.00 
(5)  For a permit for a new accessory building for storage only, whether residential, commercial or industrial, the fee based on the estimated improvement is as follows: 
Up to first 200 square feet ..... $55.00 
Each additional 100 square feet ..... $5.00 
(6)  For a permit for miscellaneous construction (i.e. roofs, storm shelters, carport, etc.), whether residential, commercial or industrial, the fee is as follows: 
$50.00, plus all applicable State fees. 
(7)  For a permit for the demolition or removal of a building or structure or part thereof, the fee shall be $50.00, plus all applicable State fees, provided that, if the demolition is a necessary part of an alteration for which a permit has been issued, no fee shall be required for such demolition. Provided further, however, that in the case of any permit which shall involve demolition or removal as described above, no permit shall be issue until the City Manager, or designee has reviewed the matter. The building inspector, or designee may make appropriate preconditions, conditions and requirements prior to authorizing issuance of a demolition permit, and in such case no demolition permit shall be issued unless and until the applicant has endorsed his or her agreement to the terms of the permit and has granted the City the right to enter upon the premises and inspect the progress of the demolition in the interests of the public safety, health and welfare. 
(8)  For a permit and inspection for the installation of signs, the fee is as follows: 
All electric signs ..... $55.00 
All non-electric signs ..... $45.00 
(e)  The payment of the fees provided for in this section shall, in no way, relieve the applicant of the obligation to pay any other fee specified by this Chapter, for inspection, certificates or approval of sewer connections, water taps, wiring, or other privileges. 
(f)  The following inspections are required and the following inspection fee(s) apply thereto. 
(1)  Residential: 
Initial inspection ..... $50.00 
Reinspection ..... $95.00 
Final ..... $75.00 
(2)  Commercial and Industrial: 
Initial inspection ..... $50.00 
Reinspection ..... 95.00 
Final ..... 125.00 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-14. - Contractor's registration. 
(a)  Except for work done by the person who is both the property owner and current resident of the property involved (as provided in Sec. 6-3), all persons desiring to engage in advertising or soliciting work for, or actually doing any work for installing, applying, designing, assembling, erecting, constructing, altering, servicing, repairing or maintaining the electrical system, or any part thereof, in or on any building or other structure within the City or which is connected to the City's electrical distribution systems must first secure an electrical contractor, journeyman or apprentice registration from the Community Development office. 
(b)  Except for work done by the person who is both the property owner and current resident of the property involved (as provided in Sec. 6-3), all persons desiring to engage in advertising or soliciting work for, or actually doing any work for installing, applying, designing, assembling, erecting, constructing, altering, servicing, repairing or maintaining refrigeration and/or air conditioning and/or heating and/or ventilating systems, or any part thereof, in or on any building or other structure within the City or which is connected to the City's electrical distribution system must first secure a mechanical contractor, journeyman or apprentice registration from the Community Development office. 
(c)  Except for work done by the person who is both the property owner and current resident of the property involved (as provided in Sec. 6-3), all persons desiring to engage in advertising or soliciting work for, or actually doing any work for installing, applying, designing, assembling, erecting, constructing, altering, servicing, repairing or maintaining plumbing, sewage or natural gas or liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) systems, or any part thereof, in or on any building or other structure within the City or which is connected to the City's water distribution and/or sanitary sewer collection system(s) must first secure a plumber contractor, journeyman or apprentice registration from the Community Development office. Provided, however, this provision shall not apply to a building or other structure outside of the City limits which is using the City's water distribution or sanitary sewer collection system, if the work to be done only concerns the natural gas or liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) systems. 
(d)  Except for work done by the person who is both the property owner and current resident of the property involved (as provided in Sec. 6-3), all persons desiring to engage in advertising or soliciting work for, or actually doing any work for in installing, applying, designing, assembling, erecting, constructing, altering, servicing, repairing or maintaining roofs, or any part thereof, on any building or other structure within the City must first secure a roofing contractor registration from the Community Development office. 
(e)  The fee for all contractor registrations provided for herein is $100.00 for the year or part thereof with such registration which shall expire as of the City's close of business on June thirtieth following. Timely renewals require appropriately completed applications with all necessary attachments received in the office of Community Development on or before June 30. There is no fee for a journeyman or apprentice registration. 
(f)  A City registration shall be issued upon application and compliance with state laws and the presentation of the current, valid state license. The applicant shall be entitled to do such work as is allowed by his/her license and is subject to all the limitations thereof. City registration will be provided to the applicant upon compliance with all of the requirements herein. Any registration provided for herein shall be nontransferable. 
(g)  Any person required to be a state license holder hereunder who is not in good standing with the licensing body or has otherwise had his/her license suspended or revoked is required to immediately disclose same to the office of Community Development. The office shall suspend the registration of such license holder and shall immediately suspend all work being done by said license holder pursuant to any outstanding issued permit(s) until the license issues are resolved and the license holder is again in good standing with the licensing body. 
(h)  If any person who has a disclosure requirement under the preceding subsection who does not immediately disclose the licensing problem to the office of Community Development, or who violates the provisions of Section 6-14, the office of Community Development shall cancel and recall the registration of such license holder and shall immediately suspend all work being done by said license holder pursuant to any outstanding issued permit(s). The license holder shall be subject to the penalties as set out for a violation of Section 6-14, and the person shall be ineligible for registration for a period of not to exceed twelve (12) months, as administratively determined appropriate by the office of Community Development, after all requirements of any sentence, or deferment of sentence, and/or probation have been met, including the payment of all fines, court costs, deferment fees and any restitution or completion of all required rehabilitative treatment. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
State Law reference- Electrical License Act, 59 O.S. §§ 1680 et seq., Registration of Electricians, 59 O.S. § 1696; Mechanical Licensing Act, 59 O.S. §§ 1860.1 et seq.; 59 O.S. § 1850.12, The Plumbing License Law of 1955, 59 O.S. §§ 1001 et seq.; Roofing Contractor Registration Act, 59 O.S. §§ 1151.1 et seq. 
Sec. 6-15. - Display. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person doing work that requires a license under the provisions of this Chapter in the City, or to a building or structure that is connected to the City's electrical and/or water distribution systems and/or its sanitary sewer collection system, to not show his certificate of registration, on demand, to any building inspector or police officer who shall ask to see the same. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-16. - Unlawful work. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person doing work that requires a license and registration under the provisions of this Chapter in the City, or to a building or structure that is connected to the City's electrical and/or water distribution systems and/or its sanitary sewer collection system, , without first obtaining the required license and registration prior to doing the work or prior to advertising and/or soliciting such work. It shall likewise be unlawful for any contractor to employ any person to do such work unless such employee is appropriately licensed under the provisions of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-17. - Liability. 
    This Chapter shall not be construed as imposing upon the City any liability or responsibility for damages to any person injured or who suffers loss of life by any defects in, or during the operation of any electric, plumbing, natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), sanitary sewer and/or mechanical appliance and/or system(s), or by the installation thereof or any part thereof; nor shall the City, or any official or employee thereof, be held as assuming any such liability or responsibility by reason of the inspection authorized hereunder or certificate of inspection issued by the building inspector; nor shall the City or any official or employee thereof be held as assuming any liability or responsibility for property damage, from any cause whatsoever, which may have been caused by any defects in, or during the operation of any electric, plumbing, natural gas, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), sanitary sewer and/or mechanical appliance and/or system(s), or by the installation thereof or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Secs. 6-18-6-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - APPEALS 

Sec. 6-26. - Appeals procedure. 
    Any person directly affected by a decision of the building inspector, or his/her designee(s), or a code official, or a notice or order issued hereunder shall have the right to appeal to the Board of Adjustment, provided that a written application for appeal is filed and received by the City Clerk within ten (10) days after the day the decision, notice or order was entered. An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this Chapter, any applicable ordinance, state statue or the rules legally adopted hereunder have been incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of this Code do not fully apply, or the requirements of this Code are adequately satisfied by other means. Appeals of notice and orders (other than summary abatement of nuisances as provided in Sec. 15-9 of this Code) shall stay the enforcement of the notice and order until the appeal is heard. The Board of Adjustment shall schedule the appeal for hearing not later than the next regularly scheduled meeting for which notice and agenda may be lawfully posted, or at an earlier special meeting to be called at the discretion of the Board of Adjustment Chairman. The appeal hearing shall be open to the public and held pursuant to a posted agenda item, although the Board of Adjustment may otherwise consult with the City Attorney and other authorized attendees in a lawfully scheduled and posted executive session. The manner of conducting the hearing shall not require compliance with strict rules of evidence, but shall mandate that only relevant information be received. The Board of Adjustment shall modify or reverse the decision of the building inspector or code officer only by a concurring vote of a majority of the total number of seated Board of Adjustment members. The building inspector shall take prompt action in accordance with the decision of the Board of Adjustment. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 6-27. - Appeals from the Board of Adjustments. 
    Any person directly affected by a decision of the Board of Adjustment or an order issued hereunder shall have the right to appeal to District Court of Ottawa County, provided, however, such appeal must be in conformity with the provisions of 11 O.S. § 44-110, and as the same may be amended or renumbered from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Secs. 6-28-6-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE 

Secs. 6-51-6-55. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-56. - Demolition permit. 
(a)  In addition to the requirements of the International Building Code (IBC) and other Codes adopted herein, every building or structure or portion or remnants thereof remaining after fire, prior or partial demolition, acts of nature, explosion or other destructive or nondestructive forces which is found to be in noncompliance with the site cleanup requirements specified in this Chapter and the Codes adopted herein, shall be brought into compliance with these requirements, as applicable, within the period of time provided by written notice from the building inspector. 
(b)  A permit for demolishing any structures and buildings shall be conditioned on the following terms and conditions, all of which are additional and supplemental to any other or further requirements of federal, state or local laws, ordinances and regulations, and the site plan which accompanies the application for a demolition permit. The application shall directly address the applicant's method of compliance with each of the requirements of this Chapter and the Codes adopted herein, all as set out in the permit application. 
(c)  In the case of any structure(s) or building(s) which, individually or in the aggregate, exceed(s) twenty thousand (20,000) square feet, the applicant shall, prior to issuance of the demolition permit, provide a surety bond issued by a good and sufficient surety authorized to do business within the State of Oklahoma, all in a form approved by the City Attorney, and which bond names the City of Miami as a named insured party, in an amount and under such terms and conditions sufficient to ensure full completion of the site plan for demolition, as well as abatement of potential impacts to public health and safety and long-term environmental impacts, and to ensure general cleanup of the demolition site. No such bond shall be released until all required work is completed and the final inspection has been approved. 
(d)  Demolition permits shall be valid for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days from date of issuance with extension(s) of up to sixty (60) days each allowed for extenuating circumstances as approved by the City Manager or his or her designee. No extension shall be granted unless the terms of any required bond shall also remain in effect for the time period of the extension. 
(Ord. No. 2018-13, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Chapter 7 - CIVIL DEFENSE AND EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Civil defense and disaster relief, 63 O.S. § 683 et seq. 

Sec. 7-1. - Title. 
    This chapter may be cited as the city civil defense and emergency management ordinance of 1990. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Civil defense forces shall mean the employees, equipment and facilities of all city departments, boards, institutions and commissions; and, in addition, it shall include all volunteer personnel, equipment and facilities contributed by or obtained from any other source. 
    Civil defense volunteer shall mean any person duly registered, identified, and appointed by the director and assigned to participate in civil defense activity. 
    Declared disaster shall mean any event, natural or technological, impending or actual, that cannot be handled by the city's resources. 
    Declared emergency shall mean any situation requiring substantial response by one (1) or more departments, requiring coordination and so declared by an elected official or the director of civil defense. 
    Director shall mean the director of civil defense as appointed by the board of commissioners or his designated assistant. 
    Emergency shall mean any concentrated effort by one (1) or more departments that requires some coordination to respond to a life or property threatening incident. 
    Miami Emergency Council Advisories (M.E.C.A.) shall mean the local committee appointed as provided in this chapter. 
    Regulations shall include plans, programs and other emergency procedures deemed essential to civil defense. 
    Volunteer shall mean contributing a service, equipment, or facilities to the civil defense organization without remuneration. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-3. - Findings and declarations. 
(a)  Because of the existing and increasing possibility of the occurrence of natural or technological disasters and future discovery of presently unknown natural or technological potential for disaster of unprecedented destructiveness including but not limited to enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or from fire, flood, tornado, hazardous material incidents or other causes, and in order to ensure that the city is adequately prepared to deal with such disasters to protect the lives and property of the citizens of the city, to prevent further loss of life and property, to maintain the objectives of the city and to provide for the recovery of such disasters, it is hereby found and declared to be necessary to: 
(1)  Create a civil defense department; provide for an appointment of a director of civil defense and the procedure thereof; 
(2)  Establish a method of funding for such department; 
(3)  Confer upon the mayor and board of commissioners and the director of civil defense emergency powers provided in this chapter; 
(4)  Provide for rendering mutual aid and the procuring of mutual aid as set forth; 
(5)  Provide sufficient organization to mitigate and meet emergencies in the general interest of the city. 
(b)  It is further declared that the purpose of this chapter and the intent of the city is that all civil defense functions be coordinated to the maximum extent with comparable functions of the state, other states and localities and private agencies of every type, to the end that the most effective planning, resources and facilities be made to address potential or actual disasters threatening this city. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-4. - Liability. 
(a)  This chapter is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety and neither the city nor agents and representatives of the city, or any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, or any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with any order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons or property as the result of such activity. 
(b)  Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants the city the right to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack or as shelter during life threatening severe weather, shall not be civilly liable for the death or injury to any persons on or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege or other permission, or for loss of or damage to the property of such person. 
(Ord. No 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-5. - Organization and appointments. 
    The mayor and board of commissioners hereby creates a department of emergency management, commonly referred to as Miami Civil Defense, with the intent that such department shall coordinate the city's mitigation, preparedness, response and recovery to emergencies, declared emergencies, declared disasters, or any other emergency action or impending emergency that confronts the city. Further, Miami Civil Defense shall be an executive department of the city government utilizing to the fullest extent all employees, equipment and facilities of all city departments, boards, institutions and commissions to ensure efficient response to the citizens of the city during aforementioned phases of management and response to emergencies or disasters or the recovery from emergencies or disasters. The organization shall consist of the following: 
(1)  As the office of civil defense within the executive department of the city government and under the supervision of the mayor and board of commissioners there shall be an executive head of the office known as the director of the office of civil defense and such assistants and other employees as are deemed necessary for the proper functioning of the organization. The director shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of commissioners as is common practice for like administrators of other departments within the city. 
(2)  The employees, equipment and facilities of all city departments, boards, institutions and commissions, will participate in the civil defense activity. Duties assigned to a city department shall be the same or similar to the normal duties of the department except as is necessary to preserve life or property or prevent the further loss of life or property. 
(3)  Volunteer persons and agencies offering service to and accepted by the city. 
(4)  The Miami Emergency Council Advisories (M.E.C.A.) shall be composed of the director who acts as chairman and appointed positions who represent the office of the city administrator, the city attorney's office; Baptist Regional Health Center; Northeastern Oklahoma A & M College; department of human services; Ottawa County Health Department; the city public school system and two (2) at-large appointees, all appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of commissioners, who shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-6. - Funding. 
    All fiscal procedures, budgetary processes, purchasing requirements as mandated by city policy, state or federal law shall apply to the office of civil defense with exceptions: 
(1)  The city authorizes the director of civil defense to accept services, equipment, supplies, materials, funds or any other thing of value by way of gift, grant or loan, for purchases of civil defense from any state or federal government or its political subdivisions. 
(2)  The city authorizes the director of civil defense to accept services, equipment, supplies, materials, funds or any other thing of value by way of gift, grant or loan, for purposes of civil defense from any person, firm, or corporation with the consent of the mayor and board of commissioners and subject to the terms of the offer. 
(3)  The city is authorized to exercise the powers vested under 63 O.S. § 683.11(b) as pertains to an emergency, declared emergency or declared disaster as defined by ordinance, in the light of exigencies of the extreme emergency situation without regard to time consuming procedures and formalities prescribed by law (excepting constitutional requirements) pertaining to the performance of public work, entering into contracts, the incurring of obligations, the employment of temporary workers, the rental of equipment, the purchase of supplies and materials, and the appropriation and expenditure of public funds as is provided for under the emergency powers set out in this chapter. 
(4)  The director of civil defense is hereby authorized to enter into mutual aid agreements, matching fund programs, grants or any other funding avenues with regard to all laws and contingent on the approval of the mayor and board of commissioners. 
(5)  The director of civil defense is authorized to participate in fund raising projects sponsored by the civil defense volunteer organization, providing permission is obtained prior to the project from the mayor or the city administrator. The city further acknowledges that such funds are property of the volunteer organization and are not subject to the city's fiscal procedures or other requirements. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-7. - Duties of the civil defense director. 
    The director of the office of civil defense shall be responsible to the mayor and board of commissioners in regard to all phases of the civil defense activity. Under the supervision of the mayor and board of commissioners, he shall be responsible for the planning, coordination and operation of the civil defense activity in the city. Under the supervision of the mayor and board of commissioners, he shall maintain liaison with the state and federal authorities and the authorities of other nearby political subdivisions so as to ensure the most effective operation of the civil defense plan. His duties shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Coordination of the recruitment of volunteer personnel and agencies to augment the personnel and facilities of the city for civil defense purposes; 
(2)  Development and coordination of plans for the immediate use of all of the facilities, equipment, manpower and other resources of the city for the purpose of minimizing or preventing damage to persons and property; protecting and restoring to usefulness governmental services and public utilities necessary for the public health, safety and welfare; 
(3)  Negotiating and concluding agreements with owners or persons in control of buildings or other property for the use of such buildings or other property for civil defense purposes and designating suitable buildings as public shelters; 
(4)  Through public informational programs, educating the civilian population as to actions necessary and required for the protection of their persons and property in case of enemy attack or disaster, either impending or present; 
(5)  Conducting public practice alerts to ensure the efficient operation of the civil defense forces and to familiarize residents with civil defense regulations, procedures and operations; 
(6)  Coordinating the activity of all other public and private agencies engaged in any civil defense activity; 
(7)  Negotiating mutual aid agreements with other municipal corporations or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the mayor and board of commissioners; 
(8)  Assuming such authority and conducting such activity as the mayor and board of commissioners may direct to promote and execute the civil defense plan. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-8. - Powers and duties of Miami Emergency Council Advisories (M.E.C.A.). 
(a)  The Miami Emergency Council Advisories (M.E.C.A.) will assume the responsibility for the preparation of the civil defense and disaster basic plan, subject to the direction of the director. The council is responsible for ensuring that comprehensive planning is undertaken, that all available resources are considered, that there is a public understanding of the plan, that the plan is continually reviewed and amendments suggested to the director. 
(b)  In time of emergency, the council may serve as an operations group, under the direction of the director. Members will serve as liaison personnel with their official groups and as liaison with agencies and groups in the community and in the community at large, as directed by the director. 
(c)  The council shall serve as a policy advisory committee to the director. It shall provide a forum for citizen participation in matters relating to emergency planning, and shall provide continuing liaison with official and nonofficial departments and agencies in the community which have the capability of being useful in meeting needs caused by disaster. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-9. - Contents of civil defense and disaster basic plan. 
(a)  A comprehensive civil defense and disaster basic plan shall be adopted and maintained by resolution of the board of commissioners upon the recommendation of the director. In the preparation of this plan as it pertains to city organization, it is the intent that the services, equipment, facilities and personnel of all existing departments and agencies shall be utilized to the fullest extent. When approved, it shall be the duty of all municipal departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. The basic plan shall be considered supplementary to this chapter and have the effect of law whenever an emergency, declared emergency, or declared disaster has been proclaimed. 
(b)  The director shall prescribe in the basic plan those positions within the disaster organization, in addition to his own, for which lines of succession are necessary. Additionally, all department heads for the city shall create a list of succession, and in each instance the responsible person will keep on file with the director a current list of a minimum of three (3) persons as successors to his position. The list will be in order of succession and will, as nearly as possible, designate persons best capable of carrying out all assigned duties and functions. 
(c)  The mayor of the city shall designate a line of succession from his position through all elected city officials, subject to the approval of the board of commissioners. The list will be kept current and approvals made at the first opportune time, except when situations exist that require immediate action, then the appointment will become effective immediately and until such time as normal procedure can be implemented. 
(d)  Each department head assigned responsibility in the basic plan shall be responsible for carrying out all duties and functions assigned therein. Duties will include the organization and training of assigned city employees and volunteers. Each department head shall formulate the operational plan for his service to ensure that the plan shall conform to and augment the overall plan, and when approved by the director and having been approved by the board of commissioners as provided in this chapter, shall become an annex to and a part of the basic plan. 
(e)  Each department head will maintain a current resource list of any and all materials possessed by his department and a current copy will be furnished to the director. Additionally, all department heads shall furnish to the director a list of agencies, persons, materials or any other item they may find pertinent to the emergency management of the city both present or conceived as beneficial for a possible future response by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-10. - Amendments to civil defense and disaster basic plan. 
    Proposed amendments to the basic plan shall be submitted to the director. The director will submit the proposed amendments to the board of commissioners with his recommendation for its approval. Upon approval by the board of commissioners by resolution, such amendments shall take effect thirty (30) days from the date of approval, unless an emergency is declared separately with the approval of the amendment. If an amendment is pending at the time that a declared emergency or declared disaster is proclaimed under provisions of this chapter, the amendment will be considered approved immediately and will remain effective unless specifically revoked by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-11. - Fallout protection in public buildings, structures. 
(a)  Every officer, board, department or commission of the city charged with the duty of preparing specifications, or awarding or entering into contracts for the design, erection, or construction of buildings or other structures, including additions to existing structures, for the city shall consider or cause to be incorporated in such buildings or other structures, fallout protection for at least its normal anticipated population which shall meet or exceed the minimum space and fallout protection criteria recommended by the Office of Civil Defense, United States Department of Defense. 
(b)  It shall be the policy of the city that fallout shelters be considered in all public buildings of the city to the fullest extent practicable, in order to provide protection against radiation for the greatest number of people in the event of nuclear attack. 
(Code 1964, § 5-6.1) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations generally, ch. 6. 
Sec. 7-12. - Emergency powers. 
(a)  When in the judgment of the director it is necessary to invoke the emergency powers pursuant to this chapter, he shall immediately seek the concurrence of the mayor and board of commissioners by whatever means are necessary or available to him. If the nature of the emergency prevents his consultation with the mayor and board of commissioners, or in the event the mayor and the board of commissioners are not available to act, then the judgment of the director, with consultation of the city administrator, or if the city administrator is not available, the judgment of the director alone shall be the sole criteria necessary to invoke the powers provided in this chapter. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed as abridging or curtailing the powers or restrictions of the mayor and board of commissioners as defined in the Charter of the city, and the mayor and board of commissioners may convene to review the invocation of emergency powers at any time and perform their legislative and administrative powers, and shall receive reports relative to civil defense activities. 
(b)  During any period when an emergency, declared emergency or declared disaster exists or is threatened, within the definition of this chapter, the director may promulgate such regulations as he deems necessary to protect life and property and preserve critical resources. Such regulations shall remain in effect until declared unnecessary by the mayor and board of commissioners or the director if the mayor and board of commissioners are not available and may include but shall not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Regulations prohibiting or restricting the movement of vehicles in order to facilitate the work of civil defense forces, or to facilitate the mass movement of persons from critical areas within or without the city; 
(2)  Regulations pertaining to the movement of persons in or around areas deemed to be hazardous or vulnerable to disaster; 
(3)  Regulations restricting the movement of persons upon the streets, public property or within the city at particular times of day or night and in particular areas; 
(4)  Such other regulations necessary to preserve public peace, health and safety. 
Regulations promulgated in accordance with the authority above will be given widespread circulation by proclamations published and uttered by newspaper, radio or civil defense forces or recognized volunteers. These regulations will have the force of ordinance when duly filed with the city administrator or his office and violations will be subject to the penalties provided in this chapter. 
(c)  The director shall order civil defense forces to the aid of other communities when required in accordance with the statutes of the state, and he may request the state or a political subdivision of the state to send aid to the city in case of an emergency, declared emergency or declared disaster. 
(d)  The director may obtain vital supplies, equipment and other properties found lacking and needed for the protection of health, life and property of the people, and bind the city for the fair value thereof. The director will make a concentrated effort to consult with the city manager, where time permits. Regardless, such action taken through this chapter shall be reported by the city manager to the mayor and city council for review at the first opportune time. 
(e)  The director may require emergency services of any city officer or employee. If regular city forces are determined inadequate, the director may require the services of such other personnel as he can obtain including citizen volunteers within and without the city. All duly authorized persons rendering emergency services shall be entitled to the privileges and immunities as are provided by state law, the City Charter and ordinances for regular city employees and other registered and identified civil defense and disaster workers and upon demand, may receive appropriate compensation for their emergency employment. 
(f)  The director will cause to be prepared the basic plan and its amendments referred to in this chapter and to exercise his ordinary powers as director, all of the special powers conferred upon him by the City Charter and this Code, all powers conferred upon him by any statute or any other lawful authority. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90; Ord. No. 1585, § 1(C.), 7-16-12) 
Sec. 7-13. - Assistance from persons outside city government. 
    When a required competency or skill for a disaster function is not available within the city government, the director is authorized to seek assistance from persons outside of government. Any and all license requirements may be waived if the persons so assigned have a like license in another jurisdiction within and without the city or state. The assignment of duties, when of a supervisory nature, shall also grant authority for the persons so assigned to carry out such duties prior to, during, and after the occurrence of a disaster. Such service from persons outside of government may be accepted by the city on a volunteer basis. Such citizens shall be enrolled as civil defense volunteers in cooperation with the heads of the city departments affected. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-14. - Conflicting ordinances, orders, rules and regulations. 
    At all time when a declared emergency or declared disaster exists pursuant to this chapter the provisions of this chapter together with any rules or regulations promulgated pursuant to this chapter shall supersede all other existing ordinances, orders, rules and regulations of the city insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-15. - Violation of chapter-Declared unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully violate any of the provisions of this chapter or of the regulations or plans issued pursuant to the authority contained in this chapter, or to willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the civil defense organization. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Sec. 7-16. - Same-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to this chapter, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided in section 1-5. 
(Ord. No. 1289, § 1, 3-19-90) 
Chapter 8 - ELECTIONS[1]

Sec. 8-1. - Wards established, designated, boundaries prescribed. 
    There are hereby established within the corporate limits of the city four (4) wards to be designated, numbered, described and bounded as follows: 
(1)  Ward No. 1 : All that portion of the city lying east of Main St. and north of E BJ Tunnell Blvd. to railroad tracks and Tar Creek; that portion north and east from Tar Creek to Quail Creek to Quail Creek Dr., east and north of Quail Creek Dr. to E BJ Tunnell being projected north and east to a point equal in distance to the extension of the city limits in those directions. 
(2)  Ward No. 2 : All that portion of the city lying west of Main Str. being projected north to a point in distance to the extension of the city limits in that direction and north of a line projected west along 4 th Ave. NW to G Str. NW and projected North to 8 th Ave. NW, being projected north and east to a point equal in distance to the extension of the city limits in that direction. 
(3)  Ward No. 3 : All that portion of the city lying south of a line projected west along 4 th Ave. NW to G St. NW and projected north to 8 th Ave. NW, projected equal in distance to the extension of the city limits in that direction and west of Main Street and south and west of the Neosho River from a point where the extension of South Main intersects railroad and extends to the Neosho River to a point extended Southeasterly along the boundaries of the Neosho River to where the same intersects with the extension of the city limits. 
(4)  Ward No. 4 : All that portion of the city lying south of E BJ Tunnell Blvd. to railroad tracks and extending north and east to Tar Creek and South and East to Quail Creek, extending north and east to end of Quail Creek Dr., extending south to E BJ Tunnell and being projected South and East to extension of the city limits in those directions and east of Main St. and north and east of the Neosho River, from the point where Main St. South intersects railroad tracks and extends to the Neosho River to a point Southeasterly along the boundaries of the Neosho River to where the same intersects with the city limits. 
(Code 1964, § 2-7; Ord. No. 1303, § 1, 2-18-92; Ord. No. 1446, § 1, 1-7-02; Ord. No. 1577, § 1, 12-19-11) 
Charter reference- Designation, description, etc., of wards by ordinance, Art. IX, § 25. 
Sec. 8-2. - Absentee ballots. 
    Absentee ballots are hereby authorized for use in all city elections as allowed by 26 O.S. § 14-101. 
(Code 1964, § 2-8)
