(d)  It shall be unlawful for any sign, awning or canopy attached to any building in the central business district to extend beyond a point of four (4) feet inside the curb line or extend less than ten (10) feet above the ground level or more than ten (10) feet above the roof line of such building. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or construct any sign on the face of a building in the central business district without first obtaining a permit from the city engineer. 
(f)  Nothing in this section contained shall preclude the City Council from authorizing in special cases the display of merchandise by business establishments where the same is on a city-wide basis and considered to be in the public interest. This section specifically excludes newspaper vending machines which are normally located on the sidewalks for the benefit and convenience of the public. 
(Code 1964, § 12-40.3(a)-(c), (f); Ord. No. 1654, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Secs. 12-4-12-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UTILITY TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal utility taxes, 68 O.S. § 2601 et seq. 

Sec. 12-26. - Natural gas tax. 
(a)  There is hereby levied an annual tax upon every person engaged in commercial sales of natural gas for residential and commercial purposes with the city, in an amount equal to two percent (2%) of the gross revenue received by such person from the sale of natural gas for residential or commercial purposes in the city. Such tax shall be payable quarterly and placed in the general revenue fund of the city. 
(b)  During continued substantial compliance with the terms of this section by any person engaged in the sale of natural gas in the city for commercial or residential purposes, the charge levied hereby shall be and continue to be in lieu of all franchise, license, occupation or excise taxes levied by the city, except ad valorem taxes. 
(Code 1964, § 24-1) 
State Law reference- Authority to levy above tax, 68 O.S. § 2601; payment of tax, 68 O.S. § 2603. 
Sec. 12-27. - Telephone tax. 
(a)  There is hereby levied an annual tax upon each and every person operating a telephone exchange in the city, in an amount equal to two percent (2%) of the gross revenues for each current year for exchange telephone transmission service rendered wholly within the limits of the city, to compensate the city for the expenses incurred and services rendered incident to the exercise of the police regulation and police control of the construction of lines and equipment of such telephone company in the city. Such tax shall be due and payable on or before the first day of May of each year, and shall be paid into and appropriated and expended from the general revenue fund of the city. 
(b)  During continued substantial compliance with the terms of this section by the owner of any telephone exchange, the tax levied hereby shall be and continue to be in lieu of all concessions, charges, excise, franchise, license, privilege and permit fees or taxes or assessments, except ad valorem taxes; provided, however, that it is not intended to extinguish or abrogate any existing arrangement whereby the city is permitted to use underground conduit, duct space or pole contacts of such company for the fire alarm and police call systems of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 24-2) 
Secs. 12-28-12-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY SALES TAX 

Sec. 12-46. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as "City of Miami Sales Tax Ordinance-1985." 
(Code 1964, § 6-1) 
Sec. 12-47. - Definitions. 
(a)  The definitions of words, terms and phrases contained in 68 O.S. § 1352 are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(b)  The term "tax collector" as used in this article means the department of the city government or the official agency of the state duly designated according to law or contract authorized by law to administer the collection of the tax herein levied. 
(Code 1964, §§ 6-2, 6-3) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-48. - Classification of taxpayers. 
    For the purpose of this article the classification of taxpayers hereunder shall be as prescribed by state law for purposes of the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code [68 O.S. § 1350 et seq.]. 
(Code 1964, § 6-4) 
State Law reference- Classification of vendors, 68 O.S. § 1363. 
Sec. 12-49. - Subsisting state permits. 
    All valid and subsisting permits to do business issued by the Oklahoma Tax Commission pursuant to the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code [68 O.S. § 1350 et seq.] are, for the purpose of this article hereby ratified, confirmed and adopted in lieu of any requirement for an additional city permit for the same purpose. 
(Code 1964, § 6-5) 
State Law reference- State permits, 68 O.S. § 1364. 
Sec. 12-50. - Purpose of revenues. 
    It is hereby declared to be the purpose of this article to provide for the support of the functions of the municipal government of the City. It hereby is declared to be the purpose of the revenues provided by the additional sixty-five hundredths of one percent (0.65%) excise tax levied by this Ordinance to provide revenues for street and road improvements and by paying the principal of and interest on indebtedness incurred on behalf of said city for said purposes. Upon retirement of the aforementioned indebtedness, or call and refinancing of the same, this additional sixty-five hundredths of one percent (0.65%) excise tax levied by this article shall continue and shall provide revenues for the additional purpose of the improvement and construction of a community event center and stadium complex to be located at the Northeastern Oklahoma A&M College campus in Miami, Oklahoma, and to retire indebtedness thereupon incurred by the city or by a public trust of which the city is a beneficiary in a principal amount not to exceed eight million and eight hundred thousand dollars and interest thereupon. This sales tax shall not be repealed until such time as such indebtedness is retired. This sales tax shall no longer be levied or collected upon the retirement of the indebtedness incurred for these purposes. 
(Code 1964, § 6-7; Ord. No. 1558, § 1, 3-15-10; Ord. No. 1591, § 1, 11-5-12, eff. 4-1-13) 
Sec. 12-51. - Tax levied. 
(a)  There is hereby levied an excise tax of three and sixty-five hundredths of one percent (3.65%) upon the gross proceeds or gross proceeds derived from all sales taxable under the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code [68 O.S. § 1350 et seq.]. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article such tax does apply to gross receipts or proceeds derived from the sale of natural or artificial gas and electricity. 
(Code 1964, § 6-8; Ord. No. 1558, § 2, 3-15-10) 
State Law reference- Authority to levy sales tax, 68 O.S. § 2701 et seq.; sales subject to state tax, 68 O.S. § 1354. 
Sec. 12-52. - Exceptions. 
    The tax levied by the provisions of this article does not apply to those transactions, sales or transfers exempt from tax under the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code [68 O.S. § 1350 et seq.]. 
(Code 1964, §§ 6-9, 6-10) 
State Law reference- Exemptions, 68 0.8. §§ 1355-1360. 
Sec. 12-53. - Due date for tax. 
    The tax levied under this article shall be due and payable at the time and in the manner and form prescribed for payment of the state sales tax under the state sales tax law. 
(Code 1964, § 6-11) 
State Law reference- Due date of state tax, 68 O.S. § 1365. 
Sec. 12-54. - Payment of tax; bracket system of collection. 
(a)  The tax levied by this article shall be paid to the tax collector at the time in form and manner provided for payment of state sales tax under the state sales tax law. 
(b)  The bracket system for the collection of the three-percent city sales tax by the tax collector, shall be as the same is hereafter adopted by the agreement of the city, and the tax collector, in the collection of both the three-percent city sales tax and the appropriate state sales tax. 
(Code 1964, § 6-12) 
State Law reference- Payment of state tax, 68 O.S. § 1362. 
Sec. 12-55. - Priority of tax, penalty and interest; collection by suit. 
    The taxes, penalty, and interest due under this article shall at all times constitute a prior, superior and paramount claim as against the claims of unsecured creditors, and may be collected by suit as any other debt. 
(Code 1964, § 6-13) 
Sec. 12-56. - Vendor's duty to collect tax; penalty for violation. 
(a)  The tax levied under this article shall be paid by the consumer or user to the vendor and it shall be the duty of each and every vendor in the city to collect from the consumer or user, the full amount of the tax levied by this article, or in an amount equal as nearly as possible or practicable to the average equivalent thereof. 
(b)  Vendors shall add the tax imposed hereunder, or the average equivalent thereof, to the sales price or charge, and when added such tax shall constitute a part of such price or charge, shall be a debt from the consumer or user to vendor until paid, and shall be recoverable at law in the same manner as other debts. 
(c)  A vendor who willfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to collect the full amount of the tax levied by this article, or willfully or intentionally fails, neglects or refuses to comply with the provisions or remits or rebates to a consumer or user, either directly or indirectly, and by whatsoever means, all or any part of the tax herein levied, or makes in any form of advertising, verbally or otherwise, any statement which infers that he is absorbing the tax, or paying the tax for the consumer or user by an adjustment of prices or at a price including the tax, or in any manner, whatsoever, shall be guilty of an offense. 
(Code 1964, § 6-14) 
Sec. 12-57. - Returns and remittances; discounts. 
    Returns and remittances of the tax herein levied and collected shall be made to the tax collector at the time and in the manner, form and amount as prescribed for returns and remittances required by the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code [68 O.S. § 1350 et seq.]. Remittances of tax collected under this article shall be subject to the same discount as may be allowed by such code for collection of state sales taxes. 
(Code 1964, § 6-15) 
State Law reference- Returns and remittances, 68 O.S. § 1365. 
Sec. 12-58. - Levy and collection of interest and penalties; forfeit of discount and penalties; forfeit of discount. 
    The provisions of 68 O.S. § 217, are hereby adopted and made a part of this article, and interest and penalties at the rate and in the amounts as therein specified are hereby levied and shall be applicable in cases of delinquency in reporting and paying the tax levied by this article. The failure or refusal of any taxpayer to make and transmit the reports and remittances of tax in the time and manner required by this article shall cause such tax to be delinquent. In addition, if such delinquency continues for a period of five (5) days the taxpayer shall forfeit his claim to any discount allowed under this article. 
(Code 1964, § 6-16) 
Sec. 12-59. - Waiver and remission of interest and penalties. 
    The interest or penalty or any portion thereof accruing by reason of a taxpayer's failure to pay the city tax levied by this article may be waived or remitted in the same manner as provided for such waiver or remittance as applied in administration of the state sales tax provided in 68 O.S. § 220; and to accomplish the purposes of this section the applicable provisions of 68 O.S. § 220 are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 6-17) 
Sec. 12-60. - Refund of erroneous payments. 
    Refund of any erroneous payment of the city sales tax levied by this article may be made to any taxpayer making such erroneous payment in the same manner and procedure, and under the same limitations of time, as provided for administration of the state sales tax as set forth in 68 O.S. § 227, and to accomplish the purposes of this section, the applicable provisions of 68 O.S. § 227 are hereby adopted by reference and made a part of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 6-18) 
Sec. 12-61. - False and fraudulent reports; failure to make reports and remittances. 
    In addition to all civil penalties provided by this article, the willful failure or refusal of any taxpayer to make reports and remittances herein required, or the making of any false and fraudulent report for the purpose of avoiding or escaping payment of any tax or portion thereof rightfully due under this article shall be an offense. 
(Code 1964, § 6-19) 
Sec. 12-62. - Records and files declared confidential. 
    The confidential and privileged nature of the records and files concerning the administration of the city sales tax is legislatively recognized and declared, and to protect the same the provisions of 68 O.S. §§ 205 through 205.2 inclusive and each subsection thereof is hereby adopted by reference and made fully effective and applicable to administration of the city sales tax as if hereto set forth in full. 
(Code 1964, § 6-20) 
Sec. 12-63. - Amendments and additions to provisions. 
    The people of the city by their approval of this article at the election hereinabove provided, hereby authorize the board of commissioners by ordinances duly enacted to make such administrative and technical changes or additions in the method and manner of administration and enforcing this article as may be necessary or proper for efficiency and fairness except that the rate of the tax herein provided shall not be changed without approval of the qualified electors of the city as provided by law. 
(Code 1964, § 6-21) 
Sec. 12-64. - Provisions cumulative. 
    The provisions of this article shall be cumulative and in addition to any and all other taxing provisions of city ordinances. 
(Code 1964, § 6-22) 
Secs. 12-65-12-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POOL HALLS AND DOMINO PARLORS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- State regulation of pool halls, 21 O.S. § 1101 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 12-81. - Obstruction of view. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a pool or billiard hall or domino parlor in any room having a partition between the front and rear entrance or to so screen the windows of such hall or parlor as to obstruct the view in any manner from the outside. 
(Code 1964, § 19-1) 
Sec. 12-82. - Minors prohibited; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any pool or billiard hall or domino parlor in the city to permit any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to enter the same or play pool, billiards or dominoes therein, unless accompanied by his parent or guardian. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years to enter any such establishment or play pool, billiards or dominoes therein, unless accompanied by his parent or guardian. 
(Code 1964, § 19-2) 
Secs. 12-83-12-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 12-96. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a pool or billiard hall or domino parlor in the city, without first obtaining a license from the city clerk. 
(Code 1964, § 19-13) 
Sec. 12-97. - Application. 
    Every person desiring a license required by this division shall make written application therefor and file the same with the city clerk. 
(Code 1964, § 19-14) 
Sec. 12-98. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this division shall be $50.00; provided, however, the fee for a license issued after January first of any year shall be $25.00. 
(Code 1964, § 19-15) 
Sec. 12-99. - Issuance. 
    A license required by this division shall be issued by the city clerk. 
(Code 1964, § 19-16) 
Sec. 12-100. - Expiration. 
    Every license issued under the provisions of this division shall expire on the thirtieth day of June of each year. 
(Code 1964, § 19-17) 
Sec. 12-101. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued under the terms of this division shall be revokable at the pleasure of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1964, § 19-18) 
Secs. 12-102-12-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FAMILY RECREATION CENTERS 

Sec. 12-126. - Defined. 
    A family recreation center is hereby defined as a room or place where two (2) or more pool or billiard tables are maintained or where one (1) or more foosball or one (1) or more air hockey or pinball tables are maintained, or where there is a combination of any of these tables abovenamed and said tables are operated for a profit for use by all persons of all ages and either sex and designed to furnish recreation for families. 
(Code 1964, § 19-29) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-127. - Establishment and operation authorized. 
    The establishment and operation of family recreation centers in the city is hereby authorized and permitted with the passage of this article, subject to the regulations herein contained. 
(Code 1964, § 19-30) 
Sec. 12-128. - Exceptions. 
    Bowling alleys and skating rinks shall be exempt from the provisions regarding family recreation centers under this article. 
(Code 1964, § 19-36.1) 
Sec. 12-129. - Alcoholic beverages, gambling prohibited on premises; amusement machines; opening, closing hours. 
(a)  Family recreation centers may operate pool and billiard tables for a profit and for the use of all persons of all ages and either sex. 
(b)  No beer or other forms of intoxicating liquors or nonintoxicating alcoholic beverages may be sold or consumed or permitted on the premises. 
(c)  No gambling or wagering of any kind shall be permitted on the premises. Provided, that amusement machines may be installed and operated in family recreation centers, but the cost of playing such machines shall not exceed $0.50 per game, and such machine shall not give as a bonus more than five (5) free games and no cash refund for free games shall be made; each amusement machine must bear a state license showing that the state license fee has been paid. 
(d)  All such places of business shall not open before 8:00 a.m. nor remain open later than 12:00 midnight, except that on Sunday of each week such place of business shall not open until 12:00 noon. 
(Code 1964, § 19-31) 
Sec. 12-130. - License required; amount, proration of fee. 
    The owner of each family recreation center upon approval by the chief of police shall purchase a license from the city clerk for each location by payment of an annual fee of $50.00 provided that if less than six (6) months remain in the fiscal year in which the license is issued, the fee charged will be $25.00 for the remainder of that fiscal year. 
(Code 1964, § 19-36) 
Sec. 12-131. - Examination, approval of owner, manager, employees prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    Each owner, manager and employee of any family recreation center must be examined and approved by the chief of police of the city before any license shall issue. 
(Code 1964, § 19-34) 
Sec. 12-132. - Supervision and control of centers; suspension of operation; notice and hearing; revocation of license; appeal. 
    Family recreation centers shall be under the direct supervision and control of the chief of police and officers of the police department, and upon learning of any violation of this article, the chief of police shall suspend the operation of such family recreation center and give notice to the licensee of a hearing to be held before the chief of police not more than five (5) days thereafter, and the license of such licensee may be revoked upon such hearing. If revoked, the licensee shall have the right of appeal and hearing before the board of commissioners by giving notice of his intention to appeal, and such hearing shall be held at the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1964, § 19-33) 
Sec. 12-133. - Frequenting of centers by minors during school hours. 
    No owner, manager or employee of a family recreation center shall permit any youth sixteen (16) years of age or less to be in or about such establishment during school hours when public schools are in session. 
(Code 1964, § 19-35) 
Secs. 12-134-12-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ELECTRONIC AND VIDEO GAMES 

Sec. 12-156. - Exceptions. 
    Any establishment or business holding a license as otherwise set forth in this chapter shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 19-41) 
Sec. 12-157. - License required; application. 
    Any establishment or business which has on its premises two (2) or more electronic or video game machines shall be required to have a license as set forth herein. Every establishment or business desiring a license required by this article shall make written application therefore and file the same with the city clerk. 
(Code 1964, § 19-37) 
Sec. 12-158. - License fee; issuance, expiration of license. 
    The annual fee for a license required by this article shall be $50.00; provided, however, the fee for a license issued after January first of any year shall be $25.00. A license required by this article shall be issued by the city clerk. Every license issued under the provisions of this article shall expire on the thirteenth day of June of each year. 
(Code 1964, § 19-38) 
Sec. 12-159. - Supervision and control; suspension of operations; notice of hearing; revocation of license; appeal. 
    Any establishment or business required to procure a license as set forth herein shall be under the direct supervision and control of the chief of police and officers of the police department, and upon learning of any violation of this article or this Code in general, the chief of police shall suspend the operation of such electronic or video game machines and give notice to the licensee of a hearing to be held before the chief of police not more than five (5) days thereafter, and the license of such licensee may be revoked upon such hearing. If revoked, the licensee shall have right of appeal and hearing before the board of commissioners by giving notice of his intent to appeal, and such hearing shall be held at the next regular scheduled meeting of the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1964, § 19-39) 
Sec. 12-160. - Examination, approval of owner, manager, employees prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    Each owner, manager and employee of any establishment or business desiring to acquire a license under this article, must be examined and approved by the chief of police before any license shall issue. 
(Code 1964, § 19-40) 
Secs. 12-161-12-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 12-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage sales shall mean and include all sales entitled garage sales, lawn sales, attic sales, rummage sales, flea market sales or any other similar casual sale of tangible personal property which is advertised by any means whereby the public at large is or can be made aware of such sale. Advertisement shall include any and all written or oral notification that might be received by three (3) or more persons at any one (1) time, and shall include display of merchandise to the public. 
    Goods shall mean and include any goods, warehouse merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder. 
(Code 1964, § 12-12(a)) 
Sec. 12-182. - Penalty. 
    Any person conducting any sale coming under this article without first being properly licensed therefor or who shall violate any of the other terms and regulations of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 12-12(f)) 
Sec. 12-183. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
(1)  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(3)  Any person selling or advertising for sale items of personal property which are specifically named or designated in the advertisement and which separate items do not exceed five (5) in number. 
(Code 1964, § 12-12(e)) 
Sec. 12-184. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale in the city without first filing with the city clerk the information hereinafter specified, and obtaining from such clerk a license to do so, to be known as a garage sale license. There shall be a fee of $5.00 for the license required herein. 
(b)  Such license shall be issued to any one (1) person or household at any one (1) address only four (4) times within a twelve-month period and no such license shall be issued for more than four (4) consecutive calendar days. 
(c)  Each license issued under this article must be prominently displayed on the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the licensed sale. 
(d)  The information to be filed with the city clerk, pursuant to this section, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Name of person conducting such sale. 
(2)  Name of owner of the property on which such sale is to be conducted, and consent of owner if applicant is other than the owner. 
(3)  Location at which sale is to be conducted. 
(4)  Number of days of sale. 
(5)  Date, nature of any past sale. 
(6)  Relationship or connection applicant may have had with any other person conducting such sale and the date, or dates, of such sale. 
(7)  Whether or not applicant has been issued any other vendor's license by any local, state or federal agency. 
(8)  Sworn statement of affirmation by the person signing that the information given is full and true and known to him to be so. 
(Code 1964, § 12-12(b), (c), (d); Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 6-7-10) 
Secs. 12-185-12-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - HOTEL TAX 

Sec. 12-200. - Citation and codification. 
    This article shall be known and cited as the City of Miami Hotel Tax Ordinance of 1998, and is hereinafter referred to as "article." 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-201. - Subsisting state permits. 
    All valid and subsisting permits to do business by the Oklahoma Tax Commission pursuant to the Oklahoma Sales Tax Code are, for the purposes of this article, hereby ratified, confirmed, and adopted in lieu of any requirement for an additional city permit for the same purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-202. - Effective date and termination. 
    This article shall become and be effective on or after September 1, 1998, subject to approval of a majority of the registered voters of the city, voting on the same in the manner prescribed by law; provided that upon approval of the voters as required above, this article shall remain in effect and not be repealed unless repealed by a majority of the registered voters of the city, voting to repeal same in the manner as required by its approval. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-203. - Definitions. 
    Advisory Board shall mean Miami Recreation, Tourism, Convention and Visitors Bureau. 
    City financial officer (CFO) shall mean the person(s), employee(s) or agent(s) designated by the city manager to perform this role or function for purposes of this article. 
    Hotel or motel shall mean any building or buildings, structure, trailer, or other facility in which the public may, for consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations in which three (3) or more rooms are used for the accommodation of transient guests whether such rooms are in one (1) or several structures. The term shall include hotels, apartment hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, bed and breakfast inns, inns, rooming houses, trailer houses, trailer motels, apartments and sleeping rooms not occupied by "permanent residents," and all other facilities where rooms or sleeping accommodations or space are furnished for a consideration. The term shall not include hospitals, sanitariums, nursing homes, university dormitories or other educational or charitable institutions. 
    Occupancy shall mean the use or possession, or the right to use or possess any room or rooms in a hotel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings, or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room or rooms. 
    Occupant shall mean a person who for a consideration uses, possesses, or has the right to use of [or] possess any room or rooms in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use, or other agreement. 
    Permanent resident shall mean any occupant who, during the current term of occupancy, occupies or has the right of occupancy of any room or rooms in a hotel for thirty (30) or more consecutive days. 
    Rent shall mean the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also any amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. 
    Return shall mean any return filed or required to be filed as herein provided. 
    Room shall mean any room or rooms of any kind in any part or portion of a hotel which is available for or let out for use or possessed for any purpose other than a place of assembly. As used herein, "place of assembly" means a room or space which is not capable of being occupied for lodging purposes and which is used for educational, recreational, or amusement purposes and shall include: dance halls; cabarets; night clubs; restaurants; any room or space for public or private banquets, feasts, socials, card parties, or weddings; lodge and meeting halls or rooms; skating rinks; gymnasiums; swimming pools; billiards; bowling, and table tennis rooms; halls or rooms used for public or private catering purposes; funeral parlors; markets; recreational rooms; concert halls; broadcasting studios; and all other places of similar type of occupancy. 
    Tax shall mean the tax levied pursuant to this article. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98; Ord. No. 1548, § 1(A.), 10-5-09; Ord. No. 1585, § 1(B.), 7-16-12; Ord. No. 1659, § 1(A.), 8-16-2016) 
Sec. 12-204. - Use of funds. 
    All taxes collected pursuant to the provisions of this article shall, except as otherwise provided for therein, be set aside and used exclusively to benefit the community by creating, organizing and administering projects designed to increase the convention, tourism and visitor expenditures in the city. The city manager may, in his sole and exclusive discretion, prospectively establish and/or disestablish a "Convention and Visitor's Bureau", or as otherwise designated, as an administrative branch, bureau, department, or assignment area of the city under his authority. 
(Ord. No. 1548, § 1(B.), 10-5-09) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1548, § 1(B.), adopted Oct. 5, 2009, repealed § 12-204, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 12-204 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 12-205. - Miami Recreation, Tourism, Convention and Visitors Advisory Board. 
(a)  Renaming and Expanding. The Miami Convention and Tourism Advisory Board also known as Miami Convention and Visitors Bureau and also known as the Miami Convention, Tourism and Visitors Advisory Board is hereby renamed and its governing board is hereby expanded by two (2) members, as provided herein, to become the Miami Recreation, Tourism, Convention and Visitors Advisory Board, (hereafter "Advisory Board") which shall be composed of nine (9) voting members. 
(b)  Membership. All voting members of the Advisory Board shall be residents of Miami or residents of Ottawa County with the location of their place of employment in Miami. If any member moves their primary residence or place of employment outside the specified geographical location, then such relocation shall operate as a resignation of their membership. 
(c)  Compensation. All voting members shall serve without compensation. 
(d)  Constitution of the Advisory Board: The Mayor shall nominate, subject to confirmation by the City Council, a Council Member to serve ex officio as a voting member of the Advisory Board and to serve as its Chairperson. The City Council shall appoint eight (8) additional voting members of the Advisory Board from nominations made by the Mayor. One City Councilperson may serve ex officio as one of the eight additional voting members of the Advisory Board appointed by the City Council. If so selected, this second Councilperson shall serve as the Advisory Board's Vice-Chairperson. If a second Councilperson is not selected to serve on the Advisory Board, said Board shall select the Vice-Chairperson from among its own members. 
(e)  Term of office. The term(s) of office for each Advisory Board member position shall be reset as of the effective date of this ordinance. The City Council shall appoint a Council Member to serve ex officio in the first member position and may appoint a second Councilmember to serve ex officio in any one of the remaining member positions. Otherwise the terms of the member positions are as follows. The second and third member positions shall serve for an initial term of four (4) years. The fourth and fifth member positions shall serve for an initial term of three (3) years. The sixth and seventh member positions shall serve for an initial term of two (2) years. The eighth member position shall serve for an initial term of one (1) year. Following the end of each initial term, each such Advisory Board member position not filled by a Council Member shall be appointed for a two (2) year term. 
(f)  Removal. The mayor and city council may, with or without cause, remove any of the board members described in this section. 
(g)  Powers and duties. 
(1)  The meetings of the Advisory Board shall be called by the Chairman or upon the written request of two (2) board members. 
(2)  Five (5) members shall constitute a quorum and all resolutions may be transacted by a simple majority of a quorum. 
(3)  All meetings and transactions of the Advisory Board shall comply with applicable provisions of the Oklahoma Open Meeting Act and Oklahoma Open Records Act , in addition to all other relevant and applicable law(s). 
(4)  The Advisory Board shall have no authority to engage employees, agents or paid consultants, appropriate funds, establish a budget, or to enter into contractual agreements. 
(5)  The Advisory Board shall have the authority to make recommendations to the Mayor, City Council and City Manager with regard to the Hotel Tax revenue(s); to meet with representatives of the City; to confer with persons with knowledge of the hotel industry, tourism and attractions, and marketing; and to liaison with local, regional, state and national organizations for the development of promotion and marketing strategies. 
(6)  The Advisory Board shall have the authority to make recommendations to the Mayor, City Council and City Manager with regard to the establishment, provision, maintenance, construction, and conduct of municipally owned parks, playgrounds, recreation centers, athletic fields or grounds, swimming pools, social and community centers, and recreation programs. 
(Ord. No. 1548, § 1(B.), 10-5-09; Ord. No. 1619, § 1, 12-17-13; Ord. No. 1648, § 1, 11-3-2015; Ord. No. 1659, § 1(B.), 8-16-2016) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1548, § 1(B.), adopted Oct. 5, 2009, repealed § 12-205, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 12-205 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 12-206. - Tax levied. 
    There is hereby levied an excise tax of five percent (5%) of the gross proceeds or gross receipts derived from all rent for every occupancy of a room or rooms in a hotel or motel in this city. This excise tax shall be in addition to any existing sales taxes imposed by the city or the state. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98; Ord. No. 1602, § 1, 3-5-13) 
Sec. 12-207. - Exemptions. 
    The following guests shall be exempt from the tax levied in this article: 
(1)  Permanent residents as defined in this article; 
(2)  Reserved. 
Every operator shall document the basis for which the exemptions are made pursuant to this section on a form provided by the CFO or, if no form is provided, in sufficient detail as to be verified by audit by the CFO. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98; Ord. No. 1389, § 1, 1-18-99) 
Sec. 12-208. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1389, § 1, adopted Jan. 18, 1999, repealed § 12-208 which pertained to proof of exemption. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 12-209. - Tax to be designated. 
    The operator shall separately designate, charge, and show all taxes on all bills, statements, receipts, or any other evidence of charges or payment of rent for occupancy issued or delivered by the operator. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-210. - Operator responsibility for collection. 
    The operator shall be responsible for the collection of the tax from the occupant and shall be liable to the city for the tax. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-211. - Records. 
    It shall be the duty of every operator required to make a return and pay any tax under this article to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross daily rentals together with other pertinent records and documents which may be necessary to determine the amount of tax due hereunder and such other records as will substantiate and prove the accuracy of such returns. All records shall remain in the city and be preserved for a period of three (3) years, unless the CFO, in writing, has authorized their destruction or disposal at an earlier date, and shall be open to examination at any time by the CFO or by any of his duly authorized agents. The burden of proving that a sale was not a taxable sale shall be upon the operator who makes the sale. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-212. - Returns. 
(a)  The tax levied hereunder shall be due and payable to the CFO on the first day of each month, except as herein provided, by any person liable for the payment of any tax due under this article. For the purpose of ascertaining the amount of the tax payable under this article, it shall be the duty of all operators, on or before the 15th day of each month, to deliver to the CFO, upon forms prescribed and furnished by him, returns, under oath, showing the gross receipts or gross proceeds arising from rents received from occupancy of hotel rooms during the preceding calendar month. Such returns shall show such further information as the CFO may require to correctly compute and collect the tax herein levied. In addition to the information required on returns, the CFO may request and the operator shall furnish any information deemed necessary for a correct computation of the tax levied herein. Such operator shall compute and remit to the CFO the required tax due for the preceding calendar month. The remittance or remittances of the tax shall accompany the returns herein required. If not paid on or before the 15th of such month, the tax shall be delinquent after such date; provided, that no interest or penalty shall be charged on such return filed on or before the 20th day of such month. 
(b)  The CFO may permit or require returns to be made by shorter or longer periods and upon such dates as he may specify. The form of return shall be prescribed by the CFO and shall contain such information as he may deem necessary for the proper administration of this article. The CFO may require amended returns to be filed within twenty (20) days after notice, which amended return shall contain the information specified in the notice. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-213. - Payment of tax. 
    At the time of filing a return of occupancy and of rents, each operator shall pay to the CFO the taxes imposed by this article upon the rents included in such return, as well as all other monies collected by the operator acting or purporting to act under the provisions of this Article. All the taxes for the period for which a return is required to be filed shall be due from the operator and payable to the CFO on or before the date fixed for the filing of the return of such period without regard to whether a return is filed or whether the return which is filed correctly shows the amount of rents and the taxes due thereon. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-214. - Bond required. 
    Where the CFO believes that any operator is about to cease business, leave the state, or remove or dissipate assets, or for any other similar reason he deems it necessary in order to protect revenues under this article, the CFO may require such operator to file with the city a bond issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in this state in such amount as the CFO may fix to secure the payment of any tax or penalties and interest due, or which may become due from such operator. In the event that the CFO determines that an operator is to file such bond, the CFO shall give notice to such operator specifying the amount of bond required. The operator shall file such bond within five (5) days after the delivery or mailing of such notice unless within such five (5) days the operator shall request in writing a hearing before the city commission or its designee, at which time the propriety and amount of the bond shall be determined by the city commission or its designee. Such determination shall be final and shall be complied with within fifteen (15) days thereafter. In lieu of such bond, securities approved by the CFO, or cash in such amount as the CFO may prescribe, may be deposited with the CFO. The CFO may at any time after five (5) days notice to the operator, apply the bond, cash or other security to any tax and/or any penalties due and for that purpose the securities may be sold at private or public sale. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-215. - Assessment and determination of tax. 
    If a return required by this article is not filed, or if a return when filed is incorrect or insufficient, the amount of tax due shall be assessed by the CFO from such information as may be obtainable and, if necessary, the tax may be estimated on the basis of external indices, such as number of rooms, location, scale of rents, comparable rents, types of accommodations and services, number of employees, or other factors. Written notice of such assessments shall be given to the person liable for the collection and payment of the tax. Such assessment shall finally and irrevocably fix and determine the tax unless the person against whom it is assessed, within two (2) years after the giving of notice of such assessment, shall apply in writing to the city council for a hearing or unless the CFO upon his own initiative shall reassess the same. After such hearing the city shall give written notice of its determination to the person against whom the tax is assessed and such determination shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-216. - Refunds. 
(a)  Procedure. The CFO shall refund or credit any tax erroneously, illegally, or unconstitutionally collected if written application to the CFO for such refund shall be made within two (2) years from the date of payment thereof. For like causes and in the same period, a refund may be made upon the initiative and the order of the CFO. Whenever a refund is made, the reasons therefor shall be stated in writing. Such application may be made by the person upon whom such tax was imposed and who has actually paid the tax. Such application may also be made by the person who has collected and paid such tax to the CFO provided that the application is made within two (2) years of the payment by the occupant to the operator, but no refund of money shall be made to the operator until he has repaid to the occupant the amount for which the application for refund is made. The CFO, in lieu of any refund required to be made, may allow credit therefor on payments due from the applicant. 
(b)  Determination and hearing. Upon application for a refund the CFO may receive evidence with respect thereto, and make such investigation as he deems necessary. After making a determination as to the refund, the CFO shall give notice thereof to the applicant. Such determination shall be final unless the applicant, within ninety (90) days after such notice, shall apply in writing to the city for a hearing. After such hearing, the city shall give written notice of its decision to the applicant. 
(c)  Person not entitled to refund. A person shall not be entitled to revision, refund or credit of a tax under this section if he has had a hearing or an opportunity for a hearing as provided in this chapter and has failed to avail himself of the remedies therein provided. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-217. - Notices. 
    Any notice provided for under this article shall be deemed to have been given when such notice has been delivered personally to the operator or deposited in the United States mail addressed to the last-known address of the operator. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-218. - Remedies exclusive. 
    The remedies provided in this article shall be exclusive remedies available to any person for the review of tax liability imposed by the article. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-219. - Powers of city financial officer. 
    In addition to all other powers granted to the CFO, he is hereby authorized and empowered: 
(1)  To make, adopt, and amend rules and regulations appropriate to the collection of taxes pursuant to this article; 
(2)  To extend for cause shown the time for filing any return for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days; and, for cause shown, to waive, remit, or reduce penalties or interest; 
(3)  To delegate his functions hereunder to an assistant or other employee or employees of the city; 
(4)  To prescribe methods for determining the taxable and nontaxable rents. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-220. - Proceedings to recover tax; civil remedies. 
(a)  Whenever any operator, occupant or other person shall fail to collect and/or pay over any tax, or to owe any tax, penalty or interest imposed by this article as herein provided, the CFO shall file notice of liens on behalf of the city against the real estate upon which the hotel is located and/or against all franchises, property, and rights to property, whether real or personal, then belonging to or thereafter acquired by the person owing the tax pursuant to 68 O.S. § 2701 et seq. 
(b)  The lien shall, upon proper filing, attached to the real estate and/or personal property then owned or thereafter acquired by the debtor, whether such property is used by the debtor in the operation of business or is under the authority of an assignee, trustee or receiver for the benefit of creditors, from the date such taxes are due and payable as allowed by 68 O.S. § 2704. 
(c)  The CFO shall notify the person owing the tax by personal service or by certified mail that the city will file such liens if any delinquent lodging taxes, interest and/or penalties are not paid within fifteen (15) days of receiving such notice. The CFO may confer with the city attorney to institute an action in personam and in rem to enforce payment and collect any delinquent lodging taxes, penalties and/or interest. 
(d)  Criminal penalties. In addition to all civil penalties provided by this chapter, the willful failure or refusal of any operator, occupant or other persons who make reports and/or remittances as herein required or the making of any false and fraudulent report for the purpose of avoiding or escaping payment of any tax or portion thereof rightfully due under this article shall be in offense and upon the conviction thereof the offending operator, occupant or other person shall be punished subject to section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-221. - Administration of oaths and compelling testimony. 
    The CFO shall have the power to administer oaths, subpoena and require the attendance of witnesses, the production of books, papers and documents, and take affidavits in relation to any matter or proceeding in the exercise of the powers and duties of the CFO or city commission under this article. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-222. - Registration certificates; certificates of authority. 
    Every operator shall file with the CFO a registration certificate in a form prescribed by said CFO within ten (10) days after the effective date of this article (September 1, 1998) or, in the case of operators commencing business or opening new hotels after such effective date, within three (3) days after such commencement or opening. The CFO shall, within five (5) days after the filing of such certificate, issue without charge to each operator a certificate of authority empowering such operator to collect the tax from the occupant and duplicates thereof for each additional hotel. Each certificate or duplicate shall state the hotel to which it is applicable. Such certificate of authority shall be permanently displayed by the operator in such manner that it may be seen and come to the notice of all occupants and persons seeking occupancy. Such certificates shall be non-assignable and non-transferable and shall be surrendered immediately to the CFO upon the cessation of business at the hotel, or upon its sale or transfer. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-223. - Administration. 
    One percent (1%) of the gross receipts derived from taxes collected pursuant to this article shall be retained by the city, for the purpose of administering and collecting the tax. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-224. - Discounts. 
    In order to remunerate an operator for keeping tax records, filing reports and remitting taxes when due, a three percent (3%) discount shall be allowed on the total taxes paid prior to the time the tax becomes delinquent. This discount shall not apply to delinquent taxes or interest payments. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-225. - Interest and penalties. 
(a)  If any tax levied or assessed by this article becomes delinquent, the person or entity responsible and liable for such tax shall pay a penalty equal to ten percent (10%) of the unpaid tax and interest on such unpaid tax and penalty shall accrue at the rate of one and one-half percent (11/2%) per month on the unpaid balance from the date of delinquency. 
(b)  The city may bring a civil suit to enforce payment of any past due tax levied or assessed pursuant to this article in addition to conviction hereunder and in said civil suit shall be entitled to recover all reasonable cost and expenses, including reasonable attorney fees. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-226. - Records confidential. 
    The confidential and privileged nature of the records and files concerning the administration of the tax is legislatively recognized and declared; and to protect the same, the provision of 68 O.S. (1998) § 205 of the State Sales Tax Code, and each subsection thereof, are hereby adopted by reference and made fully effective and applicable to the administration of this article as if herein set forth. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-227. - Fraudulent returns. 
    The willful failure or refusal of any operator to make reports and remittances herein required, or the making of any false or fraudulent report for the purpose of avoiding or escaping payment of any tax or a portion thereof rightfully due under this article shall be an offense against the city. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-228. - Amendments. 
    The people of the city, by their approval of this article at the election herein provided, hereby authorize the city commission, by ordinance duly enacted, to make such administrative and technical changes or additions in the method and manner of administering and enforcing this article as may be necessary or proper for efficiency and fairness, except that the rate of the tax herein provided shall not be changed without approval of the qualified voters of the city as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-229. - Provisions cumulative. 
    The provisions hereof shall be cumulative and in addition to any and all other taxing provisions of the city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-230. - Provisions severable. 
    The provisions hereof are hereby declared to be severable, and if any section, paragraph, sentence, or clause of this article is for any reason held invalid or inoperative by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect any other section, paragraph, sentence, or clause hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 12-231. - Payment of legal fees. 
    In the event a suit in a court of competent jurisdiction is caused to be filed, either on behalf of or against the city, and said cause is the direct result of the conditions, stipulations, or requirements hereinbefore set forth, an amount necessary to pay all legal fees incurred by the city, as well as fines or penalties imposed against it, shall be set aside from the monies authorized to be collected hereby in payment thereof, regardless of whether said cause was for the purpose of enforcing or defending the provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1380, § I, 6-15-98) 
Chapter 13 - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS AND OFFENSES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Railroad trains-Speed limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated within the city any railroad train, motor car, engine or other railroad equipment at a greater speed than twenty-five (25) miles per hour, except that on the main line track railroad equipment may be operated at a speed not greater than thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
(Code 1964, § 12-22) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to regulate the speed of trains, Art. III, § 14. 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate speed of trains, 11 O.S. § 22-119. 
Sec. 13-2. - Same-Whistle, bell. 
    Any railroad engine shall sound a whistle or bell in accordance with all state and federal requirements. 
(Code 1964, § 12-23) 
State Law reference- Sounding of whistle or bell required, 21 O.S. § 1253. 
Secs. 13-3-13-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes against the person, 21 O.S. § 641 et seq. 

Sec. 13-26. - Assaults. 
(a)  In this section assault means any willful and unlawful attempt or offer with force or violence to do a corporal hurt to another. 
(b)  Assault is a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 12-2) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prevent assaults, Art. III, § 15. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 641. 
Sec. 13-27. - Battery. 
(a)  In this section battery means any willful and unlawful use of force or violence upon the person of another. 
(b)  Battery is a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 12-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 642. 
Secs. 13-28-13-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY RIGHTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes involving property rights, 21 O.S. § 1401 et seq. 

Sec. 13-46. - Larceny. 
(a)  Larceny is the taking of personal property accomplished by fraud or stealth, and with intent to deprive another thereof. 
(b)  One who finds lost property under circumstances which gives him knowledge or means of inquiry as to the true owner, and who appropriates such property to his own use, or to the use of another person who is not entitled thereto, without having first made such effort to find the owner and restore the property to him as the circumstances render reasonable and just, is guilty of larceny. 
(c)  Larceny is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1964, § 12-17; Ord. No. 2017-11, § 1, 12-5-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. §§ 1701, 1702. 
Sec. 13-47. - Obtaining property by trick or deception, false statements or pretenses, confidence games, false or bogus checks, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, with intent to cheat and defraud, to obtain or attempt to obtain from any person, firm or corporation any money, property or valuable thing, of a value of less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) by means or by use of any trick or deception, or false or fraudulent misrepresentation or statement or pretense, or by any other means or instrument or device commonly called a "confidence game", or by means or use of any false or bogus checks, or by any other written or printed or engraved instrument or spurious coin. The same shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Every person who shall lease or rent, for any period of time whatsoever, any motor vehicle and, with intent to cheat and defraud, who pays the fees for such lease or rental by means of a false, bogus or worthless check written for the sum of less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor 
(c)  The term "false or bogus check or checks" shall include checks or orders, including those converted to electronic fund transfer, which are not honored on account of insufficient funds of the maker to pay same or because the check or order was drawn on a closed account or on a nonexistent account when such checks or orders are given: 
1.  In exchange for money or property; 
2.  In exchange for any benefit or thing of value; 
3.  As a down payment for the purchase of any item of which the purchaser is taking immediate possession, as against the maker or drawer thereof; or 
4.  As payment made to a landlord under a lease or rental agreement. 
(d)  The making, drawing, uttering, or delivering of a check, draft, or order, payment of which is refused by the drawee, shall be prima facie evidence of intent to defraud and the knowledge of insufficient funds in, or credit with, such bank or other depository; provided, such maker or drawer shall not have paid the drawee thereof the amount due thereon, together with the protest fees, within five (5) days from the date the same is presented for payment; and provided, further, that the check or order is presented for payment within thirty (30) days after same is delivered and accepted. 
(e)  A check offered for the purchase of goods or livestock that is refused by a drawee shall not be considered to be an extension of credit by the seller of goods or livestock to the maker or drawer of the check. 
(f)  A check or order offered to a merchant in payment on an open account of the maker with the merchant shall mean "a check or order given in exchange for a benefit or thing of value", notwithstanding that the merchant may debit the account of the maker or impose other charges pursuant to applicable law in the event the check or order is not honored. 
(g)  Any person who is convicted of any offense herein contained shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1964, § 12-17.1; Ord. No. 2017-12, § 1, 12-5-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. §§ 1541.1, 1541.4, 1541.5. 
Sec. 13-47.1. - Defrauding hotels, inns, restaurants, etc. 
    Any person who shall obtain food, lodging, services or other accommodations at any hotel, inn, restaurant, boarding house, rooming house, motel or auto camp, with intent to defraud the owner or keeper thereof, if the value of such food, lodging, services or other accommodations is less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). Any person who shall obtain shelter, lodging, or any other services at any apartment house, apartment, rental unit, rental house, or trailer camp, with intent to defraud the owner or keeper thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00. Proof that such lodging, food, services or other accommodations were obtained by false pretense or by false or fictitious show or pretense of any baggage or other property, or that he gave a check on which payment was refused, or that he left the hotel, inn, restaurant, boarding house, rooming house, motel, apartment house, apartment, rental unit or rental house, trailer camp or auto camp, without payment or offering to pay for such food, lodging, services or other accommodation, or that he surreptitiously removed or attempted to remove his baggage, or that he registered under a fictitious name, shall be prima facie proof of the intent to defraud mentioned in this section; but this section shall not apply where there has been an agreement in writing for delay in payment. 
(Ord. No. 2017-13, § 1, 12-5-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1503. 
Sec. 13-48. - Shoplifting. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
(1)  Merchant shall mean any corporation, partnership, association, or person who is engaged in the business of selling goods, wares and merchandise in a mercantile establishment. 
(2)  Mercantile establishment shall mean any mercantile place of business in, at or from which goods, wares and merchandise are sold, offered for sale or delivered from and sold at retail or wholesale. 
(3)  Merchandise shall mean all goods, wares and merchandise offered for sale or displayed by a merchant. 
(4)  Wrongful taking shall mean and include stealing of merchandise or money and any other wrongful appropriation of merchandise or money. 
(b)  Authority of peace officers to arrest without warrant. Any peace officer may arrest without warrant any person he has probable cause for believing has committed larceny of merchandise held for sale in a retail or wholesale establishment, when such arrest is made in a reasonable manner. 
(c)  Detention of suspect; purposes. Any merchant, his agent or employee, who has reasonable grounds or probable cause to believe that a person has committed or is committing a wrongful taking of merchandise or money from a mercantile establishment, may detain such person in a reasonable manner for a reasonable length of time for all or any of the following purposes: 
(1)  Conducting an investigation, including reasonable interrogation of the detained person, as to whether there has been a wrongful taking of such merchandise or money. 
(2)  Informing the police or other law enforcement officials of the facts relevant to such detention. 
(3)  Performing a reasonable search of the detained person and his belongings when it appears that the merchandise or money may otherwise be lost. 
(4)  Recovering the merchandise or money believed to have been taken wrongfully. Any such reasonable detention shall not constitute an unlawful arrest or detention, nor shall it render the merchant, his agent or employee criminally or civilly liable to the person so detained. 
(d)  Concealing unpurchased merchandise; presumption. Any person concealing unpurchased merchandise of any mercantile establishment, either on the premises or outside the premises of such establishment, shall be presumed to have so concealed such merchandise with the intention of committing a wrongful taking of such merchandise within the meaning of subsection (a) of this section, and such concealment or the finding of such unpurchased merchandise concealed upon the person or among the belongings of such person shall be conclusive evidence of reasonable grounds and probable cause for the detention in a reasonable manner and for a reasonable length of time, of such person by a merchant, his agent or employee, and any such reasonable detention shall not be deemed to be unlawful, nor render such merchant, his agent or employee criminally or civilly liable. 
(e)  Penalty. Every person who is convicted of violating this section where the value of the merchandise which has been taken is less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1964, § 12-40.1; Ord. No. 2017-14, § 1, 12-5-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 22 O.S. §§ 1341-1344 and 21 O.S. § 1731. 
Sec. 13-48.1. - Gasoline pump thievery. 
    Any person who pumps gasoline into the gasoline tank of a vehicle or other container of any sort and leaves the premises where the gasoline was pumped without making payment for the gasoline shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 2017-15, § 1, 12-5-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1740. 
Sec. 13-49. - Trespass upon premises or property of another prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall willfully enter or remain upon or in any land, structure, vehicle, aircraft or watercraft with knowledge that he is not authorized or privileged to enter or remain upon or in such land, structure, vehicle, aircraft or watercraft, if: 
(1)  He enters upon or in the land, structure, vehicle, aircraft or watercraft, after such entry upon or in has been forbidden by a personal communication of the owner or person authorized by the owner to make such communication, or he remains upon or in the land, structure, vehicle, aircraft or watercraft after he has been ordered to leave by the owner or person authorized by the owner to do so order; or 
(2)  The land, structure, vehicle, aircraft or watercraft is posted in a reasonable manner which would ordinarily come to the attention of intruders; or 
(3)  The premises or property is used for residential purposes. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to cases involving landlord and tenants. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 12-38) 
State Law reference- Trespass, 21 O.S. § 1835 et seq. 
Sec. 13-50. - Trespass upon places of public amusement prohibited. 
    Any person who shall go upon the enclosed grounds or into any enclosed public place of amusement while any performance is being given, when an admission fee is charged, against the will and without a ticket, pass, or written or oral permission or invitation from the manager or party having charge or control of such public place of amusement shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon the conviction thereof shall be punished under section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 12-38.1) 
Sec. 13-51. - Malicious injury. 
    Every person who maliciously injures, defaces or destroys any real or personal property not his own, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 12-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1760. 
Sec. 13-52. - Tampering with, operating, etc., vehicle without owner's permission. 
    No person shall drive, operate, use or tamper with a motor vehicle in the city, without the permission of the owner thereof. No person shall, without the permission of the owner or person in charge thereof, climb upon or into, or swing upon any motor vehicle or trailer, whether the same is in motion or at rest, or sound the horn or other sound-producing devices thereon, or attempt to manipulate any of the levers, starting device, brakes or machinery thereof, or set the machinery in motion. 
(Code 1964, § 26-9) 
Sec. 13-53. - Utility poles, marking, painting, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to mark, write, print, paint upon or otherwise make any signs or marks, by identification or otherwise, or by posting signs or posters, upon any telephone, telegraph, electric light or power pole, either wood, concrete, steel or of any other substance, within the corporate limits of the city. The word "pole" shall be construed to mean any pole supporting telephone, light, trolley or power wires or braces, and any device used to support or brace such a pole. This section shall not apply to the owners of such poles who may make such marks or signs thereon as may be needed for the purpose of protecting the public from danger by reason of such poles, and who may make such marks or identification as are necessary in the proper accounting of their properties. 
(Code 1964, § 12-26) 
Sec. 13-54. - Receiving stolen property. 
    Every person who buys or receives, in any manner, upon any consideration, any personal property of any value whatsoever that has been stolen, embezzled, obtained by false pretense or robbery, knowing or having reasonable cause to believe the same to have been stolen, embezzled, obtained by false pretense, or robbery, or who conceals, withholds, or aids in concealing or withholding such property from the owner where the value of the property received is less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), is guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Code 1964, § 12-24; Ord. No. 2017-16, § 1, 12-5-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1713. 
Sec. 13-55. - Control of advertising matter. 
    No person shall pass, circulate, distribute, post or otherwise publish any bill, poster or other advertising matter in such a manner that such advertising matter does or might blow about the streets, alleys and public places of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 12-1) 
Secs. 13-56-13-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Crimes against public health and safety, 21 O.S. § 1191 et seq. 

Sec. 13-76. - Riot. 
(a)  Any use of force or violence, or any threat to use force or violence if accompanied by immediate power of execution, by three (3) or more persons acting together and without authority of law, is riot. 
(b)  Riot is a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 12-25) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1311. 
Sec. 13-77. - Unlawful assembly. 
(a)  Wherever three (3) or more persons assemble with intent or with means and preparations to do an unlawful act which would be riot if actually committed, but do not act toward the commission thereof, or whenever such persons assemble without authority of law, and in such a manner as is adapted to disturb the public peace, or excite public alarm, such assembly is an unlawful assembly. 
(b)  Unlawful assembly is a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 12-25) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1314. 
Sec. 13-78. - Violence against person or property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any unlawful act with force or violence against the person or property of another, with or without a common cause or quarrel, or to do a lawful act in a violent, tumultuous or threatening manner, within the city. 
(Code 1964, § 12-28) 
Sec. 13-79. - Carrying and transporting weapons. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to carry upon or about his or her person, or in a purse or other container belonging to the person, any dagger, bowie knife, dirk knife, switchblade knife, spring-type knife, sword cane, knife having a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring, or other device in the handle of the knife, blackjack, loaded cane, billy, hand chain, metal knuckles, or any other offensive weapon other than a firearm, whether such weapon be concealed or unconcealed, except this section shall not prohibit: 
(1)  The proper use of knives for hunting, fishing, educational or recreational purposes; 
(2)  The carrying or use of weapons in a manner otherwise permitted by statute or authorized by the Oklahoma Self-Defense Act; 
(3)  The carrying, possession and use of any weapon by a peace officer or other person authorized by law to carry a weapon in the performance of official duties and in compliance with the rules of the employing agency; 
(4)  The carrying and use of weapons provided in this subsection when used for the purpose of living history reenactment. For purposes of this paragraph, "living history reenactment" means depiction of historical characters, scenes, historical life or events for entertainment, education, or historical documentation through the wearing or use of period, historical, antique or vintage clothing, accessories, weapons, and other implements of the historical period. 
    Any person convicted of violating this section 13-79(a) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon a first conviction, be adjudged guilty of a misdemeanor and the party offending shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $250.00, or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days or both such fine and imprisonment. On the second and every subsequent violation, the party offending shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $250.00 nor more than $500.00, or by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Pursuant to 21 O.S. § 1289.24(A)(2)(b) and § 1289.13A, any person stopped pursuant to a moving traffic violation who is transporting a loaded pistol in the motor vehicle without a valid handgun license authorized by the Oklahoma Self-Defense Act or valid license from another state, whether the loaded firearm is concealed or unconcealed in the vehicle, shall be issued a traffic citation in the amount of seventy dollars ($70.00), plus court costs for transporting a firearm improperly. In addition to the traffic citation provided in this section, the person may also be arrested for any other violation of law. When the arresting officer determines that a valid handgun license exists, pursuant to the Oklahoma Self-Defense Act or any provision of law from another state, for any person in the stopped vehicle, any firearms permitted to be carried pursuant to that license shall not be confiscated, unless: 
(1)  The person is arrested for violating another provision of law other than a violation of this subsection 13-79(b); provided, however, if the person is never charged with an offense pursuant to this paragraph or if the charges are dismissed or the person is acquitted, the weapon shall be returned to the person; or 
(2)  The officer has probable cause to believe the weapon is: 
a.  Contraband, or 
b.  A firearm used in the commission of a crime other than a violation of subsection 13-79(a) of this section. 
    Nothing in this section shall be construed to require confiscation of any firearm. 
(c)  This section 13-79 shall not apply in any way to firearms, firearms components, firearms ammunition, or firearms supplies except to the extent allowed by state law because the Oklahoma State Legislature has enacted 21 O.S. § 1289.24, by which the State Legislature occupied and preempted the entire field of legislation in this state touching in any way firearms, components, ammunition, and supplies to the complete exclusion of any order, ordinance, or regulation by a municipality or other political subdivision of this state. 
(Code 1964, § 12-29; Ord. No. 1593, § 1, 11-5-12) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prohibit the carrying of weapons, Art. III, § 25. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1272. 
Secs. 13-80-13-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Offenses against public peace, 21 O.S. § 1261 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-116. - Noise control. 
    If any person shall wilfully or maliciously disturb, either by day or night, the peace and quiet of the city, neighborhood, family or person by loud or unusual noise, or by abusive, violent, obscene or profane language, whether addressed to the party so disturbed or some other person, or by threatening to kill, do bodily harm or injury, destroy property, fight, or by quarreling or challenging to fight, or fighting, or shooting off any firearms, or brandishing the same, or by running any horse at unusual speed along any street, alley, highway or public road, he shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 12-3) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prohibit breaches of the peace and disturbances, Art. III, § 15. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1362. 
Sec. 13-116.5 - Gatherings on public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for two (2) or more persons to gather together or congregate on or in any public parking lot, park or other outdoor public property belonging to the city or any of its agencies or affiliates, whether the individuals are inside motor vehicles or not, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. except for the purpose of conducting official business of the city. Any person found to be in violation of the above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and penalized as provided by section 1-5 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1292, § 1, 5-7-90) 
Sec. 13-117. - Fighting. 
    If two (2) or more persons shall voluntarily or by agreement fight within the limits of the city to the terror of any person in the city, every person found to be in violation of the above shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 12-8) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prevent fighting, Art. III, § 15. 
Sec. 13-118. - Profane, abusive, etc., language. 
(a)  No person shall make use of any profane, vulgar, violent, abusive or insulting language toward or about another person in his presence or hearing, which language, in its common acceptance, is calculated to arouse to anger the person about or to whom it is spoken or addressed, or to cause a breach of the peace or an assault. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to use or permit the use of obscene, profane or lascivious language in any public place within the city or in any play or performance given in any theater or other public place or used for public amusement. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person in the city, whether manager, operator or owner of any theater, or other public place of amusement, to allow or to permit any person to use any obscene, profane, or lascivious language, in any play or performance given in any such theater, or other public place of amusement. 
(Code 1964, § 12-18) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prevent the use of profane, insulting, etc., language, Art. III, § 15. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 21 O.S. § 1363. 
Sec. 13-119. - Transporting nonintoxicating beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly transport in any vehicle upon a public street or alley, in the city, any nonintoxicating beverage containing more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) alcohol by volume and not more than three and two-tenths percent (3.2%) alcohol by weight except in the original container which shall not have been opened and from which the original cap or seal shall not have been removed, unless the opened container be in the rear trunk or rear compartment which shall include the spare tire compartment in a station wagon or panel truck, or any outside compartment which is not accessible to the driver or any other person in the vehicle while it is in motion. 
(Code 1964, § 12-39)
