Sec. 20-30. - Terms of members. 
    All appointments and confirmations to the library board shall be for terms of three (3) years from the expiration of the terms of office of the members of the board whose terms have expired. 
(Code 1964, § 20-20) 
Sec. 20-31. - General powers and duties. 
    The board shall have the care and management of all libraries and reading rooms in the city, for the support and maintenance of which financial provision is made, wholly or in part, by the city, except that the library director shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 20-21; Ord. No. 1462, § 1, 5-19-03) 
Sec. 20-32. - Rules and regulations. 
    The board may make all necessary rules and regulations for the proper care and management of libraries and reading rooms supported by the city. 
(Code 1964, § 20-22) 
Chapter 21 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Streets and public properties director, § 2-88 et seq.; dead or diseased trees upon parkway, § 15-2. 
State Law reference- General municipal authority relative to streets, roads and public ways, 11 O.S. § 36-101. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 21-1-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 21-26. - Permit. 
    Before any person shall dig or cut into any alley, street, curb or sidewalk in the city, he shall first secure from the superintendent of the street department a permit authorizing him so to do. 
(Code 1964, § 22-1) 
Sec. 21-27. - Guards. 
    Every person making any excavation in the streets or alleys of the city shall establish and maintain suitable and effective guards around the same from the time the same is first made until it is restored to a condition of safety. Such guards shall have lighted red lights placed on all sides and at points of approach and they shall be maintained in a lighted condition throughout the night from one (1) hour before dark until one (1) hour after dark in the morning. Danger signals and caution signs shall be established around the same and shall be maintained throughout the day in sufficient number and places to apprise any person of the impending danger. 
(Code 1964, § 22-2) 
Sec. 21-28. - Repairing. 
    After the digging or cutting, authorized by a permit required by this article, the permit holder shall make the necessary repairs to restore the alley, street, curb or sidewalk to the same condition it was in prior to such digging or cutting. 
(Code 1964, § 22-3) 
Secs. 21-29-21-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MOVING OF BUILDINGS OR HEAVY MACHINERY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, ch. 23. 

Sec. 21-46. - Permit. 
(a)  No person shall move or cause to be moved, over or upon any of the streets of the city, any building, thrashing machine, ditching machine, traction engine or other heavy piece of machinery of an extreme or abnormal weight, without first making application to the City Manager or his or her designee and receiving a permit so to do. Such application and permit shall give all necessary details in connection with the desired removal, the date, and the exact time of day or night when such removal is to be made, a full description of the route to be traversed during such removal, the exact beginning and ending points, and the number, or some other particular identifying mark, of the building or piece of machinery to be moved. Such application and permit shall be on forms prescribed by the City Manager or his or her designee. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued under this section, unless in the judgment of the City Manager or his or her designee, it is deemed advisable and it is not likely that damage to public or private property will occur therefrom. 
(c)  A permit fee of $20.00 plus the state fee shall be charged for such permit, to be placed in the general fund of the city, and not more than one (1) building, machine or piece of machinery shall be described or more than one (1) route outlined in any permit. 
(d)  No permit issued under this section shall be valid if issued more than five (5) days prior to the time of making such removal. 
(e)  The permit required by this section shall be in addition to the permit required by the building code, if any, for the removal of a building. 
(Code 1964, § 22-4; Ord. No. 1640, § 1(B.), 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 21-47. - Designation and change of route. 
(a)  The superintendent of the street department shall have full authority to direct the route for making all removals of any building, machine or machinery for which a permit is required by this article. 
(b)  If some unforeseen difficulty should prevent the following of the route described in the permit, application shall be made to the superintendent and the permit corrected to show the description of the route desired to be traversed, before entering upon any part of the route not described in the original permit. 
(Code 1964, § 22-5) 
Sec. 21-48. - Protection of pavement. 
    If the wheels on any building, machine or piece of machinery to be removed under a permit required by this article have lugs or projections on the face thereof, or if they are insufficiently wide to prevent the marring or the causing of damage to any of the streets, alleys or other public grounds along the route to be traversed, a good and sufficient plank flooring shall be laid so as to protect the pavement from any and all damage and from being marred by any such building or machinery. 
(Code 1964, § 22-6) 
Sec. 21-49. - Damage to pavement or other property. 
    All damage to any street pavement or other public property or to private property, incident to any removal, for which a permit is required by this article, shall be held as a lien or charge against the building, machine or machinery so removed as well as against the owner thereof, and such building, machine or machinery shall not be moved from the corporate limits of the city until all such damage shall have been fully satisfied. 
(Code 1964, § 22-7) 
Chapter 22 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Airport zoning ordinance, § 5-51 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; flood damage prevention, ch. 10; planning and development, ch. 18; zoning, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Subdivision regulations, 11 O.S. §§ 45-104, 46-104. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley shall mean a public or private way not more than thirty (30) feet wide affording only secondary means of access to abutting property. 
    Block shall mean an area of land within a subdivision, which area is entirely bounded by streets, highways, or ways, except alleys; or the exterior boundaries of the subdivision. 
    Board of public utilities shall mean the board of public utilities of the city. 
    Building setback line shall mean a line parallel to the street right-of-way, indicating the limit in front of which buildings or structures may not be erected. 
    Certificates shall mean and include the following: 
(1)  Certificate of county commission or board of commissioners acceptance of easements and dedications shall mean a statement certifying that the county commission or board of commissioners has accepted all public easements and dedications as shown on the plat. 
(2)  Certificate of planning commission approval shall mean a statement certifying that the plat was approved by the planning commission on a certain date and the approval is valid to a certain date. 
(3)  County treasurer's certificate shall mean a statement from the county treasurer certifying that no property taxes on the land were due and payable as of the date of certificate, which date shall be not more than seven (7) days in advance of the date of submittal of the final plat to the planning commission for approval. 
(4)  Engineer's or surveyor's certificate of survey shall mean a notarized statement certifying that the described survey of the plat is accurate and correct. 
(5)  Owner's certificate and dedication shall mean a notarized statement by the owners of the land being subdivided certifying that: 
a.  They are the sole owners, 
b.  All streets and alleys shown on the plat are dedicated to public uses, and 
c.  All easements for utilities and drainage are reserved as shown on the plat. 
    City planning commission shall mean the planning commission of the city. 
    Collector street shall mean a street which collects traffic from local streets and carries it to one (1) or more major thoroughfares, or to one (1) or more other collector streets. 
    Comprehensive plan shall mean the comprehensive plan of the planning area of the city. 
    County clerk shall mean the County Clerk of Ottawa County, Oklahoma. 
    County commission shall mean the board of county commissioners of the county. 
    County engineer shall mean the person so designated by the county commission. 
    Cul-de-sac shall mean a street having one (1) end open to an intersecting street and being terminated at the other end by a vehicular turnaround. 
    Easement shall mean a grant by a property owner to the public, a corporation, or person of the use of all or part of a parcel of land for specific purposes. 
    Final plat shall mean a map or chart of a land subdivision giving, in form suitable for filing in the office of the county clerk, necessary affidavits, dedications and acceptances, and containing a complete engineering description, including references to field markers sufficient to locate on the ground all streets, alleys, blocks, lots and other divisions of the subdivision. 
    Flood hazard area shall mean an area of special flood hazard, as delineated on a flood hazard boundary map. 
    Flood hazard boundary map shall mean an official map of the city or of the unincorporated areas of the county, issued by the federal insurance administration, where the areas within the boundaries of special flood hazards have been designated as Zone A. 
    Health department shall mean the county health department. 
    Improvements shall mean street grading and surfacing; curbs and gutters; sidewalks; water mains and lines; sanitary and storm sewers; culverts, bridges, and other utilities; and related items. 
    Inner area shall mean that part of the Miami regional district that is so identified on the map, Miami and Miami Regional District, section 22-3. 
    Local street shall mean a street intended primarily to provide access to abutting property and carrying little or no through traffic; ordinarily a street that is not a major thoroughfare or a collector street is a local street. 
    Lot shall mean a single tract of land located within a single block, which (at the time of filing for a building permit or a zoning clearance permit) is designated by its owner or developer as a tract to be used, developed, or built upon as a unit, under single ownership or control. Therefore, a lot may or may not coincide with a lot of record. 
    Lot-split shall mean a subdivision that involves the dividing or redividing of a lot into not more than three (3) parcels, and that does not involve the extension, opening, vacating, narrowing, or change of alignment of any thoroughfare, street alley, or easement. 
    Lot-split plat shall mean a plat describing a lot-split. 
    Lot splitting shall mean the action of creating a lot-split. 
    Major thoroughfare shall mean an existing or proposed street or highway identified as a major thoroughfare on the Miami Area Comprehensive Plan. 
    Miami regional district shall mean the area over which the Miami Regional Planning Commission has planning jurisdiction under 11 O.S. § 46-102. The regional district which shall be construed to mean any land outside the incorporated limits of any municipality whose any one (1) boundary, at any point, shall be within a distance of three (3) miles from the incorporated limits of the municipality. See map, Miami and Miami Regional District, section 22-3 hereof. 
    Outer area shall mean that part of the Miami regional district so identified on the Miami Regional District Map, section 22-3 hereof. 
    Planned unit development (PUD) shall mean a land development project comprehensively planned as an entity via a unitary site plan which permits flexibility in building siting, mixtures of housing types and land uses, usable open spaces, and the preservation of significant natural features. A residential PUD is limited to: 
(1)  Dwelling units without regard to: 
a.  Dwelling type, or 
b.  Whether unit ownership will be on the basis of fee ownership, cooperative apartments, condominiums, or otherwise; and 
(2)  Nonresidential uses of an educational, cultural, or recreational character that are designed and intended to serve the PUD residents. 
A general PUD contains office or commercial uses exclusively or blends residential uses with office or commercial uses in a unified plan. 
    Planning area shall mean the Miami planning area, which consists of the city and all unincorporated areas on the comprehensive plan map, except the areas lying outside the planning area boundary on sheets 72NE and 83SE. 
    Planning commissions shall mean the Miami City Planning Commission and the Miami Regional Planning Commission. The singular term "planning commission" means the city planning commission in the case of plats in the city and the regional planning commission in the case of plats in the regional district. 
    Planting screen easement shall mean a grant by the subdivider to the public of a strip of land along a property line for the sole purpose of planting and/or maintaining shrubs, plants, or trees, or the erection of a fence or wall. 
    Plat shall mean a division of land into lots, streets, and alleys by means of a representation on paper so that they can be identified. 
    Plat officer shall mean the person designated by the planning commissions to administer these regulations. One (1) person may serve in this capacity for areas both within and without the city, or the planning commissions may designate separate plat officers to serve the areas inside and outside of the city. 
    Preliminary plat shall mean a map or chart of a proposed land subdivision showing the character and general details of the proposed development and submitted to the appropriate planning commission for consideration and preliminary or conditional approval. 
    Public facility shall mean any type of public improvement, other than a public street or public utility, including, but not limited to, public schools, parks, playgrounds, fire stations, libraries, hospitals and airports. 
    Public improvement shall mean any drainage ditch, roadway, parkway, sidewalk, pedestrianway, tree, lawn, off-street parking area, lot improvement or other facility for which the local government may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation, or which may affect an improvement for which local government responsibility is established. All such improvements shall be properly bonded. 
    Public utility shall mean any utility owned or operated by a public or quasipublic agency, including, but not limited to, flood protection and drainage, sanitary sewerage, water supply and electrical distribution. 
    Standard subdivision improvement specifications shall mean the standard subdivision improvement specifications that are part of this chapter. 
    Sketch plat shall mean a plat of a proposed subdivision that indicates, in general, the area to be subdivided, the street layout, lots and blocks, and the general nature of improvements and which may be prepared in freehand, pencil form. 
    Street shall mean a public way from which the principal means of access to abutting property is obtained. (See also collector street, cul-de-sac, frontage road, local street, major thoroughfare.) 
    Subdivider shall mean any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity, acting as a unit, subdividing or proposing to subdivide land as herein defined. 
    Subdividing shall mean: 
(1)  In the case of land in the city, the dividing of land into two (2) or more lots, parcels, tracts or areas, any one (1) of which when divided has an area of less than ten (10) acres, or any dividing of land involving the vacating or dedicating of right-of-way or the alignment or width of an existing or proposed street or highway or public utility easement, or the resubdividing of land heretofore divided into lots, sites or parcels, whether such dividing or resubdividing is by means of a map or plat or metes-and-bounds description. 
(2)  In the case of land in the regional district, the dividing of land by means of a plan, plat or replat of land laid out in lots or blocks, and the streets, alleys or other portions of the same intended to be dedicated to public or private use. 
    Subdivision shall mean a tract of land that has been or is proposed to be subdivided. 
    Through lots shall mean interior lots that abut more than one (1) street. 
    Unplatted land shall mean land which is not described by a recorded plat. 
    Zoning ordinance shall mean the city zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-9.010-23-9.400), 6-18-79; Ord. No. 1483, § 1, 9-7-04) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-2. - Purpose and authority. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to further promote and secure the health, safety, and general welfare of the present and future citizens of Miami and the Miami Regional District; to help ensure coordinated, efficient, and economical development of the city and regional district and to provide general rules and regulations to platting control so that subdividers have a general indication of the standards applied in subdividing of land in the city and regional district; the following regulations are adopted, pursuant to the authority granted by the legislature of the State of Oklahoma in 11 O.S. §§ 45-104 and 46-104, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-1.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-3. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  This chapter shall apply to all forms of subdividing and lot-splitting and shall be applicable to all lands within the city and the Miami regional district. The regional district is divided into the inner area and the outer area; boundaries of the regional district and the inner and outer areas are shown on the Miami and Miami Regional District map, a copy of which may be found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  These subdivision regulations, exclusive of the standard subdivision improvement specifications, shall apply as follows: 
(1)  Lands within the city-fully applicable; 
(2)  Lands in the regional district (that is, the inner and outer area)-fully applicable, except that provision relating to the zoning ordinance or building permits shall not apply. 
(c)  The standard subdivision improvement specification shall apply to lands in the city, the inner area and the outer area, as provided in the specifications. 
(d)  The location of the line separating the inner area from the outer area may be revised from time to time by the regional planning commission. The plat officer shall thereupon revise accordingly the map, Miami and Regional District, maintained in his office and transmit a copy of the revised map to the county clerk. 
(e)  The location of the line separating the inner area from the outer area may be revised from time to time by the regional planning commission, subject to approval by the board of commissioners. The plat officer shall thereupon revise accordingly the map of Miami and Regional District maintained in his office and transmit a copy of the revised map to the county clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-1.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-4. - Appendices. 
    The appendices to Ord. No. 1123 are ratified and confirmed. 
Sec. 22-5. - Variances and exceptions. 
    Whenever the tract to be subdivided is of such unusual size or shape or is surrounded by such development or unusual condition that the strict application of the requirements contained in these regulations would result in real difficulties and substantial hardships or injustices, the planning commission may vary or modify such requirements so that the subdivider is allowed to develop his property in a reasonable manner, but so that, at the same time, the public welfare and interests of the city or county are protected and the general intent and spirit of these regulations are preserved. Such variances may be granted only by the affirmative vote of a majority of the planning commission members. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-6), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-6. - Rules authorized. 
    The planning commission may adopt rules for the administration of these regulations to the extent that such rules are not in conflict with these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-7.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-7. - Penalty for violations. 
    A violation of these regulations shall be punishable as provided by 11 O.S. §§ 45-104 and 46-104, or other appropriate statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-8.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-8. - Building permits. 
    No city building permit shall be issued for any new structure or any change, improvement or alteration of any existing structure on any tract of land that does not comply with all the provisions of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-8.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-9. - Dedication of park land or greenbelt areas. 
(a)  In addition to the regulations of the comprehensive plan hereinbefore or hereinafter adopted by the city, it shall further be required that, in subdividing land or resubdividing an existing plat, due consideration shall be given by the subdivider to the dedication or reservation of suitable sites for schools, parks, playgrounds, greenbelt areas or other public recreational areas or open spaces. Residential subdivisions shall dedicate a usable tract of land, as a common recreational area, greenbelt area or open space, according to the following schedule. 
(b)  The developer shall dedicate five percent (5%) of the total acres within each residential subdivision or development for use as open space or a park area with a minimum of one-half (1/2) acre. The acreage dedicated as park area must be suitable for that purpose. The subdivider or developer shall dedicate all such recreational areas to the city as a condition of final subdivision plat approval. 
(1)  The city council may require that the land to be dedicated for park and recreational purposes be located on the edge of the subdivision so that additional land may be added at a future date. 
(2)  Open space greenbelts or buffers depicted in the comprehensive plan shall be shown on the preliminary and final plat as open space buffers. Any such greenbelt or open space buffer depicted on the comprehensive plan shall be provided for by the subdivider of the property which when developed requires the buffering so as not to adversely affect adjacent property. 
(3)  Existing features which would add value to residential development or to the city as a whole, such as trees, watercourses, historic spots and similar irreplaceable assets, shall be preserved in the design of the subdivision. No trees shall be removed from any subdivision nor any change of grade of the land effected until approval of the preliminary plat has been granted. All trees on the plat required to be retained shall be reserved, and all trees where required, shall be welled and protected against change of grade. The preliminary plat shall show the number and location of existing trees as required by these regulations, and shall further indicate all those marked for retention. 
(4)  The requirements as set forth herein may be waived by the city upon application to the planning commission and the board of commissioners if, in the city's opinion, under the particular existing circumstances it is in the best interest of the public. 
(Code 1964, § 28-1) 
Sec. 22-10. - City planning commission. 
    The City Planning Commission shall consist of five (5) citizens, all of whom shall reside within the municipality. The members shall be nominated by the mayor and confirmed by the City Council. Each member shall serve for a term of three (3) years. Three members shall constitute a quorum. 
A.  The appointed members of the City Planning Commission shall serve ex officio as the members of the Board(s) of Adjustment established by the Code of Ordinances, and with concurrent terms. 
B.  The officers of the City Planning Commission each shall serve ex officio as the officers of the Board(s) of Adjustment, and with concurrent terms. 
C.  Joint meetings of the City Planning Commission and Board(s) of Adjustment are authorized for the efficient disposition of those matters subject to their respective jurisdictions. In the case of a joint meeting, the clerk shall designate on each substantive agenda item whether the particular subject matter is subject to the jurisdiction of the City Planning Commission or Board(s) of Adjustment. Further, the clerk shall accurately indicate on the minutes of each joint meeting that the appropriate public body provided consideration, discussion, motion(s), and disposition of each agenda item. 
(Ord. No. 1341, § 1, 1-15-96; Ord. No. 1642, § 1(A.), 7-7-2015) 
Secs. 22-11-22-35. - Reserved.

Sec. 22-38. - Fees. 
    At the time of submitting each of the respective plats to the plat officer, or other designated agent, the following fees shall be payable to the city clerk: 
(1)  Preliminary plat fee ..... $ 20.00 
(2)  Final plat fee ..... 20.00 
Or $1.00 per lot plus $10.00, whichever is larger. 
(3)  Lot-split plat fee as follows: 
a.  Lot-splits that meet all the requirements of the subdivision regulation and zoning ordinance as submitted ..... 4.00 
b.  Lot-splits that require only a waiver of subdivision regulations, subject to action by the board of adjustment on a minor variance, in accordance with the adopted policies of the board of adjustment ..... 6.00 
c.  Lot-splits that require the waiver of subdivision regulations, other than a minor variance, or a combination thereof ..... 15.00 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-3.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-39. - Coordination of flexible zoning applications with subdivision approval-Intent; plans. 
    It is the intent of these regulations that subdivision review be carried out simultaneously with the review of flexible zoning applications under the zoning ordinance. The plans required for flexible zoning applications shall be submitted in a form to satisfy the requirements of the subdivision regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.3.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-40. - Same-General requirement. 
    Whenever the zoning ordinance authorizes flexible zoning applications that permit uses of land and density of buildings and structures different from those that are allowed as of right within the zoning district in which the land is situated and such an application entails subdividing, then subdivision approval of the flexible zoning application shall be required by the planning commission in addition to all other procedures and approvals required in the zoning ordinance, whether or not such zoning procedures also require planning commission approval, review or recommendation. Flexible zoning applications shall include, but not be limited to, all dwelling groups, planned unit development and special zoning permits. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.3.2), 6-18-79) 
Secs. 22-41-22-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PLATS 

Sec. 22-56. - Generally. 
(a)  For all cases of subdividing within the scope of these regulations, the subdivider shall submit to the appropriate planning commission a sketch plat, preliminary plat and final plat in accordance with specifications set forth in these regulations. 
(b)  Each plat submitted for preliminary or final approval shall be placed on the planning commission's agenda only after fulfilling the appropriate requirements of these regulations. However, a plat not meeting all the requirements may be submitted, provided that the subdivider presents with the plat a letter requesting specific exceptions and presenting in detail the reasons therefor. Final plats shall also comply with 11 O.S. § 41-101 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-57. - Sketch plat. 
    The sketch plat, including all the information specified in sections 22-36 and 22-37, shall be presented to the plat officer at least seven (7) days prior to the meeting at which consideration is requested. The plat officer shall enter the date of the receipt of the plat. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-58. - Preliminary plat-Procedure. 
(a)  Upon approval of the sketch plat by the planning commission, the subdivider may proceed with the preparation of a preliminary plat, which shall include all the information specified for a preliminary plat in sections 22-36 and 22-37. 
(b)  After the subdivider has prepared the preliminary plat, he may take either of the following actions: 
(1)  Present the preliminary plat and preliminary plat checklist (see Appendix A) to the planning commission and obtain approval thereof before proceeding with the preparation of the improvement plans, or 
(2)  Present the improvement plans to the planning commission at the time the preliminary plat and preliminary plat checklist are presented. 
(c)  All documents relating to the preliminary plat shall be presented to the plat officer at least fifteen (15) days prior to the meeting at which initial consideration of such documents is requested. The plat officer shall enter the date of receipt on the material submitted. 
(d)  Upon receipt of a preliminary plat, the plat officer shall notify by mail all owners of adjacent unplatted land and all owners of adjacent platted lots that are two hundred fifty (250) feet or more in width and have a common boundary of at least fifty (50) feet with the land being platted, as such owners are listed on such plat. Such owners shall have ten (10) days from the date the notification is mailed within which to notify the planning commission of any protests they may have concerning the proposed subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.3(a)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-59. - Same-Reservation of land for public facilities or public utilities. 
    Whenever a subdivider proposes to subdivide land that includes, or appears to include, all or part of the proposed site for a public facility or public utility as designated in the Miami Area Comprehensive Plan, the planning commission shall, before approving the preliminary plat of the subdivision, promptly submit the plat to the public body responsible for acquiring the land for the site. If the public body determines that the site for the public facility or public utility should be located within the boundaries of the proposed subdivision, the planning commission may require the subdivider to reserve for public acquisition such land and shall designate the boundaries of such land. Such reservation shall be for a period to be determined by the planning commission, but shall not be for a period of more than six (6) months from the date of submittal of the preliminary plat. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.3(b)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-60. - Same-Planning commission action. 
(a)  When subdivider presents both preliminary plat and improvement plans. Whenever the subdivider presents to the planning commission the preliminary plat, preliminary plat checklist, and improvement plans, and the planning commission finds that the plat meets all the requirements of these regulations, it shall approve the preliminary plat by placing a stamp of approval on each copy of such plat. Such stamp shall bear the signature of the chairman and secretary of the planning commission and shall provide that the approval given thereby does not constitute approval for purposes of recording. 
(b)  When subdivider presents only the preliminary plat. Whenever the subdivider presents to the planning commission a preliminary plat and preliminary plat checklist, without improvement plans, the planning commission may conditionally approve the preliminary plat, subject to approval of the improvement plans, as provided in the Standard Subdivision Improvement Specifications, within ninety (90) days following the preliminary plat approval. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.3(c)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-61. - Same-Planning commission action. 
(a)  Time limit. The planning commission shall approve, approve conditionally or disapprove such preliminary plat within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt thereof. 
(b)  Notification. If the preliminary plat be disapproved or approved conditionally by the planning commission, the reasons for such action shall be stated in writing, a copy of which shall be attached to one (1) copy of the plat and returned to the subdivider. If no action be taken by the planning commission within the stated time, the plat shall be deemed to have been approved. 
(c)  Reasons for disapproval, conditional approval. The reasons for disapproval or conditional approval by the planning commission shall refer specifically to those parts of these regulations or the comprehensive plan with which the plat does not conform. On conditionally approving a plat, the planning commission may require submission of a revised preliminary plat. 
(d)  Copies. Three (3) copies of the approved or conditionally approved plat shall be transmitted to the plat officer, one (1) copy of which shall be filed in his office. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.3), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-62. - Same-Authorization to prepare final plat. 
    Receipt of a preliminary plat and improvement plans, both of which have been approved or conditionally approved as provided herein, shall constitute authorization of the planning commission for the subdivider to proceed with the preparation of the final plat. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.3(f)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-63. - Same-Completion of improvements. 
    After planning commission approval or conditional approval of the preliminary plat and approval of the improvement plans, and prior to submitting the final plat to the planning commission, the subdivider shall meet the requirements of article IV relative to subdivision improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.3(g)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-64. - Final plat-Submittal of plat. 
    The subdivider shall submit the final plat to the plat officer at least fifteen (15) days prior to the planning commission meeting at which consideration of the plat is requested. The plat officer shall enter the date of receipt on the material submitted. The final plat shall include all the information specified for final plats in sections 22-36 and 22-37. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.4(a)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-65. - Same-Approval by the planning commission. 
(a)  The planning commission shall approve, approve conditionally, or disapprove the final plat within forty-five (45) days from the date of receipt thereof. Planning commission approval of the final plat shall be obtained before the plat may be recorded by the county clerk. The planning commission's approval of the final plat shall be contingent upon their receipt, in accordance with section 22-189, of evidence that the improvements specified in the approved improvement plans have been made. 
(b)  Where the final plat includes the dedication of any public street or easement, the planning commission shall not approve the final plat unless and until the public dedications and the required improvements or a surety bond therefor have been accepted by resolution by the board of commissioners or county commission, as the case may be, and such acceptance evidenced on the plat. In the case of dedication of land to the public, the acceptance of such dedication shall be by the governing body of the appropriate public agency. 
(c)  After approval of the final plat by the planning commission, the subdivider may present the plat to the county clerk for recording. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.4(b)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-66. - Same-Time limit on submission. 
    The final plat of the proposed subdivision shall be submitted to the planning commission for final approval within one (1) year of the date on which the preliminary plat was approved by the planning commission. If not submitted for final approval within such time, the preliminary plat shall be considered as having been abandoned, unless the planning commission agrees to an extension of time, each such extension to be for a stated period not to exceed six (6) months. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.4), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-67. - Same-Approval for portion of subdivision. 
    If the subdivider requests permission to develop only a portion of the property for which the preliminary plat was approved, the planning commission may approve a final plat for such portion alone. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.4(d)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-68. - Same-Notification. 
(a)  If the final plat be disapproved by the planning commission, grounds for this refusal shall be stated in writing, a copy of which shall be sent to the subdivider, together with tracings and prints. 
(b)  After planning commission approval of the final plat, the original tracing and one (1) copy of such plat shall be sent to the subdivider and three (3) copies to the plat officer. One (1) copy of such plat shall be filed in the office of the plat officer. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.4(e)), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-69. - Same-Time limit on filing. 
    The final plat shall be filed in the office of the county clerk within six (6) months after approval by the planning commission. The planning commission stamp of approval upon the face of the final plat shall give the expiration date of the planning commission approval. If the final plat is not filed within such time, such approval shall be void. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.1.4(f)), 6-18-79) 
Secs. 22-70-22-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LOT-SPLITS 

Sec. 22-86. - Approval by plat officer. 
    The planning commission may empower the plat officer to approve by endorsement, on behalf of the planning commission, lot-split plats that meet all of the requirements for lot-split plats as set forth in these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.2.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-87. - Referral to planning commission. 
    Whenever a subdivider desires to create a lot-split, he shall present the lot-split plat to the plat officer for approval or disapproval. If the plat officer disapproves the lot-split plat because such plat does not meet all the requirements set forth in these regulations for lot-split plats, the plat officer shall refer the lot-split plat to the planning commission for consideration. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.2.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-88. - Report to planning commission. 
    All lot-split plats approved by the plat officer shall be reported to the planning commission at its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.2.3), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-89. - Distribution. 
    After the plat officer or planning commission approval of the lot-split plat, one (1) copy shall be transmitted to the applicant and three (3) copies shall be transmitted to, or retained by, the plat officer. One (1) copy of the plat shall be filed in the office of the plat officer. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-2.2.4), 6-18-79) 
Secs. 22-90-22-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-116. - Flood hazard areas. 
    The location, alteration or use of any structure or land in a flood hazard area is subject to the granting of a development permit as follows: 
(1)  In the city by the city engineer in accordance with the regulations set forth in chapter 10. 
(2)  In the regional district by the county engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-117. - Alleys. 
(a)  Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts, except where it has been determined by the planning commission that other definite and assured provisions have been made for service access, such as off-street loading and unloading. 
(b)  Where required, alleys shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  All alleys shall have a minimum right-of-way width of twenty (20) feet. 
(2)  Dead ends and sharp changes in alignment shall be avoided. 
(3)  T- and L-shaped alleys shall have a radius of not less than ten (10) feet at the point of intersection. The planning commission may permit comparable cutoffs or chords in lieu of rounded corners. 
(4)  All alleys shall be opened and graded to a grade approved by the plat officer. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.3), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-118. - Blocks-Width. 
    Blocks shall be two (2) tiers of lots in width, except where it is necessary to provide only one (1) tier of lots in order to overcome unusual topography or other physical conditions. Where a single tier of lots is permitted, the planning commission may require a planting screen easement along the rear lot lines. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.4.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-119. - Same-Length. 
    Blocks shall have a minimum length of three hundred (300) feet and a maximum length of one thousand three hundred (1,300) feet; measurements shall be between property lines and not between street centerlines. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.4.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-120. - Easements and dedications for public use generally. 
    No dedication for a street, other public use, or drainage easement shall be shown on a plat unless the board of commissioners or the county commission, as the case may be, determines to accept such dedication, and no utility easement shall be shown unless approved by the board of commissioners or the county commission. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.6.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-121. - Utility easements. 
    Where alleys are not provided or may not be used for that purpose, easements not less than seven and one-half (7.5) feet in width shall be provided at the rear of each lot for poles, wires, conduits, storm sewers, sanitary sewers, gas lines, water mains and lines and other such similar purposes. In no case shall any easement be less than fifteen (15) feet in total width. Additional easements shall be provided where required by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.6.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-122. - Drainage easements. 
    Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway, channel, stream or creek, the subdivider shall provide a stormwater easement or drainage right-of-way of sufficient width for such purpose and for maintenance, wherever the planning commission determines that such easement is desirable. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.6.3), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-123. - Conformance to official plans. 
    All subdivision plats shall conform to the comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.7), 6-18-79) 
Secs. 22-124-22-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREETS 

Sec. 22-141. - Conformance to the comprehensive plan. 
    All major thoroughfares shall conform to the area comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.2.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-142. - Relation to the existing street system. 
    All proposed streets shall connect to existing streets, unless the planning commission determines that such connections are undesirable. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.2.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-143. - Street alignment. 
    The radii of curvature shall not be less than the following number of feet: 
(1)  Major thoroughfares: 
a.  Collector streets ..... 150 
b.  All other major thoroughfares ..... 500 
(2)  Local streets ..... 100 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.2.3), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-144. - Street intersections. 
(a)  Angle of intersection. In general, streets shall be laid out to intersect one another at right angles, and a curve may be used in approaching an intersection to bring about this result. No street shall intersect another street at an angle of less than seventy-five (75) degrees. 
(b)  Minimum distance between intersections with a major thoroughfare. There shall be a minimum of six hundred (600) feet between intersections with a major thoroughfare having a planned right-of-way width of one hundred (100) feet or more. 
(c)  Property-line radius. Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a radius of ten (10) feet, or of greater radius where the planning commission may determine it necessary. The planning commission may permit comparable cutoffs or chords in lieu of rounded corners. 
(d)  Street jogs. Street jogs shall be avoided. There shall be a minimum of one hundred fifty (150) feet between the centerlines of street intersections. The planning commission may require that streets be connected by a curve or diagonal line in such manner that a smoother flow of traffic and the reduction of traffic hazards are assured. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.2.4), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-145. - Street right-of-way widths. 
(a)  Major thoroughfares shown in the comprehensive plan. Where an existing or proposed thoroughfare is shown as a major thoroughfare in the comprehensive plan, right-of-way widths shall be as shown in such plan, but no dedication shall be required in excess of sixty (60) feet on either side of the centerline thereof. In the case of a planned state highway on a new alignment, not on an existing right-of-way, no dedication shall be required. 
(b)  Culs-de-sac and loop streets. Culs-de-sac and loop streets that will intersect no other streets shall have a minimum right-of-way width of fifty (50) feet. 
(c)  Other local streets. All other local streets shall have a minimum right-of-way width of sixty (60) feet. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.2.5), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-146. - Culs-de-sac and dead-end streets. 
(a)  Length. Culs-de-sac and dead-end streets, designed to be so permanently, shall not exceed five hundred (500) feet in length. 
(b)  Turnaround. Culs-de-sac shall terminate in a turnaround with a property-line radius of not less than fifty (50) feet. 
(c)  Stub streets. In the case of dead-end streets that are stub streets designed to provide future connections with adjoining unsubdivided areas, the planning commission may require one (1) or more of the following: 
(1)  A temporary easement for a turnaround of the nature mentioned in subsection (a). 
(2)  A roadway at least twenty-six (26) feet in width, and not of excessive length, to connect the temporary dead-end street with an existing street. 
(3)  An appropriate area for a back-around. 
(d)  Provision of future street access to adjoining property. Wherever permanent culs-de-sac are not provided, the planning commission may require that dedication of street right-of-way be extended to the boundary of adjoining property in order to provide future street access to the adjoining property. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.2.6), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-147. - Access from the rear of through lots. 
    Where the planning commission deems it necessary to control access along a thoroughfare abutting on the rear lot lines of a single tier of lots, it may require the subdivider by appropriate instrument, deemed sufficient by the city or county attorney, as the case may be, to relinquish the right of access to the thoroughfare from the rear of such lots. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.2.7), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-148. - Private roadways. 
(a)  Election. The subdivider may elect to establish in the subdivision one (1) of the following: 
(1)  Private roadways, subject to subsection (b), 
(2)  Public streets, or 
(3)  A combination thereof. 
(b)  Election to establish private roadways. The subdivider may elect to establish private roadways in the subdivision under either or both of the following alternatives: 
(1)  Where the land proposed to be subdivided is more than one-fourth (1/4) mile from both sanitary sewerage facilities and water facilities furnished by a governmental entity, or 
(2)  Where the developer has elected to plan and develop the subdivision as a planned unit development (PUD). 
Where the subdivider elects to establish private roadways in the subdivision, such roadways shall comply with the standards of this division, unless the planning commission shall authorize a variance therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.2.8), 6-18-79) 
Secs. 22-149-22-165. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LOTS 

Sec. 22-166. - Lot dimensions. 
(a)  Inside the city, lot dimensions shall conform to the city zoning ordinance. 
(b)  Outside the city, lots shall not be required to be larger than eight thousand (8,000) square feet, unless a larger area is required by the health department to meet sanitary requirements. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.5.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-167. - Building setback lines. 
    Building setback lines shall comply with the city setback ordinance where such ordinance applies; in all other cases in the city, the building setback lines shall comply with zoning district yard regulations of the zoning district within which the subdivision is located. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.5.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-168. - Alignment of side lot lines. 
    Side lot lines shall be radial to street lines. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.5.3), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-169. - Lots with a private water supply or septic tank. 
    Each lot shall be served by an approved public or private water supply and sanitary sewer or septic tank. Where a lot is to be served by a private water supply or septic tank, such lot shall be of sufficient size to conform to the health department specifications and standards for septic tanks and individual water supply systems. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.5.4), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-170. - Large lots. 
    Whenever a parcel is proposed to be divided into lots containing twenty-five thousand (25,000) square feet or more, the dimensions and arrangements of lots, streets, and utility easements shall be such as to facilitate the future resubdividing of such lots. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-4.5.5), 6-18-79) 
Secs. 22-171-22-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 22-186. - Required generally. 
    The subdivider shall improve or agree to improve all streets, highways, alleys, or other ways and provide drainage improvements, all in such manner as is necessary for the general use of the lot owners in the subdivision and to meet local traffic and drainage needs, as a condition precedent to the approval of the final plat. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-5.1), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-187. - Types and extent of improvements required. 
    The improvements that the subdivider shall make, agree to make, or cause to be made prior to the approval of the final plat shall be as described by the Standard Subdivision Improvement Specifications. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-5.2), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-188. - Improvement plans. 
    Improvement plans shall be prepared and approved as provided in the Standard Subdivision Improvement Specifications. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-5.3), 6-18-79) 
Sec. 22-189. - Evidence that specifications have been met. 
(a)  As evidence that the Standard Subdivision Improvement Specifications have been met, the planning commission shall accept a letter from the appropriate engineer to the effect that either: 
(1)  All of the specifications have been met, or 
(2)  Adequate assurance, in the form of performance bond or otherwise, has been given that the specifications will be met, and 
(3)  If certain of the specifications have been waived or modified by the governing body, its reasons for this action. 
(b)  Such letters shall be accepted as follows for subdivisions in the indicated areas: 
(1)  City, from the city engineer. 
(2)  Inner area, from the city engineer or the county engineer. 
(3)  Outer area, from the county engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 1(23-5.4), 6-18-79) 
Chapter 23 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Transporting nonintoxicating beverages, § 13-119; transporting intoxicating beverages, § 13-120; eluding a police officer, § 13-221; nuisances, ch. 15; abandoned vehicles, § 15-66 et seq.; moving of buildings or heavy machinery, § 21-26 et seq.; vehicles for hire, ch. 25. 
State Law reference- Traffic generally, O.S. tit. 47; general powers of local authorities, 47 O.S. § 15-102. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, except where expressly provided to the contrary, or where the context requires a different meaning, the following words and phrases shall be deemed to have the following meanings: 
    Ancient vehicle shall mean a motor vehicle owned by a resident of this state, which is thirty (30) years of age or older, based upon the date of manufacture thereof, and which travels on highways of this state primarily incidental to historical or exhibition purposes only. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-101.1. 
    Authorized emergency vehicle shall mean vehicles of fire departments, ambulances, county sheriff vehicles and full-time commissioned deputies and police vehicles, including vehicles owned and operated by the United States Marshals Service, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, or by any local organization for civil defense as defined by 63 O.S. § 683.3. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-103. 
    Automobile shall mean every motor vehicle of the type constructed and used for the transportation of persons for purposes other than for hire or compensation. This shall include all vehicles of the station wagon type whether the same are called station wagons, or ranch wagons, van wagons, except those used for commercial purposes, suburbans, town and country, or by any other name, except when owned and used as a school bus or motor bus by a school district or a religious corporation or society as elsewhere provided by law. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-103.1. 
    Bicycle shall mean every device propelled by human power which any person may ride, having two (2) tandem wheels, either of which is over twenty (20) inches in diameter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-104. 
    Bus shall mean every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than ten (10) passengers and used for the transportation of persons; and every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-105. 
    Business district shall mean the territory contiguous to and including a street when, within any six hundred (600) feet along such street, there are buildings in use for business or industrial purposes, including but not limited to hotels, banks, office buildings, railroad stations and public buildings, which occupy at least three hundred (300) feet of frontage on one (1) side, or three hundred (300) feet collectively on both sides of the street. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-106. 
    Congested district shall mean all that part of the city defined and described as follows: Main Street, from the north line of Second Avenue North unto the south line of Second Avenue South; and Central Avenue, from the west line of A Street West to the east line of A Street East. 
    Controlled-access highway shall mean every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street or roadway. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-110. 
    Crosswalk shall mean that part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connection of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the street measured from the curbs or, in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway or any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-111. 
    Curb shall mean the boundary lines of the roadway portion of a street, whether curbstones are located at such boundaries or not. 
    Double parking shall mean the standing of a vehicle upon a street alongside of another vehicle which is parked at the curb. 
    Driver shall mean every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-113. 
    Highway or street shall mean the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. The words "highway" and "street" are synonymous. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. §§ 1-122, 1-171. 
    Implement of husbandry shall mean every vehicle designed and adapted exclusively for agricultural, horticultural or livestock raising operations or for lifting or carrying an implement of husbandry and in either case not subject to registration if used upon the highways. Farm wagon type tank trailers of not over one-thousand-two-hundred-gallon capacity, used during the liquid fertilizer season as field storage "nurse tanks" supplying the fertilizer to a field applicator and moved on highways only for bringing the fertilizer from a local source of supply to farms or fields or from one (1) farm or field to another, shall be considered implements of husbandry for purposes of this chapter. Trailers or semitrailers owned by a person engaged in the business of farming and used exclusively for the purpose of transporting farm products to market or for the purpose of transporting to the farm materials or things to be used thereon shall also be considered implements of husbandry for purposes of this chapter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-125. 
    Intersection shall mean the area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curblines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two (2) streets which join one (1) another at or approximately at right angles, or the area within which vehicles traveling upon different streets joining at any other angle may come in conflict. 
    Where a street includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, every crossing of each roadway of such divided street by an intersecting street shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event such intersecting street also includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, every crossing of two (2) roadways of such streets shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-126. 
    Laned street or roadway shall mean a roadway which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-127. 
    Limit lines shall mean lines painted or marked upon curbs, pavements or sidewalks to indicate directions and regulations to be observed by persons using the streets. 
    Motor vehicle shall mean every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails; the term shall exclude implements of husbandry. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-134. 
    Minibike shall mean any self-propelled vehicle or motor-driven cycle having less than an eight-inch wheel rim, or less than a forty-inch wheel base or less than a twenty-five-inch seat height. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-133.1. 
    Motorcycle shall mean every motor vehicle having a seat or saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor or a motorized bicycle. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-135. 
    Motor-driven cycle shall mean every motorcycle, including every motor scooter, equipped with a motor which produces not to exceed five-brake horsepower at full throttle without a governor as determined by a dynamometer test and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-136. 
    Motorized bicycle shall mean every vehicle having fully operative pedals for propulsion by human power, an automatic transmission and a motor with a cylinder capacity not exceeding fifty (50) cubic centimeters, which produces no more than two-brake horsepower, and is capable of propelling the vehicle at a maximum design speed of not more than thirty (30) miles per hour on level ground. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-136.1. 
    Official traffic-control devices shall mean all signs, barricades, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-139. 
    Park or parking, when prohibited, shall mean the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-142(a). 
    Pedestrian shall mean any person afoot. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-143. 
    Police officer shall mean every officer of the police department and any other officer who is authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of state traffic laws or traffic ordinances. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-147. 
    Private road or driveway shall mean every way or place in private ownership and used for vehicular travel by the owner and those having express or implied permission from the owner, but not by other persons. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-148. 
    Railroad shall mean a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-149. 
    Railroad sign or signal shall mean any sign, signal or device erected by authority of a public body or official or by a railroad and intended to give notice of the presence of railroad tracks or the approach of a railroad train. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-150. 
    Railroad train shall mean a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except streetcars. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-151. 
    Resident district shall mean the territory contiguous to and including a highway not comprising a business district when the property on such highway for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is in the main improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-154. 
    Right-of-way shall mean the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-156. 
    Roadway shall mean that portion of a highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the shoulder. In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" as used herein refers to any such roadway separately but not to all such roadways collectively. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-158(a). 
    Safety zone shall mean the area of space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or so marked or indicated by adequate signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-159. 
    School bus shall mean every motor vehicle owned by a public or governmental agency and operated for the transportation of children to or from school or privately owned and operated for compensation for the transportation of children to or from school, provided, however, that this definition of school bus shall not be extended to include buses normally used in city transit which may be used part time for transportation of school children within such cities during some portion of the day. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-160. 
    Shoulder shall mean the portion of the roadway contiguous with the traveled way for accommodation of stopped vehicles, for emergency use and for lateral support of base and surface courses. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-158(b). 
    Sidewalk shall mean that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-163. 
    Stand or standing shall mean the halting of a vehicle whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-167. 
    Stop, when required, shall mean complete cessation of movement. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-169. 
    Stop or stopping, when prohibited, shall mean any halting even momentarily of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic-control sign or signal. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-170. 
    Taxicab shall mean any motor vehicle for hire, designed to carry seven (7) persons or less, operated upon any street or highway, or on call or demand, accepting or soliciting passengers indiscriminately for transportation for hire between such points along streets or highways as may be directed by the passengers so being transported; but this classification shall not include motor vehicles of seven-passenger capacity or less operated by the owner where the cost of operation is shared by fellow workmen between their homes and the place of regular daily employment, when not operated for more than two (2) trips per day, nor shall the classification include automobiles operated by the owner where the cost of operation is shared by the passengers on a "share the expense plan," nor shall this classification include motor vehicles transporting students from the public school system when said motor vehicle is so transporting under contract with public, private or parochial school board or governing body. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-174. 
    Traffic shall mean pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles and other conveyances either singly or together while using any highway for purposes of travel. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-177. 
    Traffic-control signal shall mean any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-178. 
    Through highway shall mean every highway or portion thereof on which vehicle traffic is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield right-of-way to vehicles on such through highway in obedience to either a stop sign or a yield sign, when such signs are erected as provided in this chapter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-175. 
    Traffic lane shall mean the portion of the traveled way for the movement of a single line of vehicles. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-179. 
    Truck shall mean every motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-182. 
    Urban district shall mean the territory contiguous to and including any street which is built up with structures devoted to business, industry or dwelling houses situated at intervals of less than one hundred (100) feet for a distance of a quarter of a mile or more. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-185. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks; provided, however, the definition of vehicle as used in this chapter shall not include implements of husbandry. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 1-186. 
(Code 1964, § 26-1) 
Sec. 23-2. - Application of chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter relating to the operation of vehicles refer exclusively to the operation of vehicles upon the highways except: 
(1)  Where a different place is specifically referred to in a given section. 
(2)  The provisions of article III and article IV, division 2 of this chapter shall apply upon highways and public parking lots throughout the city. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-101. 
Sec. 23-3. - Compliance. 
    It is an offense for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this chapter. Every person using the streets and highways of the city shall comply with, observe and obey, when applicable to him, all regulations and orders issued in pursuance of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 26-16) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-102. 
Sec. 23-4. - Obedience to police and fire department officials. 
    No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a police officer or fire department official. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-103. 
Sec. 23-5. - Persons riding animals or driving animal-drawn vehicles to obey traffic regulations. 
    Every person riding an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1964, § 26-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-104. 
Sec. 23-6. - Public officers and employees to obey traffic regulations. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States government, any state, county, city or other governmental unit or agency, as well as to other vehicles. It is unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or by state statute. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 16-103; exemption for military convoys, 47 O.S. § 11-107. 
Sec. 23-7. - Application of chapter to persons working on streets. 
    Unless specifically made applicable, the provisions of this chapter, except those relating to reckless driving and driving while intoxicated, shall not apply to persons, teams, motor vehicles and other equipment while actually engaged in work upon the surface of a street, or to persons, motor vehicles and other equipment while actually engaged in construction, maintenance or repair of public utilities; provided that all highway and public utility operations shall be protected by adequate warning signs, signals, devices or flagmen; but the provisions of this chapter shall apply to such persons and vehicles when traveling to or from such work. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-105. 
Sec. 23-8. - Application of chapter to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(a)  The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, except that such driver, when responding to an emergency call or when in pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law, or when responding to, but not upon returning from, a fire alarm, may exercise the privilege set forth in this section, but subject to the conditions herein stated. 
(b)  The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may: 
(1)  Park or stand irrespective of the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after slowing down as may be necessary for safe operation. 
(3)  Exceed the maximum speed limits, so long as he does not endanger life or property. 
(4)  Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in specified directions. 
(c)  The exemptions granted by subsection (b) shall apply only when the authorized emergency vehicle is making use of audible and visual signals meeting the requirements of 47 O.S. § 12-218, except that an authorized emergency vehicle operated as a police vehicle need not be equipped with or display a red light visible from the front of the vehicle. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not relieve the driver of any authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons, nor shall such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of his reckless disregard for the safety of others. 
(Code 1964, § 26-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-106. 
Sec. 23-9. - Permitting unauthorized minor to drive. 
(a)  No person shall cause or knowingly permit his child or ward under the age of sixteen (16) years to drive a motor vehicle upon any street or highway within the city when such minor is not authorized as stated in section 23-101. 
(b)  Any person who knowingly causes or permits his child or ward under the age of sixteen (16) years to drive a motor vehicle upon any street or highway within the city when such minor is not authorized shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 26-27.2) 
Sec. 23-10. - Presumptive operator. 
(a)  If any vehicle unoccupied by a licensed driver is found upon a street or roadway in violation of any provision of this Code or state statutes, or if any vehicle has been driven in violation of this Code or state statutes, then proof of the identity of the person in whose name such vehicle is registered pursuant to O.S. tit. 47 may be sufficient evidence that such person was responsible for such violation, in the absence of probative contrary evidence and if the city judge is so persuaded. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall limit the defenses to or evidence otherwise probative and admissible concerning such violation or responsibility therefore. 
(c)  The registered owner of such violation, if not the person responsible for such violation, shall upon request inform the city police or city attorney of the identity of the person responsible for such violation, if known. 
(Ord. No. 1330, § 1, 2-21-95) 
Sec. 23-11. - General duties of police department with respect to traffic. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce traffic regulations of the City of Miami and all the State of Oklahoma vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in the City of Miami, on the roadways, streets, alleys and highways within the corporate limits of the City of Miami, including upon the roadways, streets and highways that form the boundary line of the City of Miami pursuant to 47 O.S. § 15-101.1, as amended, to make arrests for traffic violations, to investigate accidents in accordance with the provisions of 47 O.S. § 10-101, as amended, to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with ordinance violations causing or contributing to such accidents, to cooperate with other officers of the city in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out those duties specially imposed upon such department by this chapter and by any other traffic ordinances of the City. 
(Ord. No. 1645, § 1, 10-6-2015) 
Secs. 23-12-23-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-26. - Enforcement of chapter; temporary traffic regulations. 
    The mayor, and under his instructions the police department, shall have power to enforce the provisions of this chapter and all regulations and rules relative to traffic on the public streets. Whenever, in the judgment of the mayor, it shall be advisable for the public safety or convenience to temporarily close any street, alley or parts of streets to vehicular traffic, or to vehicles of a particular description, or to divert traffic thereon, or to divert or direct the course of pedestrian travel, he shall have the power and authority to do so, and any violation of any rule or regulation so made shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 26-15) 
Sec. 23-27. - Authority of police officers to direct traffic. 
    Officers of the police department, or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with this chapter and other traffic laws, provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require, not withstanding the provisions of this chapter and other traffic laws. 
(Code 1964, § 26-2) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate traffic by means of police officers, 47 O.S. § 15-102(2). 
Sec. 23-28. - Authority of officers of fire department to direct traffic. 
    Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 26-3) 
Sec. 23-29. - Designation, marking of one-way streets and alleys. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized to cause any street or alley or section or portion thereof to be designated and maintained as a one-way street or alley and to designate the direction in which vehicles shall lawfully travel thereon, as may be authorized from time to time by the mayor and board of commissioners. Whenever any street or alley is so designated, the chief of police shall cause the same to be identified as a one-way street or alley by signs or markings painted on the surface of the street or alley or by clearly visible and uniform signs erected adjacent thereto, or both, which signs or markings shall indicate the designation of such street or alley as a one-way street or alley and the direction on which vehicles shall lawfully travel by arrows pointing in that direction. Such signs or markings shall be erected or painted at each entrance to the one-way street or alley and at each cross intersection and at such other points as may be deemed advisable by the chief of police. 
(Code 1964, § 26-37) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to designate one-way streets and require traffic to move in one specific direction thereon, 47 O.S. §§ 11-308, 15-102(a)(4); necessity of signs designating one-way streets, § 15-102(c). 
Secs. 23-30-23-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC-CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS, DEVICES AND MARKINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Traffic-control devices, 47 O.S. § 11-201 et seq.; authority to erect traffic-control signals, devices, etc., 47 O.S. §§ 15-102, 15-106. 

Sec. 23-46. - Conformity with manual and specifications of state highway commission.
