(Code 1964, § 26-95) 
State Law reference- Method of parking and authority of city to permit angle parking and left-hand parking on one-way streets, 47 O.S. § 11-1004. 
Sec. 23-272. - Parking in spaces designated for the handicapped. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or park a motor vehicle in any parking space on private property accessible to the public and where the public is invited that is designated and posted as a reserved area for parking of motor vehicles of a physically disabled person unless such vehicle is eligible for a detachable insignia or reflective insignia of a physically disabled person under the provisions of 47 O.S. § 15-112 and such insignia is displayed as provided in 47 O.S. § 15-112 or regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1007; municipal authority to provide special parking privileges for disabled persons, 47 O.S. § 15-111. 
Sec. 23-273. - Prohibited for certain purposes. 
(a)  The stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle upon any public street for the purpose of demonstrating, exhibiting or advertising such vehicle or a similar vehicle for sale, or for the purpose of demonstrating, exhibiting or advertising any article for sale, is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  The stopping, standing or parking of a vehicle upon any easement for the purpose of demonstrating, exhibiting, or advertising such vehicle or a similar vehicle for sale, is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1964, § 26-87; Ord. No. 1497, § 1, 3-20-06) 
Sec. 23-274. - Stopping to load or unload passengers or freight. 
    The regulations contained in this division relative to the parking of vehicles shall not apply to vehicles which stop for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or freight. When stopped for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or freight, vehicles may stop parallel to the right curb or, in case of one-way streets, to the left curb, providing there is no vehicle parked or standing at the curb at such point. Vehicles may also stop for the purpose of unloading or loading passengers or freight at all places in the city where parking is prohibited, with the following exceptions and limitations: 
(1)  No vehicle of any character shall stop for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or freight within fifteen (15) feet of any fire hydrant, or within sixty (60) feet of the intersecting street on the side of any street where buses stop for the purpose of discharging and receiving passengers, when a bus is stopped at such place for such purpose. 
(2)  When taking up or discharging passengers or freight, vehicles shall be headed in the direction of the movement of traffic, and shall stop only at the right curb or, in case of one-way streets, at the left curb. 
(3)  In all cases where it is possible, freight, coal and ice shall be unloaded from the curb side and not from the rear of the vehicle, and the vehicle shall not back to the curb, but shall stand parallel thereto and be drawn in close to the curb. 
(4)  No vehicle shall remain upon any street within the congested district for the purpose of receiving or discharging freight or merchandise between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. where there is a public alley upon the premises where such freight or merchandise is being delivered or received, or where such premises are connected with such alley. 
(5)  All vehicles of every character, which stop for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or freight, shall stop only long enough to load or unload its passengers or freight, and then immediately move on. 
(Code 1964, § 26-92) 
Sec. 23-275. - Parking in prohibited areas; overtime parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, let, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name or owned or operated by him or in his possession or under his control to be or remain in any prohibited parking area designated and marked according to the provisions of section 23-58, or in a time limit parking area for a longer period of time than that designated by the markings on the street or by clearly visible signs. 
(Code 1964, § 26-94) 
Sec. 23-276. - Parking in alleys. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a passenger motor vehicle, except for the purpose of loading and unloading, in the alleys between Main Street and A Street, east and west, from the Northeast Oklahoma Railroad Tracks south to Third Avenue Southwest and Third Avenue Southeast. 
(b)  Vehicles parked in public alleys, where such parking is permitted, shall be parked parallel to the property line, with both right wheels not farther than twelve (12) inches from the property line and both right wheels parallel to the property line. No vehicle shall be parked or left standing in any public alley in such a place as to obstruct or prevent the free passage of other vehicles through such alley. 
(Code 1964, § 26-96) 
Sec. 23-277. - Trucks and other large vehicles not to park on certain streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating or in charge of any motor vehicle, motor van, motor bus or any other vehicle of any character, the total length of which exceeds sixteen (16) feet and eight (8) inches, or any motor vehicle or other vehicle the width of which, at its widest point, exceeds six (6) feet, to park such vehicle on any street within a business district, except where vehicles are required to park parallel to the curbline. Nothing herein contained shall be construed as prohibiting any such vehicle from stopping on any such street for a sufficient length of time to load or unload passengers or freight in accord with the provisions of section 23-274. 
(Code 1964, § 26-97) 
Sec. 23-278. - Parking or remaining on public or private property. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to remain on or park any vehicle (which for the purposes of this section shall include, but not be limited to any device used for transportation) on any public or private property in violation of any posted notice as defined in the following subsection. Any violation of this section shall be considered a violation of the traffic ordinances of the city, and shall constitute a trespass as defined herein and shall be punishable as hereinafter set forth. 
(b)  Notice. Before any person shall be guilty of a violation of the preceding subsection, the property in question must be posted in a clearly visible manner with a notice which indicates the hours that such property is opened to the public and further a statement that a trespass at any other time is prohibited. Upon the posting of the notice as required herein, the owner of the property posting such notice is authorizing the city to act as the owner's agent for the enforcement of such notice, the same as if the property was owned and controlled by the city. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall receive a citation for parking or remaining on closed property, either in person or by affixing the same to the vehicle found on such property if the owner or operator shall not be immediately ascertainable, and shall be guilty of an offense. If the citation issued hereunder shall not be personally delivered but is affixed to a vehicle, the registered owner of such vehicle shall be responsible for allowing such vehicle to remain on such property in violation of posted notice. 
(d)  Definitions. The following words shall, for the purposes of this section, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
(1)  Trespass shall mean a trespass with a vehicle. Trespass shall further be defined as follows: 
a.  Each and every actual entry upon the premises of another person's real property, public or private, without the owner's or occupant's consent thereof, whether expressed or implied, if such property has a notice posted, giving times and prohibiting the trespass during certain hours. 
b.  Each and every entry in or upon such public or private posted property, except at times and upon conditions when the same is subject to public use. 
c.  Remaining upon the premises of another, whether public or private, and refusing to leave such premises forthwith, after demand by owner or occupant, either in person or by posted notice. 
d.  This definition shall not apply to persons, including employees whose presence upon such premises is authorized by the owner, or by a person in lawful possession of such premises; any person alleged to be guilty of violating this section shall have the responsibility of showing evidence that they are authorized to be on such property in violation of any posted notice; nor shall the provisions of this section apply unless hours of business operation are posted upon such premises. Trespass shall also be defined as the act of returning to private property before the posted time of opening for business operation on the next business day after having been directed to vacate such premises under the terms of this section. 
(2)  Vehicle shall mean any device used for the transportation from one (1) place to another of a person or persons. 
(Code 1964, § 26-100) 
State Law reference- Parking of vehicles on posted private property, 47 O.S. § 11-1006. 
Sec. 23-279. - Grounds for towing of vehicles from roadway; towing rotation log. 
(a)  Any peace officer of the Miami Police Department shall be authorized to cause to be towed any vehicle found upon a roadway within the city limits in such manner, and subject to such terms, as provided by Oklahoma state law and municipal ordinances. Further such officer has authority to cause a vehicle to be towed at the sole expense of the owner thereof immediately if: 
(1)  The person driving or in control of a motor vehicle is arrested or otherwise taken into law enforcement custody; or 
(2)  At the scene of an accident, when the owner or driver is not in a position to take charge of his vehicle and direct or request its proper removal; or 
(3)  If the officer has reasonable cause to believe that a vehicle is in a location which would be hazardous to the free flow of traffic or be highly susceptible to damage from vandalism or other harm. 
(b)  The city manager or his or her designee may temporarily close a public parking area for purposes of maintenance, repair, construction, and special events. 
(1)  Whenever reasonably possible, the city manager or his or her designee shall post a notice of temporary closure at or upon the affected public parking area at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the temporary closure thereof. When it is not reasonably possible to post such notice at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance, the city manager or his or her designee shall post such notice as soon as reasonably possible, but not less than the otherwise lawful duration of parking plus one (1) hour except in the case of emergency. 
(2)  If a vehicle is stopped or parked upon such public parking area at the time it is posted as provided by subsection (b)(1), above, then the city manager or his or her designee shall place an adhesive-backed notice upon the vehicle which states the purpose of the temporary closure, the date and time it shall take effect, the date and time it shall expire, and a statement that a parked or standing vehicle during the period of temporary closure shall constitute a trespass and that any vehicles which are parked upon the affected public parking area after the date and time of the temporary closure are subject to removal by the city at the expense of the owner thereof. The city manager or his or her designee shall have no duty to place this notice upon any additional vehicle which may subsequently stop, stand or park on the affected public parking area after the initial posting. 
(3)  Any vehicle which remains stopped, standing or parked upon the affected public parking area during the temporary closure thereof may be removed at the direction of a peace officer of the Miami Police Department at the sole expense of the owner thereof. Further, such act shall be punishable as provided by section 23-278 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(4)  In the case of an emergency directly affecting life or property in which the removal of the vehicle is reasonably necessary to address the emergency situation, a peace officer of the Miami Police Department may cause the removal of otherwise lawfully parked vehicles at the expense of the city. In such case the city shall take reasonable steps to notify the owner thereof. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, all licensed wrecker services located within the city limits shall be placed upon a towing rotation log, which shall be maintained by the Miami Police Department and utilized to insure, as nearly as possible, that wrecker services are requested on an impartial basis. All licensed wrecker services located outside the city limits may petition for inclusion upon the towing rotation log to the city council, who shall determine their eligibility for inclusion upon the towing rotation log after receiving recommendations from the city manager and chief of police. The towing rotation log shall be used in instances involving an arrest, accident or temporary closure of a public parking area as described herein. In instances involving a stolen or abandoned car, the owner shall, if at all possible based upon the circumstances of the particular situation, be allowed to choose the means and method by which the vehicle shall be retrieved. 
(Ord. No. 1430, § 1, 8-20-01; Ord. No. 1589, § 1, 9-4-12) 
Sec. 23-280. - Fire safety lanes. 
(a)  Fire lanes on public and private property. 
(1)  General. Fire access roads, hereinafter known as fire lanes, shall be provided and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section. Fire lanes may be required at industrial and commercial properties and at multi-story residential properties at the discretion of the fire chief, or his designee. 
(2)  Fire chief's designee. The fire chief, or acting fire chief, may appoint a designee to implement and enforce the requirements of this section. If the occupant or owner of a building wants to establish fire lanes at his/her property, a request shall be made to the fire chief or his designee for consideration and possible approval. 
(3)  Requests for fire lanes. The occupant or owner of a building may request a review by the fire chief to add the necessary fire lanes if needed. 
(4)  Fire lane markings. Fire lanes shall be designated on all sides by painted curbs and stripes, said curbs and striping to be red in color, and by signs of design, shape and wording approved by the fire chief, or his designee. The words "NO PARKING FIRE LANE" shall appear in four-inch white letters at intervals of no less than every twenty-five (25) feet within the red border markings on both sides of the fire lane. Curbs shall be painted red to the top seam of the curb to a point even with the driving surface and lettered in the same manner as the flat surface. 
(5)  Width. Fire lanes shall be a minimum of twenty (20) feet in width and with an overhead clearance of no less than fourteen (14) feet. 
(6)  Surface. Fire lanes shall be surfaced so as to provide all-weather access with an asphalt or concrete surface sufficient to support fire equipment. 
(7)  Exceptions. Where a building, facility, or structure might have an unusual building design, topography, waterway, non-negotiable or difficult to negotiate grades or other similar conditions the fire chief, or his designee, may require additional fire lanes or fire protection systems. Clearances or widths required by this section may be increased when the fire chief, or his designee, determines that minimum clearances or widths are not adequate to provide fire apparatus access. The fire chief, or his designee, may make other exceptions for good cause and at his discretion. 
(b)  Enforcement. The fire department and police department shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To enforce parking regulations in those areas properly marked and designated as a fire lane. 
(2)  To issue citations for vehicles improperly parked in fire lanes. The citation shall contain the time, date, vehicle tag number, make, year and color of the vehicle. The citation shall be conspicuously placed upon the vehicle. The citation shall be on a form provided by the city. 
(c)  Fines and towing. 
(1)  The fine for improperly parking in a fire safety lane shall be $100.00 plus related court costs. 
(2)  Vehicles improperly parked in fire safety lanes may also be immediately towed with all costs of towing to be paid by the owner of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1506, § 1, 11-6-06) 
Secs. 23-281-23-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING METERS 

Sec. 23-296. - Definition. 
    The word "vehicle," as used in this division, shall mean any device by which any person or property may be transported upon a street, except those operated upon rails or tracks. 
(Code 1964, § 26-104) 
Sec. 23-297. - Meter zones established. 
    Parking meter zones are hereby established on such streets or parts of streets as are designated from time to time by the mayor and board of commissioners. 
(Code 1964, § 26-105) 
Sec. 23-298. - Installation; maintenance and mechanical requirements. 
    The mayor and city clerk shall provide for the installation of parking meters, including curb or street marking lines, in the parking meter zones, and the regulation and operation thereof, and they shall cause such meters to be maintained in good workable condition. Meters shall be placed upon the curb next to individual parking places and meters shall be so constructed as to display a signal showing legal parking upon deposit therein of the proper coins, as indicated by instructions on the meter, and for a period of time as provided in this division, such signal to remain in evidence until expiration of the parking period designated, at which time a change of signal or some other mechanical operation shall indicate expiration of the parking period. 
(Code 1964, § 26-107) 
Sec. 23-299. - Manner of parking in meter zones. 
    Every vehicle parked within any parking meter zone shall be parked entirely within the lines or markings designating a particular parking space in the zone. It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in such manner that is not entirely within such lines or markings. 
(Code 1964, § 26-108) 
Sec. 23-300. - Time limit for parking and required coin deposit. 
(a)  The mayor and board of commissioners shall establish the time limit for parking in the parking meter zones and the amount of deposit required to be made in the parking meters therein, which shall be indicated on the meters or on signs erected in the zones. 
(b)  When any vehicle is parked next to a parking meter, the driver or owner thereof, upon entering the parking space, shall immediately deposit in the meter the coins indicated on the meter as required for the particular parking space. Such parking space may then be used by such vehicle for the length of time purchased by such deposit, but not beyond the time limit established for the space and indicated on the meter or by appropriate signs. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or driver to fail to deposit the coins as required by subsection (b). Also, any vehicle shall be considered as unlawfully parked if it remains in any space within a parking meter zone beyond the time limit established therefor or when the parking meter for such space displays a signal showing that the time has expired. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit any vehicle registered in his name to be unlawfully parked as set out in this subsection. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall be in force and effect on such days and during such hours as designated by the mayor and board of commissioners. 
(Code 1964, § 26-109) 
Sec. 23-301. - Deposit of coin to extend maximum time limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited in a parking meter any coin for the purpose of extending the parking time beyond the maximum time limit fixed for the parking space by the mayor and board of commissioners. 
(Code 1964, § 26-110) 
Sec. 23-302. - Purpose of deposit requirement. 
    The fee required to be deposited in parking meters is hereby levied as a police regulation and inspection fee to cover the cost of providing parking spaces, parking meters and the installation and maintenance thereof; the cost of regulation, inspection, operation, control, and use of parking meters and zones; for the regulation and control of traffic moving in and out and parking in the parking spaces and zones; and for the costs of any resultant traffic administration expense. 
(Code 1964, § 26-111) 
Sec. 23-303. - Revenue to general fund. 
    All funds derived from the use of parking meters shall be paid into the office of the city clerk to the credit of the general fund of the city, and the salary and expense of servicing and maintenance; and the purchase of any equipment shall be paid from the general fund of the city upon the authority of the mayor and board of commissioners. 
(Code 1964, § 26-112) 
Sec. 23-304. - Deposit of slugs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or metallic substitute for a coin of the United States. 
(Code 1964, § 26-113) 
Sec. 23-305. - Tampering with, breaking, etc., meters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with, open or wilfully break or destroy any parking meter. 
(Code 1964, § 26-114) 
Sec. 23-306. - Penalty for violation of division. 
    Any person who shall violate or permit or allow anyone to violate any provision of this division shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed in section 1-5 of this Code; provided that, if the violation is that of overparking; i.e., leaving an automobile in the zoned area for a longer period of time than that for which money has been deposited, or time allowed for free parking, then the violator shall be given a citation envelope which shall allow him to deposit $2.00 within the envelope, then deposit the envelope in the proper containers for same, placed at intervals in the parking zones. The charge for overtime parking is $2.00 if paid on the day of violation by 6:00 p.m. (Monday through Friday-9:00 p.m. Saturday). If not paid by designated time, the minimum charge will be $6.00. 
(Code 1964, § 26-115) 
Sec. 23-307. - Impoundment of vehicles parked in violation of division. 
    Any police officer may impound any motor vehicle parked at a place where parking is prohibited by this division, or which has been parked for more than one (1) hour in excess of the time allowed for parking in any parking meter zone, or which has been involved in two (2) or more violations of this division, for which citation tags have been issued and not presented as required by section 23-266. Any person desiring to redeem such impounded vehicle shall first pay such fine as may be assessed by the municipal judge for the violation for which such vehicle was impounded and such costs as are incurred in impounding and storing such vehicle. 
(Code 1964, § 26-116) 
Sec. 23-308. - Proof of parking violations under division. 
    In any prosecution for parking a vehicle in violation of any provision of this division, proof of registration of a motor vehicle and proof of the violation shall be construed as prima facie proof that the registered owner of such motor vehicle was the user or operator thereof at the time of the violation charged. 
(Code 1964, § 26-117) 
Sec. 23-309. - Parking time limit. 
    Where official signs are erected giving notice that parking is limited to a certain period, i.e., two (2) hours free parking, no person shall park a vehicle for a period exceeding the specified limit, except on Sundays and legal holidays. It shall be a violation of this section for any person to move a vehicle in any manner or leave a parking space and then reenter it to avoid the intent of this section. Any violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 23-306. 
(Code 1964, § 26-118) 
Sec. 23-310. - Exceptions; Miami Tower parking and handicapped parking. 
(a)  Miami Tower parking. For each apartment rented in the Miami Tower located at the southwest corner of First Street and North Main, there shall be allowed one (1) free parking space. Each tenant shall make application for a special permit to be issued by the chief of police. Upon receiving the permit the tenant shall display the same as required by the chief of police in order for the permit to remain valid. Each permit shall be renewed annually but shall in no event be valid except for an actual resident of Miami Towers and then shall remain valid for only the time in which the permit holder shall remain a tenant of the tower. The permit shall only be valid for the parking lots located between Main Street and West A Street in the block between Central and First Street North and the block between First Street North and Second Street North. 
(b)  Handicapped parking. Special handicapped parking shall be designated in the following areas: The northwest and southwest parking space of the controlled public parking lots located between Main Street and East A Street in all blocks from Second Avenue South to Second Avenue North and the northeast and southeast parking space of the controlled parking lots located between Main Street and West A Street in all blocks from Second Avenue South to Second Avenue North. Only vehicles clearly identified as that of a handicapped person shall be allowed in these designated parking areas. Any other vehicle located in these areas shall be deemed to be in violation of this subsection and shall be penalized as set forth in section 23-306. 
(Code 1964, § 26-119) 
Secs. 23-311-23-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MAINTENANCE, CONSTRUCTION AND SAFETY ZONES[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Maintenance, construction and safety zones, 47 O.S. § 11-1301 et seq. 

Sec. 23-326. - Driving through safety zone prohibited. 
    No vehicle shall at any time be driven through or within a safety zone. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1301. 
Sec. 23-327. - Maintenance and construction zones. 
(a)  When any highway has been closed to traffic by the state department of highways, the county or the city while the highway is under repair, maintenance or construction and traffic-control devices or barricades have been erected, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle through, under, over, or around such traffic-control devices or barricades, or otherwise to enter said closed area; except, that the provisions of this subsection shall not apply to persons while engaged in the construction, maintenance and repair of such highway or to persons entering therein for the protection of lives or property; provided that persons having their places of residence or places of business within such closed area may travel, when possible to do so, through such area at their own risk. 
(b)  Whenever construction, repair and maintenance of any highway is being performed under traffic, the governing body having jurisdiction over the highway shall erect, or cause to be erected, traffic-control devices to warn and guide the public, and every person using such highway shall obey all signs, signals, markings, flagmen or other traffic-control devices which are placed to regulate, control, and guide traffic through the construction or maintenance area. 
(c)  No person shall remove, change, modify, deface or alter any traffic-control device or barricade which has been erected on any highway under the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1964, § 26-53) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1302. 
Secs. 23-328-23-345. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - BICYCLES, PLAY VEHICLES, ETC.[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate the operation of bicycles, 47 O.S. § 15-102(a)8; bicycle regulations, 47 O.S. § 11-1201 et seq. 

Sec. 23-346. - Compliance, parental responsibility and scope. 
(a)  It is an offense for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this article. 
(b)  The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  These regulations applicable to bicycles shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated upon any highway or upon any path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles subject to the exceptions stated herein. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1201. 
Sec. 23-347. - Traffic laws apply to persons riding bicycles. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon a roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by the traffic ordinances of this city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this article and except as to those provisions of laws and ordinances which by their nature can have no application. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1202. 
Sec. 23-348. - Manner of riding on bicycles. 
(a)  A person propelling a bicycle shall not ride other than astride a permanent and regular seat attached thereto. 
(b)  No bicycle shall be used to carry more persons at one (1) time than the number for which it is designed and equipped. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1203. 
Sec. 23-349. - Clinging to vehicles. 
    No person on foot, riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled, or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any vehicle upon a roadway. 
(Code 1964, § 26-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1204. 
Sec. 23-350. - Riding on roadways and bicycle paths. 
(a)  Every person operating a bicycle upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction. 
(b)  Persons riding bicycles upon a roadway shall not ride more than two (2) abreast except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(c)  Wherever a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such path and shall not use the roadway. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1205. 
Sec. 23-351. - Carrying articles. 
    No person operating a bicycle shall carry any package, bundle, or article which prevents the rider from keeping at least one (1) hand upon the handle bars. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1206. 
Sec. 23-352. - Equipment. 
(a)  Every bicycle in use at nighttime shall be equipped with a lamp on the front which shall emit a white light visible for a distance of at least five hundred (500) feet to the front and with a red reflector on the rear of a type which shall be visible from all distances from fifty (50) feet to three hundred (300) feet to the rear when directly in front of lawful upper beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle. A lamp emitting a red light visible from a distance of five hundred (500) feet to the rear may be used in addition to the red reflector. 
(b)  Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator to make the braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1207. 
Sec. 23-353. - Use of bicycles or skateboards on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride any bicycle, skateboard, scooter or rollerblade type skate in the downtown business district in a manner that would endanger the health or safety of another. Further, no individual riding such instrument shall perform any tricks or stunts, to include the performance of tricks in, on or around any planters, benches, trashcans or other type public or private improvement. 
(b)  All those found in violation of the above section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be subject to fines, community service, restitution for any damage done, or any other punitive measure the court deems appropriate. 
(Code 1964, § 26-6; Ord. No. 1429, § 1, 8-6-01) 
Secs. 23-354-23-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PEDESTRIANS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference- Pedestrians generally, 47 O.S. § 11-501 et seq. 

Sec. 23-371. - Subject to traffic regulations. 
(a)  A pedestrian shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device specifically applicable to him, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic and pedestrian-control signals as provided in sections 23-49 and 23-50. 
(c)  At all other places pedestrians shall be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this chapter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-501. 
Sec. 23-372. - Right-of-way in crosswalks. 
(a)  When traffic-control signals are not in place or not in operation, the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a pedestrian crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the pedestrian is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the pedestrian is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger. 
(b)  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. 
(c)  Subsection (a) shall not apply under the conditions stated in section 23-373(b). 
(d)  Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a pedestrian to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-502. 
Sec. 23-373. - When pedestrian shall yield. 
(a)  Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  Any pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing has been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(c)  Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in operation pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(Code 1964, §§ 26-124, 26-125) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-503. 
Sec. 23-374. - Roadway to be crossed at right angles; exception. 
    No pedestrian shall cross a roadway at any place other than by a route at right angles to the curb or by the shortest route to the opposite curb, except in a crosswalk. 
(Code 1964, § 26-126) 
Sec. 23-375. - Use of right half of crosswalks. 
    Pedestrians shall move, whenever practicable, upon the right half of crosswalks. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-505. 
Sec. 23-376. - Reserved. 
Sec. 23-377. - Soliciting rides or business in the roadway-Boot blocks. 
(a)  No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride, employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(b)  Those charitable organizations seeking to solicit donations in the roadway from occupants of vehicles (commonly referred to as a "boot block") shall apply for a permit with the chief of police. 
(Code 1964, § 26-128; Ord. No. 1444, § 1, 11-19-01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-507. 
Sec. 23-378. - Walking on roadways. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are provided, it is unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall when practicable walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction, and shall yield to approaching vehicles. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon any portion of a bridge for the purpose of diving or jumping therefrom into a lake, river or stream for recreation. It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to use a bridge where sidewalks are not provided for the purpose of standing or sightseeing. 
(Code 1964, § 2G-127) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-506. 
Sec. 23-379. - Duty of drivers with regard to pedestrians. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Code 1964, § 26-129) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-505. 
Secs. 23-380-23-395. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - MOTORCYCLES AND SIMILAR VEHICLES[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
State Law reference- Motorcycles, etc., generally, 47 O.S. § 40-103 et seq. 

Sec. 23-396. - Generally. 
(a)  No driver of a two- or three-wheel motor vehicle shall carry any other person on, upon or within such vehicle on any street, alley or highway within the city except as hereinafter provided. If any two- or three-wheel motor vehicle with a wheel diameter of twelve (12) inches or greater shall have either a double seating device with double footrests or a sidecar attachment providing a separate seat space within such sidecar attachment for each person riding therein so that such person shall be seated entirely within the body of such sidecar, then it shall be permissible for an operator who has attained the age of sixteen (16) years or older to carry a passenger. A demonstration ride by a licensed dealer or his employee is excepted from the provisions hereof. No motorcycle or motor scooter shall be ridden upon any sidewalk of the city. Handlebars on motorcycles and motor scooters shall not exceed twelve (12) inches in height, measured from the crown or point of attachment. No rider of a motorcycle or motor scooter shall hold to any moving vehicle for the purpose of being propelled. No driver of a motorcycle or motor scooter shall pass other vehicles in between lanes of traffic traveling in the same direction, authorized emergency vehicles excepted. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motorcycle, motor driven cycle (including minibikes, mopeds, gopeds, motorscooters, and motorized skateboards) without having a valid Class A, B, C, or D license with a motorcycle endorsement, as well as complying with all other State and municipal laws and ordinances relating to the operation thereof. (See similar provision in O.S. Title 47 Section 6-101, et seq.). 
(Ord. No. 1477, § 1, 6-3-04) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 40-103. 
Sec. 23-397. - Speed. 
    No person shall operate any motorcycle or any motor scooter at a speed greater than the speed limit legally posted; provided, however, in no event nor at any time may an operator under the age of sixteen (16) years operate a motorcycle or motor scooter at a speed greater than thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 40-104. 
Sec. 23-398. - Required equipment. 
    The following equipment shall be required on all motorcycles and all motor scooters except on actual trail rides conducted outside of public roads and highways: 
(1)  Rear view mirrors. All vehicles covered under this section shall be equipped with two (2) mirrors, containing a reflection surface of not less than three (3) inches in diameter, mounted one (1) on each side of the vehicle and positioned so as to enable the operator to clearly view the roadway for a distance of two hundred (200) feet to the rear of his vehicle. 
(2)  Windshield. All vehicles covered under this section shall be equipped with a windshield of sufficient quality, size and thickness to protect the operator from foreign objects, except that in lieu of such windshield the operator shall wear goggles or a face shield of material and design to protect him from foreign objects. 
(3)  Brakes. All vehicles covered under this section shall be equipped with brakes adequate to control the movement of same to stop and hold such vehicles, including two (2) separate means of applying the brakes; one (1) means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the front wheel and one (1) means shall be effective to apply the brakes to the rear wheels. All such vehicles shall be equipped with a stop lamp on the rear of the vehicle, which shall display a red or amber light, or any shade of color between red and amber, visible from a distance of not less than one hundred (100) feet to the rear in normal sunlight, and which shall be actuated upon application of the service brake. 
(4)  Speedometer. All vehicles covered under this section shall be equipped with a properly operating speedometer capable of registering at least the maximum legal speed limit for that vehicle. 
(5)  Fenders. All vehicles covered under this section shall be equipped with a fender over each wheel. All fenders shall be of the type provided by the manufacturer. 
(6)  Lights. All vehicles covered under this section shall carry at least one (1) lighted headlamp capable of showing a white light visible at least three hundred (300) feet in the direction in which the same are proceeding, and one (1) tail lamp mounted on the rear which, when lighted, shall emit a red light plainly visible from at least three hundred (300) feet to the rear, and such lights required by this section shall be burning whenever such vehicles are in motion during the period from one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise and at any other time when, due to insufficient light or unfavorable atmospheric conditions, persons and vehicles on the streets are not clearly discernible at a distance of at least five hundred (500) feet ahead. 
(7)  Headgear. No person under eighteen (18) years of age shall operate or ride upon any vehicle covered under this section unless such person is equipped with and wearing on the head a crash helmet of a type which complies with standards established by the state. All crash helmets shall consist of lining, padding and chin straps and be of the type as not to distort the view of the driver. 
(Code 1964, § 26-131) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 40-105. 
Sec. 23-399. - Safety helmet prerequisite to renting, leasing or lending. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to rent, lease or lend any motorcycle, motorscooter, or motorbike to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years without first ascertaining that such person or passenger is equipped with a type of safety helmet approved by the chief of police. 
(Code 1964, § 26-132) 
Sec. 23-400. - Operator's license or permit prerequisite to use. 
    No person shall rent, lease or lend any motorcycle, motor scooter or motor bike without first ascertaining that such person possesses a valid state operator's license or permit for the operation of a motor vehicle upon the public streets and highways of this state. 
(Code 1964, § 26-133) 
Secs. 23-401-23-415. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - VEHICLE CONDITION, EQUIPMENT, ETC. 

Sec. 23-416. - Vehicle equipment generally. 
    Every vehicle operated within the city shall be equipped with such lights, brakes, signaling or warning devices, mirrors and other equipment as are required by the state law, all of which equipment shall be maintained in good, safe working condition. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle within the city, unless it is so equipped. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to use on any vehicle in the city any device or equipment which is prohibited by state law. 
(Code 1964, § 26-7) 
State Law reference- Equipment of vehicles, 47 O.S. § 12-101 et seq. 
Sec. 23-417. - Muffler noise and smoke abatement equipment. 
    Every motor vehicle shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order and in constant operation to prevent excessive or unusual noises and annoying smoke, and no person shall use a muffler cutout, bypass, or similar device upon a motor vehicle on a street. No person shall modify the exhaust system of a motor vehicle in any manner which will amplify or increase the noise or sound emitted louder than that emitted by the muffler originally installed on the vehicle. 
(Code 1964, § 26-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-402. 
Sec. 23-418. - Inspection sticker. 
(a)  No person shall drive or move on any highway any motor vehicle, including motorcycles, trailers, semitrailers or pole trailers, or ancient vehicles which are not used primarily incidental to historical or exhibition purposes only or which have been modified from their original state of manufacture by changes or modifications to the engine and/or chassis, which are licensed by the Oklahoma Tax Commission and operated on the streets or highways of this state or any combination thereof, unless the equipment upon any and every vehicle is in good working order and adjustment as required in O.S. tit. 47 and the vehicle is bearing an official inspection sticker and is in such safe mechanical condition as not to endanger the driver or other occupant of any vehicle upon the highway. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any manufactured home which requires a permit to be moved upon the highways of this state; nor shall the provisions of this section apply to any ancient vehicle which has not been modified from its original state of manufacture. Ancient vehicles shall be exempt from retrofitted pollution control devices. 
(Code 1964, § 26-57) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 851. 
Sec. 23-419. - State vehicle license. 
    It shall be an offense for any person to operate a motor vehicle of any kind upon the streets or highways within the city without a state vehicle license as may be required by law of the state, or to fail to display the state vehicle license as may be required by law of the state. 
(Code 1964, § 26-26) 
State Law reference- Vehicle license and registration, 47 O.S. § 22 et seq. 
Sec. 23-420. - Loads on vehicles. 
(a)  No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any highway unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of its load from dropping, sifting, leaking, blowing or otherwise escaping therefrom, except that sand may be dropped for the purpose of securing traction, or water or other substances may be sprinkled on a roadway in cleaning or maintaining such roadway. 
(b)  No person shall operate on any highway any vehicle with any load unless such load and any covering thereon is securely fastened so as to prevent such covering or load from becoming loose, detached or in any manner a hazard to other users of the highway. Any vehicle loaded with sand, cinders, or other loose material susceptible to blowing or otherwise escaping shall have such load covered so as to prevent the blowing or escaping of such load from the vehicle. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to trucks loaded with livestock, poultry or agricultural products only except baled agricultural products, provided that any such truck shall be so constructed or loaded as to prevent such livestock or poultry from escaping therefrom. 
(Code 1964, § 22-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 14-105. 
Sec. 23-421. - Child restraint devices. 
    Every driver, when transporting a child under eight (8) years of age in a motor vehicle operated on the roadways, streets, or highways located within the City of Miami, Oklahoma, shall provide for the protection of said child by properly using a child passenger restraint system in the manner provided by Oklahoma State Law at 47 O.S. § 11-1112, as the same is in effect now and as may be subsequently amended by the State Legislature. Any person who violates this provision shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of $50.00 plus court costs. The fine shall be suspended and the court costs limited to a maximum of $15.00 in the case of the first offense upon proof of purchase or acquisition by loan of a child passenger restraint system. 
(Ord. No. 1284, § 1(26-63.1), 9-18-89; Ord. No. 1650, § 1, 11-3-2015) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1112. 
Sec. 23-422. - Safety belts. 
(a)  Every operator and front seat passenger of a passenger car operated in this city shall wear a properly adjusted and fastened safety seat belt system, required to be installed in the motor vehicle when manufactured pursuant to Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standard 208. For the purposes of this section, "passenger car" shall mean "vehicle" as defined in 47 O.S. § 1102, except that "passenger car" shall not include trucks, truck tractors, recreational vehicles, motorcycles, motorized bicycles or vehicles used primarily for farm use and licensed pursuant to the provisions of 47 O.S. § 1134. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to an operator or passenger of a passenger car in which the operator or passenger possesses a written verification from a physician licensed in this state that he is unable to wear a safety seat belt system for medical reasons. Provided, the issuance of such verification by a physician, in good faith, shall not give rise to, nor shall such physician thereby incur, any liability whatsoever in damages or otherwise, to any person injured by reason of such failure to wear a safety seat belt system. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to an operator of a motor vehicle who is a route carrier of the United States Postal Service. 
(d)  Fine and court costs for violating this section shall not exceed $20.00. 
(Ord. No. 1283, § 1(26-63), 9-18-89; Ord. No. 1372, § 1, 11-3-97) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 12-417. 
Secs. 23-423-23-440. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - MISCELLANEOUS RULES 

Sec. 23-441. - Unattended vehicles. 
    No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine and effectively setting the brake thereon and, when standing upon any grade, turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the roadway. 
(Code 1964, § 26-85) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1101. 
Sec. 23-442. - Limitations on backing. 
    No vehicle shall be backed upon any street except for such distance as may be necessary to permit the vehicle to enter the proper driving lane from a parked position. Such backing shall be done only after the driver of the vehicle has ascertained that such movement can be made without endangering other traffic. 
(Code 1964, § 26-49) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1102. 
Sec. 23-443. - Riding on motorcycles, etc. 
    No person shall drive a motorcycle, motor scooter, or a motorbicycle while transporting more than one (1) passenger, except a motorcycle, motor scooter or motorbicycle factory-designed for the purpose of carrying additional passengers. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1103. 
Sec. 23-444. - Hindrance of driver; capacity of school buses. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle when it is so loaded, or when there are in the front seat such a number of persons, exceeding three (3), as to obstruct the view of the driver to the front or sides of the vehicle or as to interfere with the driver's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle. 
(b)  No passenger in a vehicle shall ride in such position as to interfere with the driver's view ahead or to the sides or to interfere with his control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle. 
(c)  No school bus shall be operated on the streets or highways in the city when loaded with passengers in excess of the number of which such bus is designed to carry. The number of passengers, as determined by the local school board, which the bus is designed to carry shall be posted in a conspicuous place on the bus. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1104. 
Sec. 23-445. - Opening and closing vehicle doors. 
    No person shall open the door of a motor vehicle on the side available to moving traffic unless and until it is reasonably safe to do so; nor shall any person leave a door open on the side of a motor vehicle available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1105. 
Sec. 23-446. - Coasting. 
(a)  The driver of a motor vehicle when traveling on a downgrade shall not coast with the gears of such vehicle in neutral. 
(b)  The driver of any motor vehicle when traveling upon a downgrade shall not coast with the clutch disengaged. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1107. 
Sec. 23-447. - Following fire apparatus prohibited. 
(a)  The driver of any vehicle other than one on official business shall not follow any fire apparatus traveling in response to a fire alarm closer than five hundred (500) feet or drive into or park such vehicle within the block where fire apparatus has stopped in answer to a fire alarm. The driver of any vehicle other than one on official business shall not follow any emergency vehicle or shall not purposely drive to any location on a highway where an emergency exists which would interfere with the free movement of authorized emergency vehicles or any other traffic using the highway at that location. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, the definition of emergency shall include traffic accidents, airplane accidents, disasters, explosions, civil disturbances and (without limitation by the foregoing) any other related circumstances which tend to cause traffic congestion. 
(c)  The purpose of this section is to eliminate sightseers and other persons who do not have official business at the scene of an emergency, and whose presence would tend to cause traffic congestion. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1108. 
Sec. 23-448. - Driving over fire hose. 
    No vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the fire department when laid down on any street or private driveway to be used at any fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the fire department official in command. 
(Code 1964, § 26-51) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1109. 
Sec. 23-449. - Obstructing intersection or crosswalk. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1964, § 26-48) 
Sec. 23-450. - Obstructing traffic. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park any vehicle upon or in any street in such manner as to unnecessarily interfere with or interrupt the free passage of other vehicles or hold up traffic. 
(Code 1964, § 26-88) 
Sec. 23-451. - Driving through parade or procession. 
    No vehicle, except apparatus and vehicles of the fire and police departments, vehicles carrying the United States mail, and ambulances engaged in emergency work, shall be driven through any funeral procession, parade or other procession. 
(Code 1964, § 26-50) 
Sec. 23-452. - Driving in sidewalk area. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not drive within any sidewalk area except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1964, § 26-52) 
Sec. 23-453. - Putting glass, etc., on highway. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit upon any highway any glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans or any other substances likely to injure any person, animal or vehicle upon such highway. 
(b)  Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any highway any destructive or injurious material shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. 
(c)  Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a highway shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the highway from such vehicle. 
(d)  No person shall throw any substance at a standing vehicle or any occupant thereof, nor shall any person throw any substance at a person on or adjacent to a highway. 
(Code 1964, § 26-10) 
Cross reference- Littering from vehicles, § 15-81. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 47 O.S. § 11-1110. 
Sec. 23-454. - Golf carts for use by hospital personnel-Transportation of patients. 
(a)  Golf carts shall be allowed to transport patients between their attending physician's medical building and the hospital, provided that the following subsections are strictly observed: 
(1)  Golf carts are to be operated during daylight hours only. Daylight hours are from sun up to sun down. 
(2)  Flashing lights, extended flags, or other similar warning device is to be attached to the golf cart at all times to alert others to the carts presence. 
(3)  Safety belts are to be utilized by transported patients at all times. 
(4)  Carts are to adhere to an established cart path as established by the city police chief. 
(b)  Failure to abide by the provisions in paragraph (a) will constitute a misdemeanor and will be punishable by a $50.00 fine and subsequent court costs. 
(Ord. No. 1422, § 1, 6-18-01) 
Chapter 24 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 6-376 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Tampering, etc., with utility service. 
(a)  As used in this section: 
(1)  Utility shall mean any person or district, whether private, municipal, body politic or cooperative, which is engaged in the sale, generation, distribution, or delivery of electricity, water, sewer or gas. 
(2)  Utility service shall mean the furnishing, sale, generation, distribution or delivery of electricity, water, sewer or gas by a utility. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, with intent to defraud a utility, to: 
(1)  Alter, tamper with, injure or knowingly allow the altering, tampering with or injuring of any pipeline, line, wire, conduit, conductor, meter, meter seal, transformer or other equipment used by a utility to deliver or register service. 
(2)  Prevent any installed metering device from registering correctly the quantity of service passing through such metering device. 
(3)  Make or cause to be made any connection between pipelines, lines, wires, conduits, conductors, meters, transformers or other equipment in such manner as to prevent the correct registration of service by any metering device, or to otherwise use electricity without the consent of the utility. 
(4)  Supply of cause to be supplied any utility service to any person without such service first passing through the metering device provided for the utility for measuring and registering the quantity of service. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to apply to licensed and certified contractors while performing usual and ordinary service in accordance with recognized standards. 
(d)  Violation of this section is a misdemeanor. A person convicted of violating this section shall be required to make restitution to the utility, along with all other punitive measures the city municipal court may impose. If the utility is a city utility the person convicted shall also be required to reimburse the city for the expenses incurred by the city correcting the violation. 
(Code 1964, §§ 13-1, 13-22; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 1494, § 2, 12-5-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1494, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2005, renumbered §§ 24-1-24-10 as §§ 24-164-24-173. Section 2 of said ordinance reenacted the provisions of § 24-1 as set out prior to the amendment of Ord. No. 1488, § 1, adopted Sept. 6, 2005. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 71 O.S. § 23. 
Sec. 24-2. - [Community development block grant funding requirements.] 
    It shall be required that any entity connecting its facilities to utilities of the City of Miami or the Miami Public Utilities Authority which utilities are Community Development Block Grant - Economic Development Infrastructure financed and funded infrastructure improvements shall as a condition of said connection enter an agreement to provide job tracking data to the City of Miami as a condition of attaching or connecting to the utility improvement. 
(Ord. No. 1456, § 1, 7-1-02) 
Sec. 24-3. - Right of entry. 
    Every person owning, leasing, operating or in possession of any building or structure receiving City of Miami utility service must provide reasonable access for the Utility Department to enter upon the grounds for the purpose of installing, maintaining, or reading water and electrical meters, and it shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant or lessee of any premises to prevent or to refuse to permit such entry. Reasonable access includes, but is not limited to, providing entrance to private roads or fields if this entry is required to install, read or maintain water or electrical meters. The Utility Department shall, upon request of the owner, occupant or lessee of any premises, exhibit their authority to make such entry. 
(Ord. No. 2019-02, 4-2-2019) 
Secs. 24-4-24-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RATES AND CHARGES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-26. - Established. 
    The following rates and charges are hereby established and shall be collected monthly from all consumers of utility services furnished by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01) 
Sec. 24-26.1. - Exceptions for employees. 
    Any and all residential rates for electric, water, sewer and solid waste usage and services provided by Miami Special Utility Authority (MSUA) hereinafter set forth shall be reduced by twenty percent (20%) for the following: 
(1)  This reduced rate shall apply for the primary residence of all full-time employees of the city, or any other employee approved by the city council, including the department of public utilities receiving the above-mentioned utilities/services, provided that said employee was hired by the city on or before June 30, 2018. 
(2)  This discount will not apply in any manner to probationary employees, temporary part-time employees, employees not receiving utilities or services supplied by the city and elected or appointed officials. 
(3)  This discount will extend to retired employees hired by the city on or before June 30, 2018, qualifying for and receiving authorized retirement benefits. It will also extend to the surviving spouse of the deceased full-time employee hired by the city on or before June 30, 2018 who dies during their eligible service period so long as the surviving spouse owns/rents a residence in question and remains unmarried and is not cohabitating with another. 
(4)  Provided, however, if any qualified city employee hired on or before June 30, 2018, retires on or before June 30, 2023, and is vested at that time, said employee will continue to receive the discount as long as he/she continues to otherwise qualify under the requirements set forth herein. Any qualified city employee hired on or before June 30, 2018, who retires on or after July 1, 2023, shall no longer receive the discount as of the effective date of the retirement. 
(5)  Provided, further, if any qualified city employee, retiree or surviving spouse should move their primary residence outside of the MSUA service area, they will forever lose this benefit, and even if they should later move their primary residence back into the MSUA service area, this benefit will not be reinstated. 
(Ord. No. 1336, § 1, 6-19-95; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 2018-08, § 1, 6-26-2018) 
Sec. 24-27. - Purpose, intent. 
    The following rates and charges are designated to produce revenue sufficient to properly and adequately maintain the utility systems according to reasonable standards of capacity and reliability. The intent and basis for the rate design is to provide for equitable charges, insofar as is practical, for each customer classification and for each individual customer; based on the character of loads served and the resultant costs of providing the services. 
(Code 1964, § 13-2; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01) 
Sec. 24-28. - Service deposits required. 
(a)  All applications for new electrical, sewer, sanitation and water service require a minimum deposit and are defined as follows: 
(1)  Residential accounts: 
a.  Homeowner(s) and lessee(s) not currently in the City of Miami billing data base ..... $150.00 
b.  Person(s) who are not in good standing shall be required to pay two (2) times the average monthly bill determined with reference to the most recent twelve (12) month period in which the premises were occupied. 
(2)  Commercial accounts: 
a.  Twice the expected average monthly bill as estimated by the utility. 
(3)  Landlords of rental property: 
a.  Need not put up a deposit if the landlord is in good payment standing as determined by the utility. If not in good standing, the deposit for the applicable residential or commercial account will apply. 
When the deposit required is more than $100.00, the requirement may be satisfied by one (1) of the following alternatives: 
(1)  A certificate of deposit properly assigned; 
(2)  An unconditional letter of credit from a federally insured financial institution. 
(3)  Letters of Good Standing: 
a.  Residential Accounts -Letter of good standing from the requester's previous utility company, applicable only to residential accounts. 
b.  All Other Account Types -Letter of good standing from three (3) entities doing business with the requester. 
(b)  The utility board shall have the authority to establish policies that shall be applied equally throughout the service to refund the deposits required in this section to those customers who qualify for the same under the policies established by the utility board. 
(Code 1964, § 13-5; Ord. No. 1290, § 1, 4-16-90; Ord. No. 1413, § 1, 11-6-00; Ord. No. 1549, § 1, 10-19-09; Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 6-7-10; Ord. No. 1664, 12-6-2016; Ord. No. 2017-06, 4-18-2017, eff. 7-1-2017) 
Sec. 24-29. - Billing period defined. 
    The billing period may be referred to as "month" or "billing month." The intent is to represent a period of approximately thirty (30) days between regular meter readings irrespective of calendar months. The first bill may be for services spanning less than 30 days. 
(Code 1964, § 13-6; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 2017-03, § 1, 1-17-2017) 
Sec. 24-30. - Effective date of certain rate schedules. 
    The rate schedules set out in sections 24-36, 24-37, 24-57 through 24-61, and 24-82 shall be in effect thirty (30) days from the adoption of Ordinance No. 1436 (October 15, 2001) by the city council and shall be applied to all December 2001 and subsequent months' usage beginning with January 2002 billings and on all billings thereafter until otherwise amended by the city council. 
(Code 1964, § 13-7; Ord. No. 1290, § 1, 4-16-90; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01) 
Sec. 24-30.4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-08, § 2, adopted May 16, 2017, repealed § 24-30.4, which pertained to utility board-Adjustments to rates and derived from Code 1964, § 13-15.3; Ord. No. 1290, § 1, adopted April 16, 1990; Ord. No. 1373, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 1997; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, adopted Oct. 15, 2001; Ord. No. 1480, § 1, adopted June 21, 2004. 
Sec. 24-30.5. - Utility board-Rate incentives. 
    Other provisions of this article notwithstanding, the utility board shall have the authority to negotiate with any prospective commercial customer or any existing commercial customer who increases its load by such an amount as to qualify for a rate incentive for such loads from the city's power supplier, in order to reduce that customer's rates so as to pass all or a part of that rate incentive on to the customer. 
(Ord. No. 1294, § 1, 6-18-90; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01) 
Sec. 24-31. - Use of service without payment. 
    Any person using water, electrical energy or sewer services from the department of public utilities without paying, or who shall be found guilty of breaking the seal of any meter, switch or valve, or who shall install any piping or wiring, make connections, or attach wires, or any electrical device or appliance to wires in a manner so that electrical energy or water may be used without being supplied under the terms of this article, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any person convicted of violating this section shall be required to make restitution to the city, along with any other punitive measures as determined by the court. 
(Code 1964, § 13-22; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01) 
Sec. 24-32. - Due date for bills; penalty for late payment. 
    All accounts provided for by this article, together with the charge for solid waste services and other services furnished by and billed by the city shall be due and payable monthly on or before the due date printed on the customer bill. If a bill is not paid when due, ten percent (10%) will be added monthly to the unpaid balance thereon. This late charge may be waived at the discretion of the city manager or his designee for appropriate circumstances. 
(Code 1964, § 13-18; Ord. No. 1290, § 1, 4-16-90; Ord. No. 1342, § 1, 1-15-96; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 6-7-10) 
Sec. 24-33. - Interruption of service for failure to pay and discontinuance and final billing. 
(a)  Interruption of service for failure to pay. It shall be the duty of the city manager or designee to cause any utility service furnished to any person to be interrupted, without further notice, if such person shall fail, refuse or neglect to pay on or before ten (10) days following the due date in which such utility service is furnished by the city. During the event of this process the following actions and fees may apply: 
(1)  A delinquent call/text notification will be administered the next business day following the corresponding monthly due date and a fee equal to the city's computer system cost will be applied to all applicably tried accounts. The notification call/text will notify the customer of the intended cutoff date unless payment in full is received. 
(2)  If a utility service bill is not fully paid on or before the tenth (10 th ) day following a billing due date, utility service will be interrupted for nonpayment and the utility account charged the dispatch-interrupt fee at the time the account is placed in the queue for utility service interruption. 
(3)  If a utility service is interrupted pursuant to this section, the city, or its agents shall not restore the utility service until the full amount of the outstanding utility service bill with penalties provided in this section, and any applicable utility service charges to restore the service is paid. 
(b)  Discontinuance and Final Billing. The city manager or designee shall, in one (1) weeks' time from making the above interruption, discontinue the utility service and compute the amount due the city, with penalties thereon. They shall also credit the account with any monies, credit, or deposit in the hands of the city deposited by any such person as a meter deposit. If, thereafter, any such person shall request the city restore or re-establish utility services, such person shall pay all charges in arrears and pay a new meter deposit as is required by the city prior to dispatching for the connection/restore. 
(Code 1964, § 13-19; Ord. No. 1290, § 1, 4-16-90; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 6-7-10; Ord. No. 2017-06, 4-18-2017, eff. 7-1-2017) 
Sec. 24-34. - Failure to receive statement. 
    The failure of any customer to receive a statement for any utility charges provided for in this article shall not excuse the customer from their obligation to pay such charges within the time specified in this article. 
(Code 1964, § 13-20; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01) 
Sec. 24-35. - Account dispatch fees. 
    A customer's utility service account will be assessed the following dispatch fees:

    Any dispatch fee may be waived upon the written recommendation of the customer service department head or designee. Any waivers will be reported to council at their next regular meeting. 
(Code 1964, § 13-21; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 6-7-10; Ord. No. 2017-06, 4-18-2017, eff. 7-1-2017)

Sec. 24-37. - Sanitary sewer rate. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases shall, for the purposes of this section, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
(1)  City shall mean the City of Miami, Oklahoma, together with all its governing and operational bodies. 
(2)  Sanitary sewer system shall mean all facilities for collection, pumping, treating and disposing of wastewaters. 
(3)  Use shall mean the monthly gallonage of water billed to any user of the sanitary sewer system as measured through the water meter. 
(4)  User shall mean any person, establishment or owner who discharges sewage into the sanitary sewer system of the City or any sanitary sewer system connected thereto, or which ultimately reaches and discharges into the sanitary sewer system of the City. 
(5)  User charge shall mean a charge on a user of the sanitary sewer system for the cost of improvements, extensions, operations, maintenance and replacement of such sanitary sewer system. 
(b)  Establishing rates . Each user of the sanitary sewer system shall be charge the following rates per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water usage commencing on the following dates: 
Usage Charge Effective 
Nov-18 Effective 
Oct-19 Effective 
Oct-20 Effective 
Oct-21 Residential $6.07 $6.98 $7.68 $7.83 Commercial and municipal $6.07 $6.98 $7.68 $7.83  
(c)  Excessive strength charges. Users shall be charged a surcharge for excessive strength waste when the user's waste discharge biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) exceeds two hundred fifty (250) mg/l, or when the user's waste discharge suspended solids exceeds two hundred fifty (250) mg/l. The surcharge shall be calculated by the following formula: 
Cs = [Bc (B) + Sc (S) + Pc (P)] Vu 
(Based on Model No. 2, 40 CFR 35, Appendix E) 
Symbols and definitions: 
Cs = A surcharge for wastewaters of excessive strength. Bc = O & M cost for treatment of a unit of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD). B = Concentration of BOD from a user above a base level. Sc = O & M cost for treatment of a unit of suspended solids (SS). S = Concentration of SS from a user above a base level. PC = O & M cost for treatment of a unit of any pollutant. P = Concentration of any pollutant from a user above a base level. Vu = Volume contribution from a user per unit of time.  
(d)  Disposition of funds. The funds derived from the sewer use charges shall be deposited in the general revenues of the department of public utilities to be used for the maintenance, repair, operation, expansion, replacement or reconstruction of the sanitary sewer system. 
(e)  Records. The department of public utilities shall maintain proper and adequate records to reflect the costs of providing sanitary sewer service and to document compliance with federal regulations pertaining to this section and shall review said costs with federal regulations pertaining to this section and shall review said costs biannually and adjust as necessary the user charge system to accomplish the following: 
(1)  Maintain the proportionate distribution of operation and maintenance costs among users and user classes; 
(2)  Generate sufficient revenue to pay the total operation and maintenance costs necessary to the proper operation and maintenance (including replacement) of the treatment works; and 
(3)  Apply excess revenues collected from a class of users to the costs of operation and maintenance attributable to that class for the next year, and the rates shall be adjusted accordingly. 
(f)  Toxic pollutants charges. Each user that discharges any toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the cost of managing the effluent or the sludge of the treatment works shall pay for such increased costs. 
(g)  Charges for extraneous flows. The costs of operation and maintenance for all flows not directly attributable to users (such as infiltration/inflow) shall be distributed among users on the same basis as operation and maintenance charges. 
(h)  Charges for unmetered water to sewer. Users may be charged a surcharge for unmetered water entering the sanitary sewer. 
(1)  This includes but is not limited to: roof drains, driveway drains, surface drains, area drains, open or leaking service lines, any water which does not pass through the customer water service meter (unmetered). 
(2)  The monthly surcharge shall be based on the following formula: ($0.55 per 100 square feet of area drained) = monthly charge. 
(Code 1964, § 13-16.1; Ord. No. 1290, § 1, 4-16-90; Ord. No. 1369, § 1, 10-20-97; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 10-15-01; Ord. No. 1554, § 2, 12-7-09; Ord. No. 2018-15, § 1, 10-2-2018) 
Sec. 24-38. - No statement fee and meter re-read. 
(a)  A utility customer shall submit the billing statement with tender of payment. If the utility customer fails to comply with this requirement, then a $5.00 administrative fee shall be assessed. 
(b)  A utility customer may request a meter re-read. If the meter re-read indicates less usage than indicated on the billing statement, then no dispatch fee shall be assessed for the re-read. If the meter re-read indicates equivalent or greater usage than indicated on the billing statement, then the dispatch fee shall be assessed. 
(c)  One hundred thousand dollars of the accumulated funds from these assessments shall be transferred and budgeted for roadway maintenance for the fiscal year 2010-2011. 
(Ord. No. 1561, § 1, 6-7-10; Ord. No. 1563, § 1, 7-6-10; Ord. No. 2017-06, 4-18-2017, eff. 7-1-2017)

This temporary adjustment shall apply to customer usage only.

Any customer which has paid such bill(s) prior to the effective date of this ordinance shall receive an overpayment credit to their account for application to future billing. No cash refunds shall be issued. Late fees for this service period and this bill shall not begin to accrue until the next succeeding billing cycle. Any customer which has paid a January 2014 bill prior to the effective date of this ordinance shall receive an overpayment credit to their account for application to future billing. No cash refunds shall be issued.
